quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: One of the big reasons why I think curiosity loops are really useful is that it really fights the fact that there's a lot of bad advice out there. And it's not bad because it's not well-intentioned, but it's bad because it's not contextual.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: A question's good if it's specific, if it solicits rationale, and it's not biased. You don't want to start a question with, here's what I think because people have this tendency to want to please you or to agree with you.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Don't do what people tell you to do. Take it as an input and look for the hard feedback. Look for things that you strongly disagree with or are surprises to you. Because to me, I think these loops are more about looking around the corner and seeing if there's anything you missed in terms of the integrity of your decision making process.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: It's this internal scorecard of what really matters to you in your decision making process as opposed to the external scorecard of status, money, wealth, how other people perceive you, that often we feel really pressured by. So it's this great way to look back and see how well do decisions, or how well do my situations in life align with my values.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Explore and exploit, if you're familiar with it from growth background, is really just around what mode you're in. You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, how well it works, whether or not it fits for you. Or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep and then you're just trying to get more.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Don't be the frog. If you take a frog and you put in a pot and you increase the temperature degree by degree by degree, the frog doesn't notice and before it knows, it's boiled alive. It's really easy to be a victim of inertia. It's really easy for all of us to be the frog where there are little things that make us uncomfortable, and we sit with them.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: I think it's a terrible outcome to wake up one day and be late career and feel trapped because you have a certain lifestyle or a certain expectations of the people around you that you have to go work this job, but then you look at yourself in the mirror and you're not happy going in there. I think that's a terrible trap that we should all try to avoid.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: There's an outer scorecard, which is how the rest of the world evaluates you, how you keep score in terms of external factors. Top 10 lists, wealth status, title. And then your inner scorecard is things that actually matter to you, how you spent your day, how good of a person you are. Did you have an adventure today? Were you kind?

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: My hot take is that for the vast majority of people, they probably do not need a coach. If you're looking for a mentor, a coach is actually a terrible mentor in some ways because it's this one person's opinion. It's actually way better to run a curiosity loop and get the benefit of a couple different minds on a specific topic.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: We're not powerless, even though this game is rigged. We can study the game, we can help each other, and we can actually start to call out some of those rules and then find ways around them.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Eating your vegetables is really this idea around how little kids don't really develop an appreciation for vegetables until they're 10 or 12 exposures in. You have to do things a number of times before you really develop an affinity for it. Because the first time you do it, you're just not going to be good.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Figure out, maybe the night before, the one thing that you want to get done in your day, and then at the earliest opportunity, just try to give yourself five minutes on it. Just five minutes. Usually, what I find is that five minutes turns into a solid hour just knocking that thing out early in my day.

takeaways: Use curiosity loops to fight bad advice - gather structured input from 5-10 people who know you well or have subject matter expertise, then look for surprises and disagreements rather than following what they say.
Apply the explore/exploit framework to your career - early on, prioritize exploration with a thesis to discover what you love; once you find something rich, shift to exploit mode to go deeper.
Don't be the frog - be aware of your environment and whether the temperature is rising; it's easy to be a victim of inertia and miss when a situation is slowly becoming untenable.
Build an internal scorecard based on your values rather than chasing the external scorecard of status, titles, and wealth - this prevents waking up late career feeling trapped and unhappy.

Eat your vegetables by exposing yourself to uncomfortable skills 10-12 times before deciding you dislike them - the first time you try something, you won't be good at it, but persistence builds affinity.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the common belief that everyone needs a coach - argues most people don't need one and curiosity loops are often better than paying for one person's opinion
Contradicts the instinct to follow advice from trusted people - instead look for what surprises or bothers you as signals of blind spots
Acknowledges the game is rigged while refusing victimhood - empowers agency even within unfair systems

episodes.episode_title: How to build a high-performing growth team | Adam Fishman (Patreon, Lyft, Imperfect Foods)

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: The founders of that company were looking for what I would call a silver bullet strategy to their growth challenges. And what they really needed was to create a strategy to add on new growth loops and a system for how to execute against that strategy.
quotes.context: Adam reflects on a mismatch at Wyzant where founders expected quick fixes rather than systematic growth building.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: The goal of the competency model is not to find a unicorn human being that is an 11 out of 10 on every one of these things, because frankly, that person doesn't exist. The goal is to create a well-rounded team so that you're hiring and balancing skills across your team and that you don't have any gaps in your portfolio.
quotes.context: Adam explains that growth teams should be evaluated holistically rather than searching for impossible unicorn candidates.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: One of the things that people don't easily understand is that most people come to your product with an emotional frame and a lot of people want to appeal to their logical brain right away. And the reality is, don't do that. You have to understand the mindset that people are in.
quotes.context: Adam shares his background in consumer psychology and why understanding emotional motivations matters more than logical appeals.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: Seeking the solution in a customer interview is never going to work, right? You seek to understand and then you take that away and you can think through what the model should look like and how things should change as a result.
quotes.context: Adam agrees with the Collison brothers' view that user research builds your mental model of customers, not direct solutions.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: Influence is one of the biggest and hardest skills to develop. It's no different in a growth practitioner and in some cases it can even be harder because sometimes people come in with a preconceived notion of what growth is and isn't and you have to change their mind.
quotes.context: Adam describes influence as the pinnacle competency that requires constant relearning with each new company or role.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: If you're going to hire a junior person, the key is, how do you help them learn? If you don't know what you're doing as the founder or the leader, you're not going to be able to help them yourself. So you've got to be willing to invest in advisors, outside education, mentorship, coaching.
quotes.context: Adam warns that hiring junior growth talent without support systems leads to enthusiastic people running through walls when doors exist nearby.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: I tend to skew more towards internal hire to be perfectly honest, because I believe in creating opportunity inside a company. I think it's not done often enough. And I also believe that helping people transition into new roles is a way to get more people into the practice.
quotes.context: Adam recommends internal hires for growth roles because they already have customer knowledge and faster time to results.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: Onboarding is the only part of your product experience that a hundred percent of people are ever going to touch. Good luck getting a hundred percent feature adoption of anything else in your product. It's also the first opportunity that you have as a company to deliver on the promise that you made out in the marketplace.
quotes.context: Adam explains why onboarding is such an underappreciated growth lever with universal impact on the user experience.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: I like to think of your brand is the promise that you're making and your product experience is your delivery of that promise. And those two things have to be in lockstep with each other or you're going to have mismatched expectations and some really disappointed customers.
quotes.context: Adam frames the brand-product relationship as a promise-delivery system that must stay synchronized.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: I have seen companies shift their curve outward by 10, 15, 20 percentage points from making those changes, especially when you consider that churn is most likely to happen in the very earliest usage of the product. If you can get people past that hump, it's a really invaluable part of the product to work on.
quotes.context: Adam quantifies the retention impact of onboarding improvements and early habit formation.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: I actually think if you're doing it right, sometimes conversion should actually decrease a little bit. So you might actually have fewer people getting all the way through successfully, but I think that's okay because a lot of those people were probably not the right people for your product.
quotes.context: Adam shares the counterintuitive insight that good onboarding may reduce conversion but improve retention by filtering wrong-fit users.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: When you're interviewing at a company, you are actually investing an even more scarce resource. You're investing your time. There is no way to get more time. We're all on a finite clock. You can always get more money.
quotes.context: Adam reframes job decisions as investment choices where time is the scarcest and most valuable resource.

takeaways: Build balanced growth teams: Don't search for unicorn candidates - hire to fill competency gaps across execution, customer knowledge, strategy, and communication.
Onboarding is your highest-leverage growth investment: It's the only feature 100% of users touch and the first chance to deliver on your brand promise.
Favor internal hires for growth roles: They already have customer knowledge, faster time to results, and you know what you're getting.
Use proxy metrics to measure onboarding impact: Don't wait 90 days for retention data - find early signals that predict long-term success.
Treat job decisions as time investments: Apply the same rigor to evaluating companies as investors do - people, mission, and financials.

contrarian_candidates.why: Argues that good onboarding should sometimes decrease conversion - counterintuitive when most teams optimize for maximum throughput
Strongly recommends internal hires over external experienced hires - contradicts typical 'hire experts' advice for specialized growth roles
Challenges the unicorn hiring mentality - argues perfect candidates don't exist and teams should hire for balance instead

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: The exploring emerging channels framework has three core ingredients. The first is understanding if there is an overlap between what the customers need is, what your company's goals are, and what the channel actually does really well.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: I was pretty amazed how many more people were trying to crack Clubhouse than TikTok. TikTok is very clearly not going away anytime soon, where Clubhouse hopefully won't but was clearly very early. Part of this reason is to accept the risks of going into that channel.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: I like to spend a lot of time thinking about how they monetize. If you, as a business, can match or support their monetization strategy, it gives you a really interesting leg up. The likelihood of you being able to call them up and do custom stuff with them, or partner with them, goes up pretty drastically.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Do you actually have comfort in being a true first mover? Nobody knows anything, tracking's not going to work, it's not going to be programmatic. You're probably going to show up on content that's offensive. It's going to be really painful to be a true first mover. Do you have that appetite?

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Generally I wouldn't let anything bleed past a quarter. You can probably get some good signal in a month or less, what I would call fishing - putting bait in the water to figure out where the fish are, not necessarily getting statistically significant repeatable solutions.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Start by assuming you no longer have product market fit, because you had product market fit in a different market. It's a different market now, so you have to start over. If you just assume you need to launch a new channel to fix this problem, you're going to be wrong, because your entire customer base changed.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Data driven generally - performance is a very loaded word because people think it means not brand. But you absolutely can measure retention, brand, and the consideration funnel. Making data part of the DNA of everything that's happening is pretty quintessential of being a growth driven CMO.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: The iteration process is not thinking about things as 'We need to plan for the next 24 months.' Having a more agile type approach to everything - the storytelling your salespeople are doing, landing pages, logo design, brand itself. Being more open to everything being possibly iterated on using data to validate.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Learn product development. Go learn agile product development. Any great marketing CMO should be able to consume how to do product development, how to run sprints. And their mind will be like, 'Oh my gosh, I could do this with this big event. I could do this with everything.' There's nothing off the table.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: The one that I see the most is adaptability goes down really fast. Your openness to change in the business, or trying new things, has shifted from 'Here are the flags but let's give it a shot' to 'Why are we wasting our time?' That's a pretty good signal they may be more burnt out than just exhaustion.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: I can pretty cleanly tell the difference between exhaustion and depression. It tends to tie to my broader motivations, not just my motivation to work. When I'm exhausted, I'll still show up to improv class and enjoy it. If I'm depressed, I won't go. I'll just cancel it.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Now I have five or six different friends that we're massively transparent with about this stuff. The second I shared any of this with them, they shared it with me. And now we've become safe places to have those conversations where I can figure out which thing is causing this energy right now.

takeaways: Evaluate emerging channels with three ingredients: overlap between customer needs, company goals, and channel strengths - if they don't align, it's not worth your time.
Understand a channel's monetization strategy before investing heavily - if your goals align with theirs, you get access and partnership opportunities others don't.
Don't let channel experiments bleed past a quarter - you can get good signal in a month through 'fishing' before committing to statistically significant tests.
Growth CMOs must learn agile product development - applying sprint methodology to brand, events, and storytelling opens possibilities traditional marketers never see.
Burnout's clearest signal is declining adaptability - when 'let's try it' becomes 'why bother,' it's not exhaustion but something deeper needing attention.

contrarian_candidates.why: Assume you no longer have product-market fit when markets change - challenges the assumption that PMF is durable
Adaptability declining is the clearest burnout signal - not tiredness, but resistance to change reveals deeper issues

episodes.episode_title: Why most AI products fail: Lessons from 50+ AI deployments at OpenAI, Google & Amazon

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: When you start small, it forces you to think about what is the problem that I'm going to solve. In all this advancements of the AI, one easy, slippery slope is to keep thinking about complexities of the solution and forget the problem that you're trying to solve.
quotes.context: Explaining why starting with minimal AI autonomy helps teams focus on the actual problem rather than getting lost in technical complexity

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: 74% or 75% of the enterprises that they had spoken to, their biggest problem was reliability. That's also why they weren't comfortable deploying products to their end users or building customer facing products because they just weren't sure or they just weren't comfortable doing that and exposing their users to a bunch of these risks.
quotes.context: Citing UC Berkeley/Databricks research on why enterprises struggle to deploy AI products

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: I used to work with the CEO of now Rackspace. He would have this block every day in the morning, which would say catching up with AI 4:00 to 6:00 AM. Leaders have to get back to being hands-on. You must be comfortable with the fact that your intuitions might not be right. And you probably are the dumbest person in the room and you want to learn from everyone.
quotes.context: Describing how successful AI transformation requires leaders to rebuild intuitions and be vulnerable about learning

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: If someone comes up to me and says, 'We have this one click agent, it's going to be deployed in your system and in two or three days, it'll start showing you significant gains,' I would almost be skeptical because it's just not possible. I probably will go as far to say that if someone's selling you one click-agents, it's pure marketing. To replace any critical workflow or to build something that can give you significant ROI, it easily takes four to six months of work, even if you have the best data layer and infrastructure layer.
quotes.context: Warning about unrealistic AI agent marketing and setting realistic expectations for enterprise AI deployment timelines

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: There's this false dichotomy of this either evals is going to solve everything or online monitoring or production monitoring is going to solve everything. I find no reason to trust one of the extremes. Evals are basically your trusted product thinking that is going into this set of data sets. Production monitoring is you're deploying your application and then you're having some sort of key metrics that actually communicate back to you on how customers are using your product.
quotes.context: Addressing the evals vs production monitoring debate by explaining they serve complementary purposes

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: Martin Fowler at some point had this term called semantic diffusion back in the 2000s, which kind of means that someone comes up with a term, everybody starts butchering it with their own definitions and then you kind of lose the actual definition of it. That is what is happening to evals or agents or any word in AI as of today, everybody kind of sees a different side to it.
quotes.context: Explaining why AI terminology like 'evals' and 'agents' has become confusing as different groups use the same terms for different concepts

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: Codex, we have this balanced approach of you need to have evals and you need to definitely listen to your customers. It's extremely hard to build an evaluation dataset for all kinds of interactions that your customers are going to use your product for. With that said, you also need to understand that if I'm going to make a change, it's at least not going to damage something that is really core to the product.
quotes.context: Explaining OpenAI Codex team's pragmatic approach combining evals for core functionality with heavy customer feedback monitoring

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: We built these end-to-end agents and we had to shut down the product because we were doing so many hot fixes and there was no way we could count all the emerging problems that were coming up. Recently, I think Air Canada had this thing where one of their agents predicted or hallucinated a policy for a refund, which was not part of their original playbook, and they had to go by it because legal stuff.
quotes.context: Sharing the origin story of the CCCD framework - real failures that led to developing the continuous calibration approach

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: Misunderstood is the concept of multi-agents. People have this notion of, 'I have this incredibly complex problem. Now I'm going to break it down into, hey, you are this agent. Take care of this. You're this agent. Take care of this.' It's never the case that there are incredibly successful multi-agent systems that are built. Letting the agents communicate in terms of peer-to-peer kind of protocol is incredibly hard to control.
quotes.context: Explaining why multi-agent systems where agents communicate peer-to-peer are misunderstood and harder than hierarchical supervisor patterns

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: Building is really cheap today. Design is more expensive, really thinking about your product, what you're going to build. Is it going to really solve a pain point? That is way more valuable today. And it will only become more true in the near future. So really obsessing about your problem and design is underrated and just rote building is overrated.
quotes.context: Arguing that in the AI era, implementation is becoming commoditized while thoughtful product design and problem definition are increasingly valuable

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: Implementation is going to be ridiculously cheap in the next few years. So really nail down your design, your judgment, your taste. And now we have AI that could help you ramp pretty quickly. After a few years, I think everybody's job becomes about your taste, your judgment and kind of what is uniquely you.
quotes.context: Discussing how AI shifts career value from execution mechanics to taste, judgment, and unique human perspective

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: Persistence is extremely valuable. Successful companies right now building in any new area, they are going through the pain of learning this, implementing this and understanding what works and what doesn't work. Pain is the new moat. That kind of knowledge that you built across the organization or across your own lived experiences, I feel that pain is what translates into the moat of the company.
quotes.context: Introducing the concept that going through the painful learning process of building AI products creates competitive advantage

takeaways: AI products are fundamentally different from traditional software due to non-determinism (unpredictable inputs and outputs) and the agency-control trade-off - every increase in AI autonomy requires earned trust through calibration

Start with high human control and low AI agency, then gradually increase autonomy as you build confidence - jumping straight to fully autonomous agents leads to unmanageable complexity and hot-fix hell

The continuous calibration, continuous development (CCCD) framework helps teams iterate safely: scope capabilities with curated data, deploy with evaluation metrics, then analyze emerging patterns and recalibrate behavior without eroding user trust

Leaders must rebuild their intuitions in the AI era by being hands-on (like Rackspace's CEO doing daily 4-6am AI catchups) and comfortable being 'the dumbest person in the room' - top-down buy-in is critical for successful AI transformation

Implementation is becoming commoditized - taste, judgment, and obsessive problem understanding are the new differentiators. 'Pain is the new moat': companies that persist through the messy learning process of calibrating AI products build competitive advantage

contrarian_candidates.why: Direct attack on 'one-click agent' marketing hype - claims it's pure marketing and real AI products take 4-6 months minimum
Challenges multi-agent hype by calling peer-to-peer agent communication 'misunderstood' and incredibly hard to control
Contrarian stance that building is overrated and design is underrated in AI era - opposite of 'ship fast' mentality

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: Deep thinking takes time and space, and you got to create that space. The mundane, pointless bullshit will take every square inch you give it. So you got to make that space to sit back and reflect and luxuriate in these ideas.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: To me, LLMs are magical duct tape. They're formed principally by the distilled intuition of all of society into a thing that operates between, a cost structure between human and plain old computing. So much of how the industry is built presupposes the idea that software is expensive to write and cheap to run, and LLMs undermine both of these.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: I think in this early stage, we're in the community gardening phase, not the factory farming phase of this technology. And so I think what people need most is curiosity and play. You should be playing with these things and trying out different things and seeing what weird things are possible now.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: We've seen a vast reduction in the cost of distribution of information, and now we're seeing a reduction in the cost of information production. And most of it is slop. And so in this cacophony, how do you stand out? You stand out by having good taste.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: Taste, one way of looking at this is differentiate from what the LLM would've written if given the same prompt. How different, how distinctive is what you have to say.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: Think of it as having an extremely well-read but slightly naive friend who will never make you feel dumb and is willing to engage you in any particular topic you want to go down. So I use LLMs to help me. It's like getting an electric bike for idea spaces. You can just cover so much more ground so much more quickly in them.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: Kayfabe is a word that comes from professional wrestling and it means a thing that everybody knows is fake and yet everybody acts like is real. And I think it's one of the defining forces within an organization, any organization. So kayfabe in the small is optimism, enthusiasm. The problem that you get is as organizations get larger, this compounds. So then your layer above you does the same, and levels up you can be many orders of magnitude off of the ground truth.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: So much of the way that we tackle problems and build products is this builder mindset. It's like I have a plan, I then manipulate things to match my plan and make it happen. Part of the problem though is it can't possibly create more value than the effort that you put into it. What I look for instead are things that can be gardened, things that can grow on their own and that you can direct or maybe give a little bit of extra energy to.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: I think emergence is one of the most powerful forces if you know how to marshal it and you know how to work with it. And the only thing that's hard about it in my opinion is you're going to look like you aren't very serious. You're going to look like a weirdo. You're going to look like a kook.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: If you want to get your team to do good work, there's a million different paths to do that. If you want to get your team to do great work, there's no shortcut other than to have an extremely high-trust environment where people lean into their superpowers in a way that adds up to something greater than sum of its parts.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: The adjacent possible is a set of actions that you can do. They are right in front of you that if you do them, they would almost certainly work. And in the tech industry in particular, we default assume that the adjacent possible is like this and then flying leap to something. And in reality, the adjacent possible is quite small. It's within arm's reach.

takeaways: LLMs are 'magical duct tape' - they're powerful but squishy, enabling cheap prototyping but requiring product designs that gracefully handle occasional failures rather than expecting perfect accuracy
Stand out in the AI age by developing distinctive taste - your value is how different your perspective is from what an LLM would produce given the same prompt
Think like a gardener, not a builder - plant cheap seeds with compounding potential, nurture what grows naturally, and let emergence create value beyond your direct effort
Create 'strategy salons' or 'nerd clubs' - small groups of intrinsically motivated people who 'yes, and' each other's ideas in low-stakes environments to generate breakthrough insights
Navigate organizations by understanding kayfabe - the shared fictions everyone acts like are real compound up the chain, so seek disconfirming evidence before problems become critical

contrarian_candidates.why: Contrarian against the 'scale AI adoption now' narrative - argues we're still in early exploration phase requiring play and curiosity, not factory farming optimization
Openly acknowledges that emergence-oriented work makes you look like 'a weirdo' and 'a kook' - challenges the legitimacy theater of traditional strategy work
Directly contradicts the 'think big, moonshot' advice dominant in tech - argues the adjacent possible is actually quite small and incremental steps beat flying leaps

episodes.episode_title: Why humans are AI's biggest bottleneck (and what's coming in 2026) | Alexander Embiricos (OpenAI Codex Product Lead)

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: By far, I would say the speed and ambition of working at OpenAI are just dramatically more than what I can imagine. And I guess it's kind of an embarrassing thing to say because everyone who's a startup founder thinks like, 'Oh yeah, my startup moves super fast and the talent bar is super high and we're super ambitious.' But I have to say, working in OpenAI just made me reimagine what that even means.
quotes.context: Alexander describes his initial shock at OpenAI's pace after running his own startup for 5 years

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: If I think of what I was doing in my startup, it moved way slower and there's always this balance with startups of how much do you commit to an idea that you have versus find out that it's not working and then pivot. But I think one thing I've realized at OpenAI is the amount of impact that we can have and, in fact, need to have to do a good job is so high that I have to be way more ruthless with how I spend my time now.
quotes.context: On the ruthless time management required when the stakes and potential impact are extremely high

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: Because we don't exactly know what capabilities will even come up soon and we don't know what's going to work technically, and then we also don't know what's going to land even if it works technically, it's much more important for us to be very humble and learn a lot more empirically and just try things quickly. And the org is set up in that way to be incredibly bottoms up.
quotes.context: Why OpenAI operates with radical bottoms-up decision making due to inherent uncertainty in AI development

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I was just, again, surprised or even shocked when I arrived at the level of individual drive and autonomy that everyone here has. So I think the way that OpenAI runs, you can't read this or listen to a podcast and be like, 'I'm just going to deploy this to my company.' Maybe this is a harsh thing to say, but I think very few companies have the talent caliber to be able to do that.
quotes.context: A candid admission that OpenAI's bottoms-up approach only works with exceptional talent density

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I like to joke today that AI products, and it's a half joke, they're actually really hard to use because you have to be very thoughtful about when it could help you. And if you're not prompting a model to help you, it's probably not helping you at that time. And if you think of how many times the average user is prompting AI today, it's probably tens of times. But if you think of how many times people could actually get benefit from a really intelligent entity, it's thousands of times per day.
quotes.context: The gap between current AI usage (tens of prompts) and potential value (thousands of daily assists) drives Codex's proactivity focus

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: My analogy for this is, going back to this teammate analogy, it's like if you hired a teammate, but you're never allowed to get on a call with them and you can only go back and forth asynchronously over time. That works for some teammates and eventually that's actually how you want to spend most of your time. So that's still the future, but it's hard to initially adopt. But the key unlock is actually first you need to land with users in a way that's much more intuitive and trivial to get value from.
quotes.context: Why Codex pivoted from cloud-first to IDE-integrated - you need synchronous rapport before async delegation

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: If we're going to build a super assistant, it has to be able to do things. And one of the learnings I think we've seen over the past year or so is that for models to do stuff, they're much more effective when they can use a computer. It turns out the best way for models to use computers is simply to write code. So we're kind of getting to this idea where, well, if you want to build any agent, maybe you should be building a coding agent.
quotes.context: The counterintuitive insight that every AI agent should fundamentally be a coding agent

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: As we make code even more ubiquitous, it's actually just going to be used for many more purposes. And so there's just going to be a ton more need for humans with this competency. I think what we can do basically as a product team building in the space is just try to always think about how are we building a tool so that it feels like we're maximally accelerating people rather than building a tool that makes it more unclear what you should do as the human.
quotes.context: The product philosophy of maximally accelerating humans rather than replacing or confusing them

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I have this sort of hypothetical future that I like to share sometimes with people as a provocation, which is in a world where we have truly amazing agents, what does it look like to be a solopreneur? And one terrible idea for how it could look is that actually there's a mobile app and every idea that the agent has to do is just vertical video on your phone and then you can swipe left if you think it's a bad idea and you can swipe right if it's a good idea.
quotes.context: A provocative thought experiment: Tinder-style swiping as the ultimate human-agent interface

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: We recently shipped the Sora Android app, and that was one of the most mind-blowing examples of acceleration, actually. The Sora Android app, a fully new app, we built it in 18 days. It went from zero to launch to employees, and then 10 days later, so 28 days total, we went to just GA, to the public, and that was done just with the help of Codex.
quotes.context: Concrete example of Codex impact: Sora Android app (became #1 in app store) built in 28 days with handful of engineers

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I think we might've been in this weird temporary phase where, for a while, it was so hard to build product that you mostly just had to be really good at building product and it maybe didn't matter if you had an intimate understanding of a specific customer. But now I think we're getting to this point where actually if I could only choose one thing to understand, it would be really meaningful understanding of the problems that a certain customer has.
quotes.context: As building becomes easier, deep customer understanding becomes the most valuable competitive advantage

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I think a current underappreciated limiting factor is literally human typing speed or human multitasking speed on writing prompts. My view is that we need to unblock those productivity loops from humans having to prompt and humans having to manually validate all the work. So if we can rebuild systems to let the agent be default useful, we'll start unlocking hockey sticks.
quotes.context: The surprising AGI timeline insight: human input/validation speed is now the limiting factor, not model capability

takeaways: OpenAI's extreme velocity comes from combining top talent density with radical bottoms-up autonomy - most companies cannot simply copy this model
The gap between AI's current usage (tens of prompts/day) vs potential value (thousands of assists) reveals the massive opportunity in proactive, contextual AI
Every agent should fundamentally be a coding agent - code is the most effective way for AI to interact with computers and compose capabilities
Human typing speed and code review bandwidth are now the underappreciated bottlenecks to AGI productivity gains, not model intelligence
As building becomes commoditized, deep customer understanding becomes the most valuable competitive advantage - distribution and customer intimacy win

contrarian_candidates.why: Bluntly states that most companies lack the talent to operate like OpenAI - challenges the common 'just copy successful companies' advice
Proposes a 'Tinder for business decisions' future where humans just swipe on agent proposals - provocatively minimal human involvement
Claims human typing/review speed is the AGI bottleneck, not model capability - inverts the common narrative about AI limitations

episodes.episode_title: Scripts for navigating difficult conversations | Alisa Cohn (executive coach)

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: No one wants to make anybody upset, but through that upset on the other side of that, can often be a whole new possibility and a whole new revelation, and actually a lot of joy and freedom. I think that we forget about all the other possibilities that come out of difficult conversations and we just land on these really uncomfortable parts.
quotes.context: Alisa reframes difficult conversations as opportunities for breakthrough rather than just discomfort

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: She cried. Of course she did. She cried. That's what he knew she was going to do. And so she was upset and she went home early and the whole thing. The next day she came in and she said, 'Thank you so much for telling me that. I wish someone had told me that 15 years ago. I think I could have had a different career.'
quotes.context: Alisa shares a story about a manager who finally gave difficult feedback despite knowing the employee would cry

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: What I'm trying to convey in my tone is also, 'You know what? It's Tuesday. We got to have this conversation. I'm sure it's going to end well. I'm not mad.' The more even keeled and even matter of fact you can be about something that's kind of just run-of-the-mill feedback, the better.
quotes.context: Alisa emphasizes the importance of neutral, matter-of-fact tone in delivering performance feedback

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: Observable facts. The idea that this is not a judgment. This is not... Sort of as less judgy as possible is also very helpful. It makes it neutral. It's observable facts and it's also sort of based on expectations, right? So the writing is, we expect it to be at a certain level and it's not that way.
quotes.context: Alisa explains how grounding feedback in observable facts rather than judgments makes it easier to deliver and receive

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: Hope for the future is so important and I think sometimes we're such in a rush to kind of deliver the bad news that we forget there's a human being over there who needs hope for the future. And hopefully. If they're a good employee, hopefully they have hope for the future.
quotes.context: Alisa emphasizes the importance of providing hope when delivering difficult news about promotions

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: When you, as a leader signal a lot, I care about you, I care about your feelings, I care that you're disappointed, I care about your career, you are always going to be able to help people stay resilient in the face of setbacks and ultimately, do extra work, do the right work for you and be engaged in your company because you've spent the time and energy making sure they know that even when things are not going their way, they have an ally in you.
quotes.context: Alisa explains how signaling care builds resilience and engagement even during difficult conversations

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: Before you fire someone, I think it's helpful to have the conversation before the firing conversation. Regularly with my clients, I'll say, 'Okay, have you been crystal clear about what you need from this person?' And what they always do is the hand motion like well, sort of, but well, maybe. Which means no, which means no. You've not been crystal clear.
quotes.context: Alisa explains the importance of crystal clear expectations before considering termination

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: The positive feedback should have the same standard, which is, 'I saw the way you ran that launch, it was fantastic. All these different benefits came from it. You're so organized, keep doing that.' If you do that often enough, you become in the habit of getting better at positive feedback, which is extremely motivating to people at work.
quotes.context: Alisa argues that positive feedback needs to be as specific and thoughtful as constructive feedback

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: I think it's very misguided for leaders to have this notion that their most important role is to keep people happy, is to create this high engagement workforce. What that comes from is winning culture, which means we're set up for success. We've got the structure for success, we have the culture for success, everyone understands their role, they know the impact of their role.
quotes.context: Alisa challenges the common belief that leaders should focus on making employees happy versus driving results

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: My three questions to end the meeting are, what did we decide here? Who needs to do what by when? And who else needs to know? And if you can capture those, articulate those as deliverables, I promise you, you're going to have better meetings.
quotes.context: Alisa shares her framework for ending meetings with clear decisions and accountability

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: According to Noam Wasserstein, 65% of startups fail because of conflict with founders or the founding team. So it's really essential to get this right, and I agree that people step into this relationship with a lot less care than they should. And bad things can happen because you haven't done the work of getting to know each other before you decide to co-found.
quotes.context: Alisa introduces the founder prenup concept by citing founder conflict as the leading cause of startup failure

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: If you can see your path all the way through to the end, you are following someone else's path. Your path only becomes clear moment by moment as each foot hits the ground.
quotes.context: Alisa shares a Joseph Campbell quote that animates her life philosophy on career paths

takeaways: Difficult conversations often lead to breakthrough results - through discomfort comes new possibilities, joy, and freedom, and withholding feedback robs people of opportunities to improve.
Ground feedback in observable facts, not judgments - describing specific behaviors and outcomes against clear expectations makes feedback neutral, easier to deliver, and easier to receive.
Your job as a leader is not to make employees happy, but to create a winning culture - happiness comes from clarity on roles, impact, structure for success, and celebrating wins together.
Always provide hope for the future when delivering difficult news - remember there's a human being who needs to know they have an ally in you even when things aren't going their way.
End every meeting with three questions: What did we decide? Who does what by when? Who else needs to know? - This simple ritual prevents re-deciding issues and ensures accountability.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the popular belief that leaders should prioritize employee happiness - argues that focusing on winning culture and results is more important than engagement scores
Embraces the discomfort of making someone cry during feedback - counterintuitive message that the tears are worth it when the person later thanks you
Rejects the need for a clear career plan - suggests uncertainty about your path is actually a sign you're on YOUR path, not someone else's template

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: I really enjoy being right and then it turns out in the working world, that did not serve me so great. I think the hard part is sublimating your ego a little bit and saying it's more important to get to the outcome than to be right.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: Assume that executives have a little tiny dinosaur brain. We can really only hold three facts at the same time. We will never be able to go deep in the way that you are able to do on everything that crosses our desk. The best service you can do is actually do the work of making a recommendation.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: You don't want to come to a product review for every single decision. Instead, what you want is to come to a product review with one decision, but the goal of that decision is to walk out with principles about how to make these decisions in the future so that you don't have to come to product review.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: For me, the hill climb is all about the difference between a local optimum and a global optimum. You're standing on top of the hill, but way off in the distance you can see a mountain. You have to decide, are you going to take the risk of climbing down your hill, crossing an unknown chasm, just to get to the same level with more climbing to do?

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: Narrative can carry so much weight where otherwise you can either tell everybody exactly what to do at every point or you can create a story that we all agree on. If we all agree that the feeling of something should be sitting in Dolores Park with friends on a sunny Saturday, people will just naturally build something that feels more consistent.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: Strategy is super fun but customers don't care. Customers don't care about your fancy strategies and your five-year plan. They care about the product that's in their hands. Anything that distracts you from thinking about the product in your hands is a distraction.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: When you have great strategy but poor execution, you don't win because your strategy never makes it to the market. And what's even worse is that you have learned nothing. You don't know whether it was your strategy that was wrong or whether it was your execution that was wrong.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: The biggest thing that held me back from talking about strategy was I didn't feel confident that I knew enough to declare a strategy. It was actually almost like a self-confidence, imposter syndrome thing. I was always like, how could anything could happen? Who would I be to say I know how the world's going to develop?

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: Don't dampen who you are and your strengths, just continue expanding. Whenever you run into a problem, just add more to the things that you can do, the tools that you have, the ways you can express yourself. Just keep on adding and growing and don't shrink yourself, ever.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: If you give everyone the same goal like 'go get GMV', it leads to what I call toddler soccer, where everybody just runs to the same surface or the same customer set. Everyone's tripping on each other, nobody really gets contact on the ball, there's no coordination.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: As you get senior, the only problems you'll see are ones that are fundamentally unsolvable because otherwise, someone would've solved it before they got to you. All you're doing is choosing which branch of suboptimal you're going to put your name on and describing the principles you're using.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: The thing that has led me to the places where I do my best work is a feeling of being at home, which is all about trust. Can I walk through and feel like these people are going to have my back, they're going to let me take risks, I'm going to enjoy spending time with them?

takeaways: Execution beats strategy every time - customers don't care about your five-year plan, they care about the product in their hands. Perfect strategy with poor execution means you win nothing and learn nothing.
Use product reviews to establish principles, not just get decisions - the goal is to walk out calibrated so you don't need to come back for every choice.
The 'dinosaur brain' rule: executives can only hold three facts at once, so come with a clear recommendation rather than drowning them in information.
Don't shrink yourself to fit in - expand your toolkit instead. Add new skills and ways of expressing yourself rather than dampening your strengths.
Avoid 'toddler soccer' by giving teams different goals that ladder up to the company outcome - otherwise everyone runs to the same measurable surface and trips over each other.

contrarian_candidates.why: Provocatively dismisses strategy as something 'customers don't care about' - challenges the worship of strategic planning
Dark take on senior leadership - all decisions are suboptimal and you're just choosing which bad outcome to put your name on

episodes.episode_title: Behind the product: Replit | Amjad Masad (co-founder and CEO)

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: Typically, you're bottlenecked where your ideas are not fitting in because they need to be made and they need to be made quickly. Now, you open up that bottleneck. So now actually making things is a lot easier. Actually, you become limited by how fast you can generate ideas.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: I could imagine whatever five years from now, someone running a billion-dollar company with zero employees where it's like the support is handled by AI, the development is handled by AI, and you're just building and creating this thing.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: The vision for Replit has always been is like, okay, making software is fun, is great, more people should do it, but so for more people to do it, it needs to be easier to do, it needs to be in one place, and it needs to be learnable.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: I often go with minimalist prompts. That's also how I code as well. I have a vague idea for what I want to build and iterate from there. Other people, product managers like to write PRDs and more descriptive things, and you can do either of those things.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: If you think about it's like we're building as you were building, so we're building out the agent so that it can continue getting better as our users are also building their applications.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: When the cost of things go down, the total consumption of it goes up. And so I think that's going to be the case of software. As the costs go down, people will just make a lot more software to improve their lives and to improve their work and start more startups and all of that.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: These silos between designers, product managers, and engineers. Everyone feels that pain of, we have low bandwidth communication, which is language and then text on Slack and Zoom calls. The common language that everyone shares is code. What if the language becomes actually working prototypes and working applications?

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: Being generative, being able to generate new ideas quickly, because you can think about it as a factory line. Typically you're bottlenecked by the middle part where your ideas are kind of like they're a lot of them and they're not fitting in, because they need to be made and they need to be made quickly. Now you open up that bottleneck. Actually, you become limited by how fast you can generate ideas.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: The return on investment for learn to code is doubling every six months. Every six months, that's netting you more and more power because you're going to be able to create a lot more. It's going to be easier to create. You're going to be able to create a lot more complete things.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: The way we work is going to change rapidly, and it's important to be resilient to that change. You want to be able to react to it really quickly. When the Anthropic drop the computer use set of capability, we slaughtered our roadmap. We immediately jumped on it and started building things. Being agile, not being stuck with roadmaps, being able to just say, oh, we're just going to switch priorities right away, is going to be super important.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: You got to be fluid because when designers can code and engineers can design, it really becomes, you can't have a lot of structure around that. So you want to build a culture and you want to build an environment or milieu that is really, really flexible, which is uncomfortable for a lot of people.

takeaways: The bottleneck is shifting from execution to idea generation - when tools make building easy, creativity becomes the constraint
Amjad's Law: The ROI on learning to code doubles every 6 months as AI tools improve exponentially
Working prototypes become the common language that breaks down silos between designers, PMs, and engineers
Resilience > roadmaps - be ready to 'slaughter your roadmap' when new capabilities drop that change everything
Build flexible, fluid cultures where people can work across traditional role boundaries without rigid structure

contrarian_candidates.why: Predicts billion-dollar companies with zero employees - provocative vision that challenges traditional company structures
Advocates 'slaughtering your roadmap' when new capabilities drop - anti-planning, embracing radical adaptability
Says structured organizations are incompatible with fluid cross-functional work - 'uncomfortable for a lot of people'

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: Charlie Munger says, 'Fish where the fish are.' If you see a large pond with a whole bunch of fishermen elbowing each other out of the way, you actually want to walk off into the forest and find a small fishing hole with lots of fish and very little competition. Competition equals lower margin.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: You don't want to walk into the gym on day one and try to deadlift 300 pounds. When someone comes to me as a first time entrepreneur and they say, 'I'm going to make the next great AI company,' I think that is the equivalent. You want to take the baby weights and start slowly building your muscle.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: There's a big difference between a business and a job. If the business can get big enough where you can have employees, you can just focus on sales or digital marketing or whatever aspect of the business you love. Lean into what I call lazy leadership - how do I get away from things I hate as quickly as possible?

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: I started Flow, basically Asana before Asana. I made the mistake so many entrepreneurs make - going after an industry everybody goes after. I ended up losing $10 million trying to compete with venture-backed businesses while bootstrapping. It was like Fiji deciding to invade the United States.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: It's just not true that a bootstrap business can't get huge. We bootstrapped the entire business and now across all our companies we do almost $300 million in revenue. The only difference between what we do and what a VC does is the level of tolerance for burning money on fire.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: When I'm buying a business, I'm looking for something I can't mess up. Warren Buffett would call it a moat - a brand like Coca-Cola that gives you pricing power, or network effects where a community has gotten so big that people don't want to go elsewhere. If someone else wants to compete with Letterboxd, why would someone go when all their friends are already there?

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: My business partner says, 'There are no problems. There is only people problems.' As long as I'm surrounded by great smart people, I feel fine. But when we have a bad actor, a psycho or narcissist, all bets are off. I spend 20% of my time just filtering people carefully and ensuring we work with people we enjoy.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: With Lindy, I've automated my email. The AI decides if I even need to see it, labels things time-sensitive, and for simple decisions like 'Want to get lunch?' it emails me privately with multiple choice options. I just say 'four' and it'll email you as me. It's replaced my full-time assistant working on email.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: We are in the Palm Treo phase of AI. If it was accessible to everybody where you could just open ChatGPT and say 'I run a business, can you help me?' and it starts asking questions and becomes a digital employee - that's the iPhone moment we're going to have in the next five years.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: I met this guy worth $5 billion, and he goes, 'Jeff Bezos is just so fucking rich.' I asked what Bezos can do that he can't. He said, 'He can buy a super yacht.' We're all just comparing ourselves to our peers. Whatever our peers have that we don't, we feel hard done by. That's the scary reality.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: I reframed money so that 90% goes into my philanthropic foundation and gets given away. So when I think about working hard or an investment going well, the win isn't for me. The win is about doing something good. I also stopped spending as much - the more stuff I had, the less happy. I was owned by my stuff.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: I started taking an SSRI and within three or four days, it was like someone had turned down the volume on the nasty voice inside of me. For the first time in my life I felt relief. No amount of money or success or attention had done what this little tiny yellow pill could do for my mental state.

takeaways: Fish where the fish are - find the small fishing hole with lots of fish and little competition rather than fighting with everyone else in the obvious pond.
First-time entrepreneurs should start with baby weights - don't try to build the next great AI company on day one when you've never had a business win.
Bootstrap businesses can get massive ($300M revenue) - the only real difference with VC is tolerance for burning money, not potential scale.
AI automation has already replaced a full-time assistant for email - the 'iPhone moment' for AI agents where everyone can use them is coming within five years.
No amount of money fixes anxiety - billionaires still compare themselves to their peers, but medication (SSRIs) can turn down the volume on the nasty voice in ways wealth never could.

contrarian_candidates.why: Bootstrapping against VC-backed competitors is like Fiji invading the United States - know when you're outgunned
Money can't fix anxiety but a little yellow pill can - challenges the narrative that entrepreneurs should just grind through mental health issues

episodes.episode_title: When enough is enough | Andy Johns (ex-FB, Twitter, Quora)

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: I was so focused on my work that I had slowly become the frog that was boiling in the pot, the typical analogy of you don't realize how bad things are getting because it's happening to you slowly until it happens quickly.
quotes.context: Andy describes how burnout crept up on him gradually during his tech career, using the classic frog in boiling water metaphor to explain why high achievers often don't notice deteriorating mental health.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: I learned very early on that if I wanted to feel good, I needed to achieve, and that if I wanted to love myself and be considered lovable by others, I needed to achieve.
quotes.context: Andy traces his drive for achievement back to losing his mother at age 10, explaining how achievement became his coping mechanism and source of self-worth.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: I'd say that it's a fair estimate to say that at least 50% to 60% of tech employees who have been in the saddle, so to speak, for a minimum of five to seven years, they're experiencing some form of psychological and emotional distress.
quotes.context: Based on surveys and research, Andy shares the prevalence of psychological distress among tech workers, noting it may be more significant than people realize.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: These adaptations, if you're unaware of them and if you're unaware of the subconscious drivers that are responsible for them, they run the risk that they go too far, and that these adaptations, which were initially beneficial to you and to your life, they reverse course in a sense, and they become detrimental to your present state and your future development.
quotes.context: Andy explains how survival mechanisms that served us well earlier in life can become harmful if we remain unaware of their subconscious influence.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: These large transitions in life rarely take place in the absence of suffering. So step number one is suffer. Usually, the deeper somebody suffers, the more significant the transition that may follow.
quotes.context: Andy outlines his four-step framework for deep personal transformation, beginning with the necessary role of suffering in catalyzing meaningful change.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: I now understand what some philosophers described as death before dying. In this process of change that I've been going through, it's been the death of the old me, the death of Andy whose identity was entirely attached to succeeding, and that old Andy doesn't want to let go.
quotes.context: Andy describes the psychological experience of letting go of a decades-old identity built around achievement and success.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: There is necessary suffering in life or the mandatory suffering, and then there's the unnecessary suffering, which is the suffering that is almost entirely, and I think the argument could be made that it's entirely made up in our minds.
quotes.context: Drawing from Eastern philosophy, Andy distinguishes between unavoidable life hardships and the self-created suffering that comes from our mental interpretations.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: Once that dog can make it into the arms of an owner that it feels safe with and loved by, that's when you see the dog transform and change, and that's when you can teach it a lot because it's open and receptive to it.
quotes.context: Using the analogy of adopting a traumatized dog from a shelter, Andy explains why feeling safe is the prerequisite for genuine healing and transformation.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: If your sleep always sucks, if your relationships are constantly strained or frequently strained, if your physical health is failing, there's so many ways that that can be measured so there's really no excuse for that to say, 'Oh, I just didn't know.'
quotes.context: Andy identifies the physical and relational warning signs that indicate deeper psychological distress, emphasizing that the body keeps score of our mental health.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: So we lose who we were before the world told us who to be. It's actually a Carl Jung quote, 'The world will ask you who you are, and if you don't know, it'll tell you.'
quotes.context: Andy explores how social conditioning causes people to lose touch with their authentic selves, citing Carl Jung on the tension between individuality and conformity.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: The vast majority of people who die on Mount Everest actually die on the way down, not on the way up. You don't save anything for the return home, I think is the point.
quotes.context: Andy uses the Everest metaphor to challenge the relentless pursuit of career peaks, suggesting that treating life as a mountain to climb leaves nothing for the descent.

takeaways: Burnout often creeps up gradually like a frog in boiling water - by the time you notice the severity, significant damage may already be done to your mental and physical health.
Achievement addiction commonly stems from early life experiences where accomplishment became tied to self-worth and feeling loved, creating unsustainable patterns that eventually break down.

Deep personal transformation follows four steps: suffering, seeking truth about why you suffer, developing self-compassion when you realize it's not your fault, and extending that compassion to others.

The body keeps score of psychological distress through disrupted sleep, strained relationships, and physical health problems - these are warning signs demanding attention, not inconveniences to push through.

Rather than climbing mountains seeking fulfillment at the peak, consider floating downstream - surrendering control and letting life's current guide you may lead to unexpected places you were meant for.

contrarian_candidates.why: Argues suffering is the necessary first step for transformation - challenges self-help narratives of optimization without pain
Challenges the mountain-climbing metaphor for life and career success - most climbers die on descent, suggesting peak-chasing leaves nothing for what follows
Exposes achievement as an addiction formed in childhood rather than a healthy drive - challenges the glorification of high performance culture

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: The way I learned how to pitch in business school, and I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor. So you have a problem, a pain, I have a solution, a treatment, and I'm going to tell you why it's better than all the other treatments. And the structure that I read about in these movies was different. Every movie starts with some kind of shift in the world.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: This structure really is about defining a movement and that's very different from, 'Hey, I'm going to solve your problem.' So Benioff comes in and he says, 'Hey, software is over and there's this new world called the cloud, a new game, new rules. That's the new way to win.'

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: What I think is really interesting is this story has a certain structure. I call this shift the shift from the old game to the new game. The archetypal example in the business world is what Benioff did with Salesforce. Instead of just saying we're better than Siebel, they said all those others are part of that old game.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: What I call naming the stakes. Zuora is saying, 'Hey, look at all the new winners, Airbnb, Box, they're already doing this subscription thing.' They show this scary stat about the longevity of Fortune 500 companies getting smaller. Basically they make this case that companies are dying, the ones that are winning are doing this.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: How does George Lucas change Luke's mind? He basically kills the aunt and uncle. Now it's pretty clear they're coming for Luke. Now the stakes are life and death. The prospect doesn't see the future as sort of okay. They see it as split between a very negative outcome and a potentially very positive outcome.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Airbnb for a while had this one, live anywhere. If you think about it, this buyer mission statement, this rallying cry, I think of it really as the mission of the company. What is the mission of Airbnb other than to help people live there if they're going to be customer focused?

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: I think about obstacles because they sound like problems. This is what people would normally say, 'Oh, these are the problems we solve.' But by setting up this story thing first we've repackaged them as obstacles to a new goal state that we've already positioned as life and death. So they take on this much more emotional meaning.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Amit Bendov told me, 'Yeah, you know what? In hindsight we probably could have called it strawberry intelligence. It didn't matter. It was really the story that sort of mattered.' I guess I feel like by calling it category and category name, we're just focusing on those three words so much when really we should focus on the story.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Once we have this story then everything in marketing can be all about this story. With Zuora, maybe 80% of the content is not 'Hey, let me tell you about how Zuora is so great.' It's 'Here's how music companies are embracing subscriptions. Here's how luxury goods companies are embracing subscriptions.' It's less salesy.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Another thing I always hear is it becomes the strategic north star for the product. One CEO said, 'We are constantly getting feature requests through sales, through customer success. And we had no way to decide what we take on, what don't we take on. This has clearly become our bar.'

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: I am so against templates. Every team I work with, it's different. It's not the same number of slides. Sometimes we can lay out this shift in one slide, sometimes it just feels better if it's a few. Sometimes there's no slides. These are principles for building it, not any prescribed formula.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Make the title the takeaway of the slide so that the person looking at it has to do zero work to take away. Replace 'The team' with 'Our team is veterans of whatever industry.' Every single slide it's a takeaway, not a label. It'll make everything flow a lot better.

takeaways: Stop pitching like an 'arrogant doctor' (problem-solution-why-we're-better) - instead define a movement from old game to new game that makes your solution inevitable.
Name the stakes by showing winners already playing the new game - this creates life-or-death urgency that transforms reluctant buyers into committed believers.
Your strategic narrative becomes a north star for product decisions - when feature requests come in, you can evaluate whether they help achieve the new game's objective.
Category names matter less than the story - Gong's CEO said they could have called it 'strawberry intelligence' and it would have worked because the narrative was strong.
Turn problems into obstacles by framing them within your movement story - this repackages features as heroic tools rather than boring solutions.

contrarian_candidates.why: The 'arrogant doctor' pitch (problem-solution) that everyone teaches is fundamentally wrong - movements beat features
Category names are overrated - you could call it 'strawberry intelligence' and it wouldn't matter if the story is right

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: When people say 'I want someone that's strategic,' they're really saying 'I want someone that can articulate a compelling and simple why behind decisions.' The second piece is 'I want someone who will champion and be a change agent for things that are hard but best for long-term interests.' If you have one without the other, people won't see you as strategic.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Summarization, even though I may not be adding a new idea, people actually view that as strategy. They view effective summarization as strategy. Taking ideas and making them slightly better, slightly better - when you think from an outside-in perspective of customer problems, you start to get to big ideas that can really be change agent ideas.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Having a founder that can effectively operate in founder mode means I can go have a conversation with the CEO and say 'We have this huge opportunity and these things aren't working.' Activating that founder to push the initiative that I think is best by making them an ally.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Understanding the details of the business, asking questions about what's working, what's not, financial goals, how decisions are made - getting into that level of depth is super important. Then you can decide as a leader what you want to do with that information. A lot of information I collect, I don't do anything with at a point in time.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Be a historian. When I joined Rubrik, I tried to understand what happened in the past. What products weren't successful? Why? What was the perception of different people? I constructed this past knowledge so I could better understand how to make decisions going forward and learn from mistakes I didn't personally live through.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: It's not about making the right decision, it's about making the decision. Once you commit to a decision, you learn more post committing than in hypothetical analysis. As long as your decision is 70% right, you can iterate on that 20-30%. If you don't commit, you don't get any new high fidelity information.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: I reward the learning versus the outcome. If we're constantly learning, it's okay if we make bad decisions as long as we learn from them. Even in making a bad decision, we learned something about our customers or business that we can use in another context.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: When I hit a difficult personality, I try to understand what drives that person. What do they really care about? If I need something from them, what can I do to motivate them to find what I need important? Like building a product - they have this desire, how do I get them to care about what I want to achieve?

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Instead of feeling anger or frustration, I ask myself what can I learn from this person? Everyone has something they can teach you - their communication style, how they marshal people together, their visionary ideas. Studying that person and being curious, then genuinely feeling gratitude for what I got from the situation.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: I care so much about you and I'm giving you this feedback because I want you to be successful. You do all of that setup explicitly - you actually say that and show it in your body language. That makes the other person much more receptive to hearing whatever you have to say.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: I frame things as 'this is how you're being perceived' rather than 'you are doing X.' You're giving them the benefit of the doubt that how they're trying to show up is different than how people perceive them. Then you can have a conversation about what they can do to change that perception.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Journaling is very powerful. When I have a lot of thoughts going through my head, especially negative thoughts, putting them on paper helps me break down what's abstract. I realize 'this is something I feel but the why behind it is irrational, let me let this go.' It's like doing cognitive behavioral therapy on yourself.

takeaways: Being strategic means two things: articulating a compelling why behind decisions, AND championing hard changes that are best for the long term - having one without the other doesn't count.
Summarization is strategy - pausing to synthesize what's been said helps people feel heard, moves conversations forward, and makes you look strategic even without new ideas.
It's not about making the right decision, it's about making the decision - you learn more after committing than in hypothetical analysis, and 70% right is enough to iterate from.
When giving hard feedback, explicitly say 'I care about you and want you to succeed' - don't assume they know it; frame issues as perceptions to give benefit of the doubt.
With difficult personalities, ask what you can learn from them - studying their strengths and feeling genuine gratitude shifts frustration into an abundant mindset.

contrarian_candidates.why: Making the decision matters more than making the right decision - commit at 70% confidence because you learn more after committing
Feel gratitude for difficult people - instead of frustration, study what you can learn from them and be genuinely thankful

episodes.episode_title: This will make you a better decision maker | Annie Duke (Thinking In Bets, former pro poker player)

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
