quotes.text: We're all adults and as adults, we don't ever get all we want and we have to learn how to make trade-offs. And what I've learned is that I turned 60 this year, and the more I actually get comfortable with making trade-offs, the fact is the more satisfied I become. And so part of this is that when you think you're supposed to get it all, the fact is the less satisfied you are.

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: When you're in a startup, it changes who you are. And the moment that you get out of that environment, you need to take the time to reset your mind and your body back to who you really are. Because at some point it's not you. It's the combination of the context you're in. The moment you are comfortable doing nothing, you know who you are again, and you can actually figure this out.

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: It's answering two what I call easy questions but very hard answers. Who are you and who are you not? And then ultimately, what do you want? And most people just don't think about that. They're like, how do I get the next job? And so this is why I feel like everybody, the transactional level of resumes and job descriptions and interviews, they've automated the insanity as opposed to trying to make the process better.

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: I believe that innovation or product is a conflict sport. It's where you have to have arguments in order to be better. And every time you have an argument it gets better. And the moment that they try to make me better at harmony, the reality is you actually strip away my superpower of actually being able to innovate.

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: Most people suck at talking about themselves. They don't really know how to talk about what they do and what they're good at. And StrengthsFinders gives you the language to talk about it, but the bottom five are the things you really need to focus on because that's where the energy drains come from. That's the cheat sheet to get to energy drivers and drains.

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: That disability created super ability in me, which is questions. I know how to ask so many questions because that's the way I learn. My disability has caused me to have super abilities. That's why I think your weaknesses actually create your super abilities and knowing what they are is so important.

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: Self-awareness is one of the biggest assets you're going to have. And to know what you're good at, to know what you suck at, it's also going to tell you about the team you need to build around you. You confuse activity with productivity and you end up doing a lot of work that just doesn't matter and you're stressing yourself out for all the wrong reasons.

takeaways: Employees hire companies more than companies hire employees - the moment you stop making progress in your career is the moment you start looking for another job, so take responsibility for your own career trajectory.
Focus on energy drivers and drains rather than job features - if you can shift from 95% energy-draining work to 50-50, you won't even feel like you're working anymore.
Job descriptions are made up - negotiate for more of what energizes you and less of what drains you, because companies often reshape roles for the right candidate.
Treat yourself like a product and prototype different career paths through informational interviews before committing to a direction.
Your weaknesses create your superpowers - understand both your bottom five strengths and top five to find roles where you can truly thrive.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the reverence for job descriptions - they're made up and negotiable, not sacred requirements
Argues innovation requires conflict, not harmony - trying to improve your weaknesses can destroy your superpowers
Suggests startups fundamentally change who you are and advocates for deliberate recovery time - counter to hustle culture

episodes.episode_title: The ultimate guide to JTBD | Bob Moesta (co-creator of the framework)

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: Jobs helps you see the true competitive set from what we call the demand side of the world as opposed to the competitive set from the supply side of the world, which is the technology or the underlying business model by how which we're making it. And so it allows you to actually see what customers really want as opposed to trying to figure out, how do we sell things to people?
quotes.context: Explaining how JTBD reveals Snickers competes with protein shakes and coffee, not just other candy bars

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: And so all of this starts with a struggling moment, not with a product. And so that's what we mean when we're customer-centric is that we're studying the struggling moments they have and people like Intercom and Basecamp, they look at struggling moments and that becomes their roadmap.
quotes.context: Describing how SNHU grew to 200,000+ students by focusing on struggling moments rather than building features

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: Most people think they create a product and that creates demand. But the real thing that if you start to study causality is that a struggling moment causes demand.
quotes.context: Challenging the 'build it and they will come' myth with the insight that demand precedes products

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: It's not just the pain. See, what we're taught in business school was pain and gain, but the reality is it's the context. It's the fact that I didn't eat lunch before, the fact that I still have a lot of work to do. It's not that I'm in pain, but it's the context that makes me value this in the moment that much more than something else.
quotes.context: Distinguishing JTBD from traditional pain/gain frameworks taught in business schools

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: Every time I show somebody something new, it actually creates anxiety. More features create actually anxiety, can it do all those things? And what you start to realize is if I reduce friction, I actually don't have to do anything with a product, I just have to make it easier.
quotes.context: Explaining the forces of progress model where reducing friction can be more effective than adding features

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: So what this is it's really about focusing on the customer. It's about understanding the causation behind it and then using design thinking to actually start to realize, how do we actually enable people to make progress? We don't need to sell them, we need to enable them to buy.
quotes.context: The core philosophy shift from selling to enabling customers to make progress

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: Although for example, everybody I would survey before buying a house, I had 93% say they wanted an Energy Star compliant house. It cost 30 grand to make an Energy Star compliant at the time. And the reality is nobody bought it, they all bought the finished basement. And so there's the difference between what they say they want and what they want.
quotes.context: Illustrating why traditional surveys fail - people's stated preferences don't match actual buying behavior

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: The other tip I have is to not have a discussion guide. It drives people crazy because everybody wants to ask the same set of questions, but the problem happens is when you ask the same set of questions, you actually don't follow the ones that actually have the most meaningful information in it.
quotes.context: Unconventional advice against structured interview guides in favor of following meaningful threads

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: So the phrase I have 'Bitchin' ain't switchin'.' Just because people bitch about something doesn't mean they're going to do anything about it. This is where at Basecamp, we learned the fact that everybody said, 'Oh, if you had Gantt charts, I'm going to leave you if you don't put Gantt charts in,' and as much as they all say they want it, they're not leaving because of it.
quotes.context: Warning against building features based on complaints alone - action matters more than words

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: Most A students don't start until they know the answer, most D students start because they don't know the answer. And so you start to realize we're wired very differently to do that. And so I always say that the A students have a disadvantage against the D students in entrepreneurship because we just go start and we learn.
quotes.context: Bob sharing how his dyslexia became a gift - acting without perfect knowledge is an entrepreneurial advantage

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: Most people are studying the momentum of where people are and what's the momentum of their direction, but the reality is what we're trying to do is study what causes people to change their direction. And that's where innovation happens. Innovation happens when people change.
quotes.context: The fundamental insight that innovation comes from studying behavioral change, not status quo momentum

quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.text: And so it turns out that the dining table was the emotional bank account for their entire life. And so if you weren't going to take it or your sister wasn't going to take it, the reality is they weren't going to give it to Goodwill. People would literally stay where they are until they knew where the dining table's going to go.
quotes.context: The famous dining table story showing how irrational emotional factors block purchase decisions

takeaways: Struggling moments cause demand, not products - study the context that makes people ready to change, not just pain points or features.
Jobs to Be Done reveals true competition from the demand side - Snickers competes with protein shakes and coffee, not Milky Way, because the job is 'meal replacement when hungry.'
Reduce friction instead of adding features - anxiety from new features and habit of the present are forces that prevent switching, often more powerful than your product's pull.
Don't trust what customers say they'll do, study what they actually did - 93% said they wanted Energy Star homes, but everyone bought the finished basement instead.
'Bitchin' ain't switchin'' - customer complaints and feature requests don't predict behavior; only interview people who have already made a change to understand causation.

contrarian_candidates.why: Advises against structured discussion guides for customer interviews - contradicts conventional UX research methodology
'Bitchin' ain't switchin'' challenges the customer-centric idea that you should build what customers ask for
A students have disadvantage vs D students in entrepreneurship - contrarian view on education and action

episodes.episode_title: Making Meta | Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth (CTO)

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: Communication is the job. If you want to have an impact on the world around you, it is exclusively done through the creation of artifacts or verbalizations that affect other humans. That is all there is. People always think, 'Oh, I had that idea.' It means nothing. It means absolutely nothing. Or 'Oh, I wrote this post.' Well, you didn't break through with it. That's on you.
quotes.context: Explaining his most famous principle that having ideas means nothing without effective communication

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: The advice I find I have to give more frequently than any other is for people to more directly leverage their leaders. We want to do it ourselves to prove we can. But your job is not to do it yourself. Your job is to get it done. The tools you need live with your manager, your partner, your mentor. Nobody wants you to succeed more than your manager does, because when you're amazing, their life gets easier.
quotes.context: Sharing his most frequently given career advice about asking managers for help

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: I don't want to take away from the romanticism of it. It's just that most often, we hear those romantic stories from the successes. It's a healthy thing for people to want to throw themselves into something and take that risk, but it is not glamorous at the time. I worked 120 hours per week, I didn't sleep for more than four hours at a time, I'd wake up every four hours and check if anyone was attacking the site.
quotes.context: Describing the unglamorous reality of early Facebook days as the 10th engineer

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: We joke inside of Meta, to this day, we call it the eye of Sauron. When Mark has determined that the thing you're working on is the most important thing, there is no detail too small for him to notice. He will be in a review and say, 'Strategically, I think we're off course. And also, this one pixel is definitely wrong. You have to fix that.' That's a big range.
quotes.context: Explaining the legendary 'eye of Sauron' metaphor for founder attention to detail

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: Multimodality. Repetition never spoiled the prayer. I will give an all-hands and then write a post with the content of the all-hands, because different people are going to respond differently to these modalities. Making sure that you address people's fears and concerns right up top. People will not listen to you if they think you don't know what's going on.
quotes.context: Sharing practical techniques for effective communication at scale

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: Identity threat is just the biggest threat. Your worst behavior is always going to come out when you think you're under identity threat. When you feel like some core part of how you see yourself is in question, you will react with every ounce of your fiber to defend that conception of yourself because it's so expensive to reconceptualize who you are.
quotes.context: Explaining why he got into an embarrassing technical argument with his best friend Dave Federman

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: Ami Vora could have the most profound disagreement with somebody and they would say the thing she thought was not just wrong, but crazy wrong. She would respond, 'Fascinating. You have to tell me more about why you think that.' She meant it from the core of her being. She saw this schism between her and that person and reacted with the most genuine and profound curiosity.
quotes.context: Describing the transformative leadership lesson he learned from watching Ami Vora handle disagreement

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: News Feed was an easier case than people suspect. Everyone was outraged at the same time as they immediately doubled their usage of the product. We had cognitive dissonance between stated preferences and revealed preferences in the economic sense. So we were like, Okay, there's something real here.
quotes.context: Explaining how they had conviction to stick with News Feed despite user backlash by watching actual behavior

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: Mark is somebody who is maybe the strongest willpower of a person I've ever met. You'll give him feedback, he'll listen. He'll most often tell you that you're wrong, why you're wrong. What will happen is over the course of the next week or two, you'll just see shifts. The information gets to him, and at night he re-compiles the whole world with all that information and comes back.
quotes.context: Describing Mark Zuckerberg's unique way of processing feedback and iterating on his mental model

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: Gell-Mann Amnesia: You'll read a newspaper article about a thing you're an expert in, and you'll be baffled because it's not just wrong, it's inverted causality. It's a 'wet sidewalks make rain' story. And then you turn the page and it's another article about a topic you know nothing about, and you'll read it as if it's gospel truth. You know more than the critics do.
quotes.context: Explaining why Meta's team needed to trust their own expertise during the stock downturn rather than external narratives

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: Extreme ownership: Whenever thing goes wrong, I ask myself, what could I have done differently in terms of how I communicated things for this to have gone better? I give somebody a piece of work and they come back six months later and they have done the wrong thing, I'll take the L. That's my responsibility. I did not communicate clearly what I wanted.
quotes.context: Explaining how he applies extreme ownership from US Marines/SEALs to all communication failures

quotes.speaker: Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth
quotes.text: The motto my family has is just trust yourself. I really think so much of the success I've had was just having faith that I was making good decisions. You have to believe you, your eyes, ears and intellect have combined to give you a point of view that has intrinsic value and deserves your respect. Trusting yourself also includes taking risks because you trust that you can deal with what happens when the risks don't pay out.
quotes.context: Sharing his family's life motto and how conviction in yourself enables both risk-taking and resilience

takeaways: Communication is the job - having ideas means nothing without creating artifacts or verbalizations that affect other humans; if you didn't break through, that's on you not the audience
Leverage your leaders more often - your job isn't to do it yourself, it's to get it done; nobody wants you to succeed more than your manager because when you're amazing, their life gets easier

Embrace curiosity over defensiveness when challenged - when someone disagrees profoundly, respond with 'Fascinating, tell me more' from genuine curiosity rather than identity threat (lesson from Ami Vora)

Identity threat triggers your worst behavior - when core parts of your self-concept feel questioned, you'll defend with every ounce because reconceptualizing who you are is expensive; recognize this pattern

Trust yourself to take conviction-driven risks - you have to believe your eyes, ears, and intellect give you a point of view with intrinsic value; trusting yourself includes knowing you can handle when risks don't pay out

contrarian_candidates.why: Brutally dismisses the 'I had that idea' excuse - argues having ideas means literally nothing without effective communication, which contradicts the innovation mythology that celebrates ideation
Deflates startup romanticism by exposing the unglamorous reality - 120 hour weeks, waking every 4 hours for 2 years, no social life, contradicting the 'fun startup journey' narrative
Challenges the authority of external critics and media - argues you know more than analysts/press/Twitter and should trust your own expertise despite public narratives

episodes.episode_title: Brandon Chu on building product at Shopify, how writing changed the trajectory of his career, the habits that make you a great PM, pros and cons of being a platform PM, how Shopify got through Covid

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: To have the highest trajectory and what certainly was a tailwind for my career was you guys have to lean into those founder skills. Things like being a great storyteller, how to get the most out of people around you, foster creative and motivated teams and know how to make really, really hard high conviction decisions that actually can't be solved.
quotes.context: Brandon explains what separates high-trajectory PMs from the rest - it's not hard skills but founder-like abilities

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: We don't actually put the product org on a pedestal as the only people that can have an opinion about the product or should be listened to when we think about what should be built. There's sort of an understanding at Shopify that everyone at the company from engineers to support, to sales, everyone's responsible for product thinking.
quotes.context: Describing Shopify's approach where product thinking is distributed across the entire company, not just PMs

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: Your job is to help teams ship the right thing at the right time in the right way. It really comes down to two main concepts. There's help teams. So it's like servant leadership. You're not necessarily the CEO of the product. You're not dictator. Everyone's responsible for product thinking and you're there to help the team get to ultimately the right thing.
quotes.context: Shopify's one-liner job description for PMs that emphasizes servant leadership over product dictatorship

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: It's important that we set broad direction, so everyone can put their energy towards the right place. But we also want a place where we're hiring smart people so that they can figure out what to do. And we also know that in software and in tech and in this world, things change so rapidly. So don't even kid yourself that we're going to plan out everything we're going to have to do for the next year.
quotes.context: Explaining Shopify's balance between setting direction and giving teams autonomy to figure things out

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: What's really amazing and also difficult about Shopify is we're pretty good at never falling into sunk-cost fallacy. We'll throw it all away anytime if the world changes. There are cases where you're building three, six months into something and it's just not important anymore or the world changed.
quotes.context: Shopify's willingness to abandon work when priorities change, avoiding sunk-cost fallacy

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: During COVID, this cultural resilience we had to change was so vital because all of a sudden, these grandiose ideas and visions we had for 2020 didn't matter and what mattered was like, 'Oh, shit. Retail businesses are going from a hundred percent to zero.' It's like 0% revenue overnight.
quotes.context: How Shopify's culture of adaptability prepared them to pivot rapidly during the COVID crisis

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: I figured out everything in those posts at the exact moment I wrote them. It was the writing process itself that actually allowed me to solidify those mental models and those frameworks in my mind. I wasn't ahead of the game in any way. I just really wanted to disambiguate the chaos in my mind about what my job was.
quotes.context: Revealing that his famous PM posts weren't written from expertise but were the process of figuring things out

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: When you write it down, you just kind of release it from your mind. It's not floating around there because I'm scared to lose it or something like that. And you kind of just now you cleared your mind and you can actually think. You build on top of that knowledge into something else.
quotes.context: Writing as a cognitive release mechanism that frees up mental space for new thinking

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: Even if it's not to be publicly shared, ultimately, especially in an increasingly digital world and increasingly remote world, you've got to be able to articulate yourself. You owe your team, your peers, your stakeholders that level of clarity. Even if you write it and throw away, you've created a clarity in your mind.
quotes.context: Making the case that every PM should write, even privately, to develop clarity of thought

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: Even if it never got picked up, the ROI is already huge because it just helps you refine how you talk about the work and the decisions. But that aside, writing accelerated my career probably a decade.
quotes.context: The massive career impact of his public writing, claiming it accelerated his trajectory by a decade

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: Given the fact that we only have limited time and that the most important decisions are so much more important than the other 98, 99 of them, you should spend all your time on those very few important decisions. For all other decisions, just go with whatever your gut is or delegate it because you're only human.
quotes.context: His famous decision-making framework: spend all time on critical decisions, use gut for everything else

quotes.speaker: Brandon Chu
quotes.text: Do a legitimate side hustle, found a company on the side and learn everything else. It humbles you a bit. It reminds you of how hard it is to build software and how many people it takes to do that well. And especially if you're not technical, really lean into it and build something simple for yourself, demystify the technology.
quotes.context: His number one advice for PMs leveling up: start a side project to understand the full picture

takeaways: Writing crystallizes your thinking - Brandon figured out his famous PM frameworks through the writing process itself, not before it
The most important PM skill is identifying which decisions matter - spend all your time on the critical few and use gut instinct for the rest
Servant leadership over product dictatorship - Shopify's PM philosophy is to help teams ship the right thing, not dictate what to build
Never fall into sunk-cost fallacy - be willing to throw away months of work if the world changes and it's no longer important
Start a side hustle to level up as a PM - founding something humbles you and teaches you how hard it is to build products end-to-end

contrarian_candidates.reason: Challenges the common belief that you should see projects through - argues for abandoning work when priorities shift
Counterintuitive advice to use gut instinct for 98% of decisions rather than analyzing everything thoroughly
Reveals that expertise often comes from the act of writing, not before it - contradicts the expert-then-teach model

guest_metadata.name: Brandon Chu
guest_metadata.title: VP of Product at Shopify
guest_metadata.known_for: The Black Box of Product Management blog series on Medium

episodes.episode_title: He saved OpenAI, invented the "Like" button, and built Google Maps: Bret Taylor (Sierra)

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: I probably would self-describe as an engineer, but more broadly I think of myself as a builder and I like to build products and I think companies are one of the most effective ways to build products.
quotes.context: Explaining his flexible view of identity and why he sees himself as a builder first, regardless of specific role

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: One of the dangers for founders and product managers, but I think particularly for founders is incorrect storytelling. People don't like my product because of X. And if you tell that to yourself and you tell it to your team, all of a sudden, it goes from being an intuition to being a fact.
quotes.context: Warning founders about the danger of false narratives that get mistaken for facts when repeated

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: I've observed with first time founders in particular is you're often a single issue voter based on your skillset. So if you're a great engineer, the answer to almost every problem in your business is engineering. If you're a product designer, the answer almost to the proverbial redesign.
quotes.context: Explaining how founders subconsciously default to solutions that match their existing strengths

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: If you think the thing that you've been doing your whole career is the way to fix your problem, it's at least 30% likely that you've chosen that because of comfort and familiarity not truth.
quotes.context: Quantifying the comfort bias that makes founders default to familiar solutions rather than correct ones

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: When you ask for advice, don't just ask what to do but why. Be an obnoxious two-year-old kid, why? Why? Why? Why? And really try to understand the framework that someone is using to give you advice.
quotes.context: Teaching how to extract maximum value from advisors by understanding the reasoning behind their recommendations

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: The interesting thing about advice is people are often extrapolating from relatively few experiences. So they will say, never do this or always do that. And it's because they had one experience where something backfired or something could have gone better if they had done it.
quotes.context: Explaining why advice should never be treated as a rule - it's usually based on limited anecdotal experience

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: Your job as the operator of that code-generating machine is to make a product or to solve a problem and you really need to have great systems thinking and you're going to be managing this machine that's doing a lot of the tedious work of making the button or connecting to the network.
quotes.context: Describing the future of software engineering as operating code-generating machines rather than typing code

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: I think that's where agents will go. I think it's going to be more about product than it is about technology over time. Just going back to my metaphor, in 1998 when Mark and Parker started Salesforce, just getting that database running in the cloud was like a technical achievement.
quotes.context: Predicting that AI agents will evolve like SaaS - from technical differentiation to product differentiation

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: I think agents will truly start to bend the curve again like we did in the very early days of computing because software is going from helping an individual be slightly more productive to actually accomplishing a job autonomously.
quotes.context: Explaining why AI agents represent a step-change in productivity - from assistance to autonomous job completion

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: The whole market is going to go towards agents. I think the whole market is going to go towards outcomes-based pricing, not because it's the only way, but the market is going to pull everyone there because it's just so obviously the correct way to build and sell software.
quotes.context: Predicting the inevitable shift toward agents and outcomes-based pricing as the new software paradigm

quotes.speaker: Bret Taylor
quotes.text: I think people who are trying to get productivity gains in departments like software engineering need to stop waiting for the models to magically work if they want to see the gains now. And you really have to create root cause analysis and systems to produce the right system so the models can do it today.
quotes.context: Advising that AI productivity requires active root cause analysis, not waiting for models to improve

takeaways: Have a flexible identity - think of yourself as a builder, not just an engineer or PM, and be willing to transform into what the company needs at each stage rather than conforming the job to what you like to do.
Beware incorrect storytelling - founders often create false narratives about why customers don't buy that become accepted as facts, when the real reason may require a much harder solution to fix.
Question your comfort bias - if your proposed solution happens to match your strongest skill, there's at least a 30% chance you've chosen it for comfort and familiarity rather than truth.

Extract frameworks from advice, not rules - advisors are usually extrapolating from limited experiences, so ask 'why' repeatedly to understand their framework and apply it with nuance to your situation.
Don't wait for AI models to magically work - if you want productivity gains now, create root cause analysis systems to identify what context the models need and build systems to provide it.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the assumption that experience-based intuition is reliable - argues 30% of familiar solutions are chosen for comfort, not correctness
Undermines the authority of advice from successful people - most advice is based on single anecdotes extrapolated into rules
Rejects the passive 'wait for better AI' approach - argues companies must actively build context engineering systems to get productivity gains now

episodes.episode_title: Why ChatGPT will be the next big growth channel (and how to capitalize on it)

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: Building a great product is one of those things that's necessary, but not sufficient, and actually the separation is between those that build really great distribution.
quotes.context: Brian explains that while building a great product is necessary, the real differentiator for startups is building great distribution.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: One of the major, major ways that we always see is that this can happen when new distribution platforms emerge, because when new distribution platforms emerge, startups are usually the fastest to take advantage of them. It's slower for the incumbents to move. It gives startups this opportunity essentially to play this game.
quotes.context: Brian describes how new distribution platforms create opportunities for startups to outpace incumbents who are slower to adapt.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: All of the conditions, all of the ingredients for a new distribution platform to emerge are essentially happening. So I think we're at an inflection point where we're going to see this emerge really fast.
quotes.context: Brian predicts an imminent new distribution platform emerging from AI, likely centered around ChatGPT.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: These players, somebody essentially identifies whatever the moat is, the thing that is going to help build them defensibility and help them hit escape velocity and become that monopoly or duopoly in that single category. Once they figure out what that moat is, then they need to press the advantage.
quotes.context: Brian explains the first step of the platform cycle: identifying and pressing the advantage on whatever creates defensibility.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: This cycle happens because of competitive and capitalistic dynamics and pressures. It's the same environment that enables creating amazing new companies here in the US. You go through this cycle because it's a competitive environment. You're trying to figure out how to beat competitors, and this is one of the strategies to beat competitors.
quotes.context: Brian explains that platform cycles aren't evil - they're natural outcomes of competitive dynamics that also enable innovation.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: The broad trend is that the cycles seem to be getting shorter and shorter and shorter and shorter, so you actually have a smaller amount of time to play the game.
quotes.context: Brian warns that distribution platform cycles are accelerating, giving companies less time to capitalize on new opportunities.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: What's going to happen is that if you don't do it, your competitors are going to certainly go to the new platform and your customer expectations change, and you have to rise to those customers' expectations. It ends up being a prisoner's dilemma, which is, there is no opting out of the game. You have to play the game.
quotes.context: Brian explains why companies can't opt out of platform shifts - competitors will take advantage and customer expectations will change.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: My hypothesis, and I think there's a lot more consensus around this now than there might've even been three months ago, is that the moat is about context and memory. These models by themselves, if you compare them side by side, they generate the same result, and so the actual difference-maker is which one has more of your context.
quotes.context: Brian explains his hypothesis that context and memory will be the key moat for AI platforms like ChatGPT.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: If you look at history once again, it was never the person who had the biggest distribution at the moment of time. It was the one that had the best retention and engagement. Google had the best retention and engagement over the others. Facebook was smaller, but had way better retention and engagement over the others.
quotes.context: Brian argues that retention and engagement, not raw user numbers, predict which platform will win in competitive markets.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: If you're a late-stage company, you can afford the luxury to place multiple bets and spread your chips. But for startups, it's a totally different ballgame. You don't have the luxury to spread your chips. You have to go all in. You have to choose one and go all in. You have scarce resources, scarce attention from the market.
quotes.context: Brian contrasts betting strategies for late-stage companies vs startups when new platforms emerge.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: Play the game. Don't opt out of the game. Don't trick yourself into thinking that you can't play the game. That's number one. Number two, no matter who you bet on, just make it a focused bet. Because if you look back, all the failures are the ones that tried to play multiple games at once with scarce resources.
quotes.context: Brian's core advice for startups facing platform shifts: participate and make focused bets rather than spreading thin.

quotes.speaker: Brian Balfour
quotes.text: Look, your output is constrained by the slowest part of your system. If you think about AI adoption as a system, there's all parts of the system that could be slowing adoption. In a lot of these cases, it's things like IT, legal, procurement are the slowest part of the friction and are setting the pace of all of this output.
quotes.context: Brian explains why companies struggle with AI adoption - the slowest part of the system constrains overall output.

takeaways: Distribution beats product: Building a great product is necessary but not sufficient - the real separation happens through great distribution.
New platform cycles create startup opportunities: When new distribution platforms emerge, startups can outpace slower-moving incumbents.
There is no opting out: Platform shifts create prisoner's dilemmas where competitors will capitalize even if you don't, and customer expectations change.
Startups must make focused bets: Unlike late-stage companies that can spread chips, startups with scarce resources must go all-in on one platform.
AI adoption is constrained by the slowest system part: IT, legal, and procurement often become bottlenecks that set the pace for entire organizations.

contrarian_candidates.why: Argues there's no opting out of platform games - contradicts the common 'build your own platform' or 'avoid platform dependency' advice
Reframes platform 'lock-in' and 'closing' as natural competitive dynamics rather than corporate evil - challenges anti-platform sentiment
Argues retention and engagement beat raw distribution - counterintuitive when everyone chases user counts

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: Leaders are in the details. And there's this negative term called micromanagement. I think there's a difference between micromanagement, which is like telling people exactly what to do, and being in the details. Being in the details is what every responsible company's board does to the CEO. That doesn't mean the board is telling them what to do. But if you don't know the details, how do you know people are doing a good job?

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: You can't build a product unless you know how to talk about the product. You can't be an expert in making the product unless you're also an expert in the market of it. If you build a great product and no one knows about it, did you even build a product?

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: We wanted a company where a thousand people could work, but it'll look like 10 people did it.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: I think the CEO should be basically the chief product officer of a product or tech company. If the CEO is not the chief product officer then I don't know if they're a product or tech led company.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: The less involved I was in the project, the more spin there was, the less clear the goals, the less advocacy the team had, the less resources, the fewer resources they had. And then therefore the slower they moved. And the slower they moved, the more they assumed it was because I was too involved.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: There's a great saying that the best way to slow a project down is add more people to it. We have fewer than 7,000 employees today. As a relative comparison, I think Uber has 30,000. And it's not to say they're big, it's just say that's how small we are and we've really benefited from having not a lot of employees.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: A design leader's job should be managing the design first, the people second. That's what Jony did. I could never imagine Jony out at Apple just being a manager of people. He was looking and designing the work with the team. How do you manage the people without managing their work? How do you give them development if you're not in the details with them on the work?

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: Way too many founders apologize for how they want to run the company. They find some midpoint between how they want to run a company and how the people they lead want to run the company. That's a good way to make everyone miserable. Because what everyone really wants is clarity. And what everyone really wants is to be able to row in the same direction really quickly.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: Five teams should do one thing rather than one team do five things. People should work together. I think that people should consider doing launches. You can by the way, ship every hour of every day, but then package it and tell a story if you want hold the product back.

quotes.speaker: Brian Chesky
quotes.text: Everyone should row in the same direction. If there's only one thing I said in this interview today, actually I'm not sure what it would be, but I think a good candidate is try to get everyone to row together in the same direction. Otherwise, why the hell are you all in the same company?

takeaways: Leaders must be in the details without micromanaging - there's a critical difference between telling people what to do and understanding their work deeply enough to guide and develop them.
Product and marketing are inseparable - if you can't articulate the product, you haven't truly built it. Brian merged product management with product marketing at Airbnb.
Company clarity comes from focused direction - everyone rowing together in the same direction beats distributed empowerment that creates politics and bureaucracy.
Small, expert teams beat large generalist ones - Airbnb has 7,000 employees vs Uber's 30,000, and leaders must be domain experts who manage the work first, people second.
The CEO should be the chief product officer in product-led companies - delegating away your core strength as a founder creates the conditions for organizational decay.

contrarian_candidates.why: Leaders must be in the details, not delegate - attacks micromanagement criticism as excuse for ignorance
Founders apologize for how they run companies, seeking midpoint makes everyone miserable - anti-consensus

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: We've been profitable for seven years and one of the reasons is that we never want to be put in the situation where we have to go to someone for money to ensure the survival of the business. Being profitable means that we can always do it on our own terms and in our own time.

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: We've always been an incredibly product-led company. We always think first and foremost about the product. That was the whole genesis of Canva itself, having a product that we thought people would love to use and desperately needed to get out into the world.

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: You can bring in the world's best person at X, Y, and Z, but if they're not fitting into your team and understanding your culture and have the same passion and vision that you do, they're not going to succeed. Everyone at Canva mightn't be the number one person in the world, but they get more done because they've built that trust and safety.

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: One of those sections in the cultural onboarding is on giving away your Lego. You need to think about who you're going to bring in to help you. Finding joy in building a team, passing on your experience, helping other people do great writing or great product building or great engineering is what giving away your Lego is about.

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: We have a system we call coaching at Canva. We don't really have managers. Your coach is the person who thinks about you in a specialty sense. They know the skills that you have to use, the trajectory that you could possibly grow into, the structures around Canva that you could slot into when you want to go to the next level.

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: For us, product managers are really connectives. They connect the team, ideas, data, a whole bunch of different things. It's very messy. There's no exact recipe for how to do it, but connecting these disparate areas and moving the team and the technology and our customers to a new place, a new vision is essentially what product managers do.

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: The product is the experience and giving people a great experience is an intrinsic part of the product. People having a good experience of being enthusiastic about it has been how we've spread the word of Canva. Organic word-of-mouth growth was the biggest driver of Canva's growth for many years and probably still is.

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: Even today we build for ourselves. I think we're fortunate that we are our customer and that the problems we experience are the problems that hundreds of millions of people experience. That's one aspect of it and I think that is also about being passionate, entering an area that you are extremely passionate about.

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: There's a real fear of the blank page. We just got people to walk through, keeping their interest up, keeping the bar of effort quite low, but within three or four steps, they'd built up something that they'd never been able to do before. The words we literally got were, 'I didn't know I could be a designer.'

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: Andre thought through that whole end-to-end flow from first landing on Google and typing into the search box through to that magic moment where they're like, 'Canva just helped me do something amazing and I want to do it again.' You can't just SEO the hell out of something that is a terrible experience.

quotes.speaker: Cameron Adams
quotes.text: Freemium for us wasn't so much a growth strategy or a monetization strategy as much as it spoke to our core mission of empowering the world to design. We truly want to democratize design, which means we want to get design into the hands of as many people as we can.

takeaways: Profitability creates independence - being profitable for seven years means never being forced to take money on bad terms, allowing decisions on your own timeline.
Replace managers with coaches - Canva's coaching model focuses on skill development and career trajectory, with coaches in the same specialty helping people level up.
Giving away your Legos is essential for scaling - find joy in building teams and helping others grow rather than holding onto the work that gave you identity.
Product managers are connectives, not controllers - PMs connect teams, ideas, and data, constantly reorienting around constraints rather than following a recipe.
Freemium is mission alignment, not just growth strategy - when your mission is democratization, free access becomes philosophically essential, not just tactically smart.

contrarian_candidates.why: We don't really have managers - Canva replaced traditional management with a coaching model focused on specialty skill development
Build for yourself contradicts common advice - when you are your customer, your intuition becomes valid research

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: I'm going to find that in places where they are so quashed their creativity for the actual business or product that they're building and their voice in that is so ignored that they don't have any outlets in that space and so, they are going to use the space that they have an outlet in, the place where they have some control and that's usually the technology choices and the details there.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: I think the product managers that have done the best, they're not threatened by other people having ideas. They're not threatened by the engineering team being full of smart people because they realize that yeah, some of the engineers may have good ideas, but they still don't really know how to do the product job.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: You think, 'Oh, we kind of know what's going on, so it's not going to be that big a deal.' Engineers notoriously, notoriously, notoriously, massively underestimate the migration time for old system to new system and that causes a lot of problems. By the way, you still have to support the old system while you're working on the new system.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: A lot of times people really underestimate what the old system does and how well they know what the old system does. There's so much logic buried in legacy systems, it tends to be undocumented, it tends to be weird. You haven't thought through all the business rules, you haven't thought through the data formatting.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: One piece of advice I give everybody is don't stop being a hands-on technical until you feel like it's in your bones. You feel like you've got mastery that you could... if you know a second language fluently or if you played an instrument really, really seriously for a long time, you'll be familiar with theI haven't done that in a long time, but if I was to pick it up, it would be rusty, but I would get there pretty quickly.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: What people care about with technical leaders in my experience is they want people who actually seem like they sort of understand what you're doing and can ask good questions and help guide you to better decisions without actually being the one who's like, 'Oh no, you need to use this library instead of that library.'

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: If you happen to be a woman or otherwise underrepresented person in tech, people will tend to underestimate your technical abilities just unfortunately as a get-go. I also think it's particularly important to kind of develop that internal confidence in your abilities before you make this sort of scary leap.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: I think it's probably somewhere in the 10-year range of really having spent a lot of your time over those years writing code and really understanding how to be a technical expert.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: Management is much more... I'm not a huge fan of servant leadership exactly, but management really is a service job. You are serving the team, you are serving the company. Your job is to help make things better and that usually doesn't mean that you're making all the decisions.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: What I've seen and I've heard a lot of friends at many companies complain about is this idea that everybody is doing one-on-ones with everyone else. So the manager is doing one-on-ones with their team. They're also doing one-on-ones with all of their peers. They're doing one-on-ones with all of their stakeholders. It's just not a scalable approach.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: I think we all understand that if we could just figure out and focus on really the most important things, we would justeverything would be better. And it's hard to figure out what the most important things are, but overwork kind of lets you just sidestep doing the hard work of figuring out what's important in the first place.

quotes.speaker: Camille Fournier
quotes.text: I'm a very strong believer that platform engineering has to involve software engineering. If you don't have any software engineers on your platform team and you only have more operations systems engineers, DevOps, SRE... I think you're kind of missing the picture. Platform engineering is not just maintaining cloud infrastructure and doing small scripts or blueprints.

takeaways: Great product managers are not threatened by engineers having ideasthey embrace collaboration while recognizing each role's unique value, creating environments where engineers feel heard without over-engineering as their creative outlet.

System rewrites are often a trap because engineers massively underestimate migration time and the hidden logic buried in legacy systemsevolve systems incrementally rather than going away to build something new.

Don't stop being hands-on technical until mastery is 'in your bones'roughly a 10-year range of serious coding before transitioning to management, especially crucial for underrepresented people who face assumptions about technical ability.
Management is a service job, not a position of authorityyou don't own your time anymore, the company and team do, and your job is to serve and guide rather than make all the decisions.
Overwork lets you sidestep the hard work of figuring out what's importantchallenge yourself to focus, delegate, and regularly audit your time rather than filling hours with low-value activities.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges conventional management wisdom that more one-on-ones equals better relationshipsargues they don't scale and can waste everyone's time
Directly confronts hustle culture by arguing overwork is actually a way to avoid the harder problem of prioritization

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: Some of the most important aspects of getting to the executive suite are working harder, learning more, pushing yourself, taking on more responsibilities and opportunities, maybe even in the white space, that aren't your job or aren't in your regular time.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: There's no shortcuts. Tomasz Tunguz would wake up 5:00 or 6:00 AM every morning and write three to four blogs a week for 10 years. That is self-discipline and insight and drive. So yeah, no shortcuts.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: A guy at the Tesla factory said, 'After work every night, I'd go to each part of the plant and try to figure out what they were working on and what the challenges and opportunities were. That's how I moved up.' It's just understanding how the whole thing works together.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: Your career and your ability to transcend is fairly dependent on the momentum of your company. I was a leader at Oracle for five years, and my team grew from five to seven. I was a leader at Atlassian for four years, and my team grew from 15 to 100. If you pick the right company with the right momentum, you have a better chance.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: The best executives I know have had down periods in their careers, where they were out of work for a while, where they were fired by a CEO. And what they have in common is endurance. They're just back in the ring. It's also important not to settle on a crappy job or a crappy company.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: There's this book called The Millionaire Next Door, which talks about how the very best antique store makes one or 2% profit. And the very worst oil and gas company makes 35% profit. Some of the worst software companies make 65% profit. So picking your industry will propel your career.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: Your product has to really be fantastic. Oracle spent a ton of money, and people still didn't like us because they had poor experiences with the salespeople, or they didn't like Larry, or the product had kind of languished since it had been acquired. You really need to be thoughtful about spending consistently over a longer period of time.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: In order to get hypergrowth, you have to have organic, inbound, and viral word of mouth. You can't pay enough to grow at those rates and have a viable company. The biggest thing is an amazing product that people love to use. ChatGPT is the most hypergrowth product we've seen in history because people are so excited to use it.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: Hypergrowth companies go through the stages of growth that would take other companies five years or 10 years. They're going from 10 to 50, from 50 to 100, from 100 to 200. They're jumping. So they really need to keep hiring 2X and 3X leaders who have seen the next stage of growth, because it's going to be here before you know it.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: Getting to virality and getting the hypergrowth is not a magic bullet. It's consistency, customer obsession, incremental improvements across all parts of the business. Founders just need to double down on having a product that's differentiated and does something that their customers really love.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: The founders were going through this experiment that turned out to be really successful, where they took all the money they would've spent on a sales org and plowed it into engineering and product. We spend way less on sales and marketing and took all that money and put it into product to make a product that really sold itself.

quotes.speaker: Carilu Dietrich
quotes.text: For product led growth companies, bundling is not a great land strategy. At Atlassian, we experimented with different bundled lands and it really slowed down the product led growth motion. If you have to evaluate multiple products to purchase something, it's not a fast and easy online self-service buy.

takeaways: Hypergrowth requires organic word-of-mouth - you can't pay enough to grow at hypergrowth rates with a viable business; the product must be so good people naturally share it.
Your career growth depends on company momentum - at Oracle team grew from 5 to 7 in five years; at Atlassian it grew from 15 to 100 in four years. Pick the right rocket ship.
Hire 2X and 3X leaders ahead of need - hypergrowth companies compress years of growth into months, so you need people who've already seen what the next stage looks like.
Bundling kills product-led growth velocity - when users have to evaluate multiple products, the fast self-service motion breaks down. Land with a single product.
Endurance is the common trait of successful executives - the best leaders have had down periods and been fired; what distinguishes them is getting back in the ring.

contrarian_candidates.why: Take all sales/marketing money and plow it into product - Atlassian's radical bet that a great product can sell itself
Bundling kills PLG velocity - counterintuitive when bundling seems like it should increase value

episodes.episode_title: How to build deeper, more robust relationships | Carole Robin (Stanford professor, "Touchy Feely")

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: People do business with people not ideas, not products, not machines, not tactics, strategies, not even money, they do business with people. So you better get the people part right if you really want to succeed. And that interpersonal competence is a determinant of both personal and professional success.
quotes.context: Explaining why interpersonal dynamics is taught at Stanford Business School as part of the leadership curriculum

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: If you want to build a sustainable long-term legacy, then you probably want to think about showing up in a way that other people come to see you as a referent figure, somebody in their life that they say, 'When I grow up, I want to be more like that.' And that is a form of power.
quotes.context: Discussing referent power and why people should follow leaders

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: Step a little bit outside your comfort zone. If you step a little bit outside your comfort zone, you're very unlikely to freak yourself or the other person out. But you'll know, you'll feel it a little bit, you'll be like, okay, I feel just a little uncomfortable saying this, but I think I'm going to try.
quotes.context: Explaining the 15% rule for progressive disclosure and relationship building

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: I can get up and say, probably no secret to most of you, that's the third month in a row we've lost share. And man, I wish I could stand up here and tell you I know exactly what's happening and I know exactly what we should do about it, but I don't, and I have never needed you all more. Now, who would you rather follow?
quotes.context: Contrasting appropriate vulnerability with inappropriate oversharing in leadership communication

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: 'Are you human after all?' And then I burst out crying and I tore up our agenda and I said, 'You don't think I'm human?' We spent the next two days talking about who we were, why we were there, what we wanted, what was important to us, how we could help each other. To this day, I believe that was the day I became a leader.
quotes.context: Sharing a pivotal moment from her career when an employee's feedback transformed her leadership approach

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: Anger is often a secondary emotion and often under anger is either fear or hurt. Anger is a distancing emotion, whereas hurt, fear, sadness, loneliness, happiness, joy are all connecting emotions. So those are kinds of things people learn when they come through our programs.
quotes.context: Explaining why leaders who lead with anger push people away instead of connecting with them

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: We've all been socialized not to be vulnerable, especially in business and naming any of those other things makes us feel vulnerable. So somehow being angry doesn't make us feel vulnerable. That's the okay emotion, as long as you express it in an appropriate way, but it's a distancing emotion.
quotes.context: Explaining why professionals default to anger instead of more vulnerable but connecting emotions

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: In any exchange between two people, there are three realities. There is my intent, how I see the world, my background, my history. There is what I do or say or don't do, verbal or nonverbal. And whatever happens on your end is reality number three, the impact of what I've said or done, how you see things, your background.
quotes.context: Introducing the three realities framework as the foundation for giving effective feedback

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: The formula is when you do insert behavior, I feel - pull out the vocabulary of feelings - and I'm telling you this because, or I'm hoping the outcome of you knowing this is. And so then what happened is he said, 'Well, if you want my undivided attention, then you've got to give me some time to unwind when I get home.'
quotes.context: Demonstrating the feedback formula and how it leads to problem-solving conversations

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: You have to suspend judgment. You cannot be curious if you've already decided you know what's going on for someone else. You can always go back to being judgmental, but you got to suspend it long enough to see if there's something for you to learn.
quotes.context: Explaining the art of inquiry and why suspending judgment is essential for understanding others

quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.text: Advice creates even bigger power differentials between people. Often when we give advice, it's a good thing to stop yourself and ask yourself, 'Who am I doing this for? Am I doing this for me so that I can puff myself up with everything I know or am I doing it for you because this is really going to help you and make you better?'
quotes.context: Challenging the mental model that leaders should always have answers and give advice

takeaways: Vulnerability is a leadership strength, not a weakness - appropriately sharing uncertainty and asking for help builds trust and rallies teams more effectively than projecting false confidence.

Anger is a secondary emotion that creates distance - underneath anger is usually fear or hurt, and naming those connecting emotions leads to better outcomes in both professional and personal relationships.
The 15% rule enables growth without overwhelm - step slightly outside your comfort zone with disclosure and feedback, enough to feel it but not so much you trigger defensive reactions.
Stay on your side of the net when giving feedback - stick to observable behaviors and your own feelings rather than attributing motives or labeling the other person.
Giving advice often serves the advisor more than the recipient - asking questions and being a thought partner develops people better than providing quick answers.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the assumption that leaders must always project confidence - argues that admitting uncertainty and asking for help is actually stronger leadership
Provocatively suggests that giving advice often serves the ego of the advisor rather than helping the recipient - questions a fundamental leadership behavior
Counter-intuitive insight that anger is the socially acceptable emotion in business, but it's actually the least effective for building connection and influence

episodes.episode_title: Thinking beyond frameworks | Casey Winters (Pinterest, Eventbrite, Airbnb, Reddit)

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: When interest rates are zero, every startup operates like it's a public company with billions of dollars. Now that I'm interviewing PMs again, they all sort of look the same. They seem pretty ill-prepared for a real startup. You ask them to solve a problem and they'd say things like, 'I can't even begin to come up with solutions until I see all the data and talk to customers.' When's the last time you used your brain versus followed a process someone else designed?
quotes.context: Describing the 'zero interest rate phenomenon PM' - product managers who've only worked in high-resource environments and can't make decisions under uncertainty.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: It's certainly okay to learn a bunch of frameworks. There's a reason I've invested a ton of time in Reforge. But you have to understand that the job is not to follow the process. The job is not to learn every framework possible. The job is to figure out how to add value to customers that translates into value to the business. Just reorient your North Star.
quotes.context: On frameworks as tools in a toolkit versus a coloring book to stay inside the lines of, emphasizing independent thinking over process adherence.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: At Eventbrite there was this team that didn't ship anything in a quarter. I went to the designer and was like, 'Dude, you didn't ship anything. How could you have gone the entire quarter, not shipped any of your designs and felt that that was okay? There's just no way you can get better as a designer. There's no way you can have an impact on the company. There's no way you can have an impact on our users.'
quotes.context: On the importance of shipping to learn versus over-preparing, challenging a team that spent an entire quarter without releasing anything.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: User research is a scarce resource. We have to reserve it for the areas that have extreme uncertainty and high leverage for getting to certain. If you're redesigning the login page for Eventbrite, you don't need to use that resource to learn what to do. Just go see what FANG and the top unicorns did. They probably did a good job, and our customers use those products so they're going to be familiar with us copying any approach.
quotes.context: On when to use research versus when to just ship or copy proven patterns, pushing back on over-reliance on research for low-uncertainty problems.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: Interviewing is handing out Oscars based on who's prepared the best tell me about a time response, versus actually assessing who can do the job we're hiring for. Most PMs are better PM interviewers than PMs now. I'm a bit contrarian here. I don't ask about your work history. I don't care about your perfectly practiced answers. I'm going to give you real scenarios from the role. If you can't come up with a few reasonable ideas and test them quickly without analyst support or research, I'm just not interested.
quotes.context: On his contrarian interviewing approach that tests actual job skills rather than rehearsed behavioral answers.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: If you thought the PM job was just filling in the latest Reforge or Shreyas framework, and then getting that automatic FANG promotion every year and a half, then yeah, you're going to get replaced by AI. The real PM job is the least likely to get replaced over time because you need real subject matter expertise. You need to be trading off a lot of different types of things and making good decisions for the company and for your customers.
quotes.context: On AI's impact on product management, distinguishing framework-followers from true strategic thinkers who won't be replaced.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: AI is a tool that's trained on sounding smart rather than always necessarily being smart. Someone showed me Notion AI. It said I started my career at Google and worked on Google Trends. None of which happened. It was just complete nonsense. Half of it was completely made up. It sounded plausible, but it wasn't actually true. That would scare me as a PM.
quotes.context: Warning about AI hallucinations and the danger of tools that sound confident but provide incorrect information.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: If founders are lucky/good enough to find product-market fit, they've usually built up all this intuition that's really hard to explain and may even be subconscious. I've seen some founders be like, 'Cool. I need to let these experts own these areas and get out of their way.' That's actually the opposite of what you want. None of these people know the business as well as you. You actually need to direct them until they show you they've really got it and are making better decisions than you would.
quotes.context: On the founder intuition vs team expertise framework, arguing founders delegate too early before team members truly understand the business.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: When you start scaling the company, it's the first time that founders run into what got you here won't get you there. What got you to product-market fit was iterating on product and doing things that don't scale. Guess what? You found a product that works. Don't do that anymore. Make it scale. Don't come up with new products. You found the one that works.
quotes.context: On the critical mindset shift from finding PMF (iterate constantly) to scaling PMF (stop changing the core product, focus on distribution).

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: At the Grubhub competitor we acquired, they were largely in the same phase as us but still operated like they were founding the company. Everything was going through the founder. Intuitively, I was like, 'Oh, this is why we're acquiring you, and not the other way around.' Everything was not moving as quickly because everything had to go through the same person to get done. They just bottlenecked themselves.
quotes.context: On how founders who don't delegate at scale create bottlenecks that lead to being acquired rather than winning.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: It's their company. They can run it any way they want. If you state your point, you've built up the expertise, you're confident and you are refuted, you have to find ways to be contrarian and prove you're right. Different founders have different forms of feedback they listen to. You try to figure out what actually influences the CEO and build that case, whether it's through an experiment, the right customer intro, the right external advisor. If they rebuke that as well, then you got to disagree and commit, or find a new company to join.
quotes.context: On how to influence founders who won't listen to direct feedback, by understanding what forms of feedback they do respond to.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: During existential threats, it's like when Nassim Taleb says, 'The only rational reaction is overreaction.' Unless you have a real viable reason to assume otherwise, you got to assume the disruptor is right and base your strategy on them playing an optimal game. Whereas, I think Grubhub assumed the disruptor was wrong and that it would all play out eventually in their favor, and it clearly didn't.
quotes.context: On lessons from Grubhub vs DoorDash, arguing you must assume disruptors are right and overreact to existential threats rather than waiting to see if they fail.

takeaways: ZIRP phenomenon PMs are ill-prepared for resource-constrained environments - they've learned to follow frameworks and processes but can't use their brain to make decisions under uncertainty without data teams and research support.

Frameworks are tools in a toolkit, not coloring books to stay inside the lines of. The job is to add value to customers and the business, not to perfectly execute every framework you've learned at Reforge.

Reserve user research for extreme uncertainty + high leverage problems. For low-uncertainty work like redesigning a login page, just copy FANG or ship to learn. Shipping nothing for a quarter to do research is inexcusable.

Founders delegate too early after raising senior hires. You need to direct new leaders until they demonstrate they truly understand the business and are making better decisions than you would - not just assume experts 'got it.'

When facing existential threats from disruptors, the only rational reaction is overreaction. Assume they're right and base your strategy on them playing an optimal game, rather than hoping their model fails.

contrarian_candidates.why: Calls out an entire generation of PMs as unprepared - provocative critique of framework-driven product management
Rejects standard behavioral interviewing in favor of testing actual job skills - contrarian hiring approach
Argues founders delegate too early, opposite of common advice to 'hire experts and get out of their way'
Advocates overreaction to threats rather than measured response - citing Taleb's provocative maxim

episodes.episode_title: How to sell your ideas and rise within your company | Casey Winters, Eventbrite

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: I find that in general people just way under communicate upward inside of companies. And then they'll complain that executives are out of touch when they aren't telling executives what the executives need to know.
quotes.context: On the importance of proactive upward communication when facing challenges, rather than silently struggling and later blaming leadership for being disconnected.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: Many times when non-executives are presenting to execs, they'll start on like chapter six. Even if that part of the story is right, you haven't earned the right to tell that part of the story yet because you skipped the first five chapters.
quotes.context: On communicating effectively with executives by starting with company strategy and assumptions before diving into implementation details.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: You want to de-risk that meeting not make it a big success or fail moment. If there is a big presentation coming up, I try to run through it with the team, pretending to be the other members of the audience, so I'll say what the CFO's going to ask about here is X. You want to answer that question before it gets asked.
quotes.context: On preparing for important meetings by role-playing different executive perspectives and anticipating their questions.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: The point is not how much time you spend, it's how well do you really know the material, and how well do you really know what your audience is going to care about with that material. If you haven't thought through all the questions that might be asked from the document you're sharing, you're not prepared enough.
quotes.context: On the depth of preparation required for high-stakes meetings with executives, emphasizing knowing the material inside-out rather than memorizing a script.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: We strive for this concept of what we call perceived simplicity, which is there are advanced features in the product and they are easily discoverable when you look for them, but they're effectively hidden if you're not looking for them.
quotes.context: On solving the product complexity problem at Eventbrite by making advanced features discoverable but not intrusive, inspired by WhatsApp's approach.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: Some of the most impactful projects that product teams can work on at scale are the hardest to measure. And because of that, they just get chronically underfunded. You can't really do a lot of this work alone. If you're a PM, you want to be approaching this from a well, my engineering manager and my design leader also bought in that we need to work on performance.
quotes.context: On justifying non-sexy product improvements like stability and performance by first getting peer leaders aligned before approaching executives.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: When you're an early stage company, everything is trying to drive upside. But when you've actually built a real business, you can actually lose what you've built. Trying to help executives understand that this thing we've got could go away if we don't do these other things can be incredibly powerful.
quotes.context: On shifting mindset from pure growth to protecting existing gains once you've achieved scale.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: User expectations just continue to go up every day. The competitive landscape in the market continues to get better. If you're not continually pushing to make your product better, you might find yourself fall out of product market fit entirely. And that's a really dangerous place to be.
quotes.context: On product-market fit as a constantly moving target that requires continuous iteration to maintain, not a one-time achievement.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.text: Having marketing ops means you suck at marketing. It scares me when the first tactic people go to is to add people to help scale. When you say their job is to do this manual process long term, that's where I get super concerned because you're not rooting out efficiency in how you build your company.
quotes.context: On operations roles as a sign of inefficiency, arguing teams should invest in automation and process instead of scaling ops headcount.

quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
