Low momentum leads to more low momentum because there's this energy that kinda goes through companies where, when there is momentum, when people are shipping, when things are going well, other people feel that energy, and they wanna do the same.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: Consumer is you're always fighting for attention. You might be some consumer social company, but you're kind of like competing with Netflix too. Like people could be watching Netflix, or they could be using your product. So, now you're competing with so many different things. Many of those are incumbents where the consumer also has built-in habits, routines.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: I think it's really hard to build a consumer company without some sort of unique insight, maybe impossible. I used to write a problem journal. Just when things annoyed me or when things were less efficient, I would write it down as a note. And I didn't try to solve it. I didn't say, 'Oh, here's the solution.' I was just like, 'This is annoying.'

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: The more narrow you're generally, the easier it is to build a great solution for those people, because now you can actually hone in the product experience, the messaging, and everything to serve exactly those people. My bias is not to worry too much about if it's too small because what you probably find is, over time, opportunities to expand beyond that.

takeaways: Call it an experiment, not a startup - the framing of 'experiment' removes pressure around success and focuses on learning whether people want what you're building, making it easier to adapt and pivot.

Launches serve multiple purposes beyond customer acquisition - recruiting, fundraising, partnerships, feedback, SEO, and team morale are often more valuable reasons to launch than pure user acquisition.

Monetize sooner than you think necessary - even dedicating 10% of focus to revenue generation early can lead to cash flow break-even within a year, giving you flexibility and ownership of your destiny.

Momentum is reflexive and compounds in both directions - when people are shipping and things are going well, others feel that energy; the reverse is equally true, making momentum one of the most important things in early-stage startups.
Go narrow to go big - focusing on a specific niche makes it easier to build a great solution because you can hone the product and messaging; expansion opportunities will reveal themselves over time.

contrarian_candidates.why: Reframes side projects as 'experiments' where success isn't the goal - challenges the typical founder obsession with outcomes over learning
Challenges the assumption that launches are primarily for customer acquisition - argues other benefits like recruiting and morale often matter more
Openly admits founders must wear a mask and cannot be 100% transparent - contradicts the authenticity movement in startup culture

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: In the first 30 seconds of using a new product, you are lazy, vain, and selfish. You want to get it done super quickly. You want to look good to your colleagues or to your friends. You want to feel successful very quickly by engaging in this product. You don't want to have to watch a tour or read anything, really endure any learning curve whatsoever.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: It's fascinating to me that most teams spend the final mile of their time building the product, considering the first mile of the customer's experience using the product. If you can just get more customers through that top of funnel, you are a world-class product team.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: The most humbling moments for me as a product leader have always been shoulder to shoulder to customers. Watching them actually go about their day, not just use my product but go about their day because what you end up getting is context for a lot of data that you're missing.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: Product leaders expect people to talk about a product being great. And people don't talk about a product doing exactly what they expected it to do. They talk about a product doing what they didn't expect.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: Whenever I'm asked by teams, what features need to be part of their MVP, how do they decide which features they need to ship first, I always tell them to optimize for the problems they want to have. You want the problem of customers getting through your funnel, feeling successful, using your product and getting value.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: So actually if you make the whole product about one thing, everyone does that. That core crank operates at 10X the velocity and if that's the most important metric for the business, that's gold. And so, we basically went on a killing spree. And we just started killing things.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: Some of the best product leaders that I've worked with, I do feel like they have this great reductionist or minimalistic tendency by default. They anchor themselves on the one thing they want people to do and do well. And they just are pretty ruthless about everything else.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: I always like to use the analogy of we're driving our teams across country as product leaders with the windows blacked out in the backseat and everyone's sitting in the backseat. If they don't receive the narrative, they will go stir-crazy. As product leaders, we have to merchandise progress. We have to be the steward of this narrative.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: How much conviction do you have in the solution you're building? I know in the beginning before you knew all you know now, you had tons of conviction. That's what caused you to leave your job. Now, knowing all you know, do you have more or less conviction in the problem and the solution you're building?

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: I have an allergic reaction to founders that are real promoters who are constantly trying to sugarcoat the truth, who like to gloss over the hard parts. I've always admired leaders that are optimistic about the future but very pragmatic and somewhat pessimistic about the present.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: I've always found that resourcefulness brings you further than resources despite the fact that over the last seven to 10 years, we've basically thrown resources at every problem. If resources are carbs, resourcefulness is like muscle. It stays with you. It makes you stronger.

takeaways: Users are lazy, vain, and selfish in the first 30 seconds - design your onboarding to make them feel successful immediately without requiring any learning curve or tutorials.
Focus your product on one core thing and ruthlessly eliminate everything else - when Behance killed features like groups and the tip exchange, their core metric of project publishing increased 10X.
Build empathy by being shoulder to shoulder with customers in their full context, not just watching them use your product but understanding everything else competing for their attention.
The conviction test determines whether to quit: if knowing everything you now know gives you more conviction than when you started, stay the course. If less, it's time to pivot or move on.
Resourcefulness beats resources - constraints force creative problem-solving that builds lasting muscle, while throwing money at problems creates temporary solutions that don't strengthen your team.

contrarian_candidates.why: Calls users lazy, vain, and selfish - a brutally honest framing that challenges the typical user-centric language of treating users as thoughtful rational actors
Advocates going on a 'killing spree' to eliminate features - directly opposes the common instinct to add more features and please all users
Leaders should be pessimistic about the present while optimistic about the future - challenges the toxic positivity common in startup culture

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: The Black Loop is someone comes in, they make a doc, they share with a group of people, some subset of the people turn around and make another doc, and the process repeats itself over and over again. The blue loop is someone comes in, makes a doc, and instead of sharing it with a team or with the collaborators, they publish it to the world.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: Almost all products have some form of loop. That person turns around and maybe sharing is built right in your product or maybe it's not, or maybe there's a way that it happens through advocacy, but understanding that the way products actually grow and spread happen through some type of loop not funnel, is I think pretty fundamental.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: He said great companies have a very small list of golden rituals. And there are three rules of golden rituals. Number one, they're named. Number two, every employee knows them by their first Friday and, number three, they're templated.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: When we're building companies, we actually build two products. We build one for our customers and we build another one for our employees. That's actually how we work part of it. That's the term he uses for that, is culture. That's the product we build for our employees.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: You can direct the writer, so you can tell people what to do. You can motivate the elephant, so you can give this thing a kick in the butt and it's going to move. You don't know exactly where it's going to move, but it's going to move. And you can shape the path. Shape the path is I'm going to set this way up so that you can only do these things.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: The eigenquestion, the simplest definition of eigenquestion, it's the question that when answered also answers the most subsequent questions. Rank them by which ones would eliminate the most other questions off the list.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: We basically have this discussion and we all came to the conclusion this market is going to value consistency over comprehensiveness. And by the way, I think, I mean now almost 15 years later, I think we were right. If you go look at video market obviously it exploded. There's so many great video properties out there, none of them are comprehensive.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: We value consistency over comprehensiveness. We would much rather be on fewer phones with a more consistent experience than be on all of them with an inconsistent experience.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: If you're a junior product manager, what happens? You get handed a problem. You get handed a solution. You get handed the how. And all you have to do is execute. At some point you become a little more senior. We hand you a problem and you come back with the solutions. And at some point you're senior enough that you tell us the problems.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: Everything about leading up to this moment from high school and college has been about scope. And at this point you're all of a sudden told, 'We're not judging you on scope anymore. We're judging you on this PSHE thing that's very confusing.'

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: I generally value the reference check over interview signals. If I had to stack rank in interviews, what is the best signal, the reference check is the top of the list. Those people, they worked with this person sometimes for years, their knowledge, what you're going to get out of 30 minutes of artificial scenarios, it's just never going to compare with what a good reference check will give you.

takeaways: Products grow through loops, not funnels - understanding whether your growth comes from viral sharing (Black Loop) or publishing to the world (Blue Loop) fundamentally changes how you structure teams and pricing.
Great companies have golden rituals that are named, known by every employee by their first Friday, and templated - these rituals are a mirror of culture and define how work actually gets done.
Eigenquestions are the questions that when answered, eliminate the most subsequent questions - finding them is a learnable skill that separates exceptional strategic thinkers from average ones.

The PSHE framework (Problem, Solution, How, Execution) reveals that career growth isn't about scope in the middle phase - it's about whether you identify problems, create solutions, or execute playbooks handed to you.

Reference checks are the most valuable hiring signal, far exceeding interview performance - people who worked with candidates for years provide insights that 30 minutes of artificial scenarios never can.

contrarian_candidates.why: Choosing consistency over comprehensiveness - intentionally being on fewer platforms with better experience, against conventional wisdom of maximum distribution
Reference checks beat interviews - challenges the common belief that interviews are the primary hiring signal

episodes.episode_title: The art of product management | Shreyas Doshi (Stripe, Twitter, Google, Yahoo)

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: If you do a pre-mortem right, you will not have to do an ugly post-mortem. The genius is the initial prompt: imagine this project has failed six months from now. Now work backwards and ask what went wrong. It creates psychological safety for team members to talk about things they're concerned about without being negative.
quotes.context: Introducing the pre-mortem framework with tigers, paper tigers, and elephants

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: In a pre-mortem, bring up three things: a tiger (a threat that will actually kill us), a paper tiger (a seeming threat others worry about but you're not), and an elephant in the room that nobody is talking about. That shared vocabulary becomes powerful - in future meetings people started saying 'I have this tiger' and it became okay to bring those things up.
quotes.context: Explaining the specific structure of effective pre-mortems

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: All your tasks are not created equal. There are L tasks (leverage) where you put in effort and get 10X or 100X in return. N tasks (neutral) where you get what you put in. And O tasks (overhead) where you get back less than you put in. Most ambitious people treat each type the same way - and therein lies the problem.
quotes.context: Introducing the LNO framework for prioritizing PM time

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: The same activity can be an L, N, or O task depending on context. Filing a bug report can be leverage if it's a critical issue requiring detailed documentation, or overhead if it's minor and you're just being thorough. Taking notes can be leverage after a strategic CEO decision, or overhead after a routine sync.
quotes.context: Illustrating how the same activity requires different levels of effort based on strategic importance

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: Most execution problems that I encounter in high performing environments are actually not execution problems - they are either strategy problems or interpersonal problems or cultural problems. When you put on a bandaid and the bandaid falls off, it's probably not an execution issue.
quotes.context: Explaining why teams stay overwhelmed solving the same problems repeatedly

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: Two teams misaligned? It looks like an execution problem. But often it's because we don't know what the strategy is. We craft OKRs based on what makes sense, but they're not aligned because we lack clear strategy and priorities. All the review meetings in the world won't fix a strategy problem.
quotes.context: Illustrating how lack of strategy manifests as execution problems

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: In high leverage roles, stop doing work that simply provides positive ROI. Start focusing on work that minimizes opportunity cost. The problem with ROI mindset is you decrease the denominator by working on quick wins and low-hanging fruit. You fill your plate with quick wins and miss the upside by not focusing on optimal things.
quotes.context: Explaining the opportunity cost framework learned from observing Patrick Collison at Stripe

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: Opportunity cost is the value of the optimal option minus the value of the chosen option. When we reprogram ourselves to think in terms of opportunity cost, we're no longer thinking 'Is this a good use of my time?' Instead: 'Is this the best use of my time?' It's a subtle but profound shift.
quotes.context: Contrasting opportunity cost thinking with traditional ROI thinking

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: I learned from Google's 70-20-10: during planning, give teams allocation guidance. 60% on incrementals (high ROI features), 30% on big new initiatives (can't be five initiatives, probably one or two), 10% on stability and infrastructure. This gives people space to pursue the right things instead of filling everything with quick wins.
quotes.context: Sharing tactical guidance on portfolio allocation to enable opportunity cost thinking

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: High agency is finding a way to get what you want without waiting for conditions to be perfect or blaming circumstances. The PMs who surprised me in positive ways - exceeded their capabilities on paper - all had high agency: strong ownership, creative execution through challenges, and high resilience.
quotes.context: Describing the trait that differentiates high-impact PMs from those with unrealized potential

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: At Google I learned the power of thinking really big. There was this unwritten rule: if it's not going to generate more than $100 million in revenue, it's not worth talking about. They would regularly not pursue $100 million opportunities because they had access to billion dollar ones. That habit to ask 'can we make it 10X bigger?' got ingrained.
quotes.context: Describing Google's culture of thinking big and pursuing only massive opportunities

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: Jack Dorsey would just listen a lot more than you'd expect the CEO to listen. Then he would ask one vital question. We discussed a potential acquisition - went through all the intellectual arguments, strategic arguments, metrics arguments. Jack asked: 'How does this make our users love Twitter more?' Simple question. We never really talked about that. I didn't have a good answer.
quotes.context: Describing Jack Dorsey's leadership style and ability to ask penetrating questions

takeaways: Run pre-mortems with tigers, paper tigers, and elephants - imagine the project failed six months from now and work backwards to identify threats, creating psychological safety to discuss concerns without being 'negative'

Use the LNO framework to prioritize time - identify which tasks are Leverage (10-100X return), Neutral (1X return), or Overhead (<1X return), and treat them differently instead of applying equal effort to everything

Most execution problems are actually strategy or culture problems - when the same issues keep recurring despite bandaid fixes, look for missing strategy, cultural misalignment, or interpersonal friction as root causes

Minimize opportunity cost instead of maximizing ROI - stop asking 'is this good use of time?' and start asking 'is this the BEST use of time?' to avoid filling your roadmap with quick wins while missing transformative bets

High agency PMs exceed their on-paper potential through strong ownership, creative execution through challenges, and resilience - they find ways to achieve goals without waiting for perfect conditions or blaming circumstances

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges conventional wisdom that execution problems need execution solutions - argues most are actually strategy/culture problems disguised as execution issues
Goes against ubiquitous ROI-maximization advice - argues that chasing positive ROI leads to quick wins addiction and missing transformative opportunities
Reveals Google's contrarian filter of ignoring $100M opportunities - most companies would celebrate such wins, but thinking bigger meant only pursuing billion-dollar bets

episodes.episode_title: Mental models for building products people love ft. Stewart Butterfield

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: We're on these narrow sidewalks in Vancouver when it starts raining. Most people with umbrellas wouldn't move them out of the way - the pokey bits are at eye level. Only one-third would tilt their umbrella. We said your failure to really exercise this courtesy and be empathic about other people's experience is an advantage that you can create.
quotes.context: The umbrella tilt story that became a core Slack value about product craftsmanship and empathy

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: Utility curves: first bit of effort produces no value, then there's a magic threshold where it produces enormous value, then continued investment doesn't pay off. We would investigate whether we were on the first shallow part of the curve, the second shallow part, or just coming up to it. This helped us decide whether something was worth it.
quotes.context: Explaining the utility curve S-curve framework for product investment decisions

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: It became an assumption that you should always be trying to remove friction. But the challenge is really comprehension. If your software stops me and asks me to make a decision and I don't really understand it, you make me feel stupid. Instead of reducing clicks or taps, focus on how can I make this simple? How do I prevent people from having to think?
quotes.context: Explaining why comprehension matters more than reducing friction or clicks

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: Have you exhausted the possibilities? Creating the distance so that you can make an intellectual rational decision rather than an emotional decision is essential. The reason I say you have to be coldly rational is because pivoting is fucking humiliating. You convinced so many people - investors, employees, press, users - and now you're admitting 'I was wrong. This didn't work.'
quotes.context: Explaining the emotional difficulty of pivoting after Glitch  Slack and Flickr pivots

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: This is 2014, the year Slack launched. MIT Technology Review asked if we were working to improve Slack. I said, 'I feel like what we have right now is just a giant piece of shit. It's terrible and we should be humiliated that we offer this to the public.' If you can't see almost limitless opportunities to improve, you shouldn't be designing the product.
quotes.context: Expressing divine discontent and high standards for Slack even after launch

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: We invented the magic link experience. Typing your password on your phone if you have any minimal threshold of password hygiene is a terrible experience. Capital H, lowercase Q, six, caret, period. So let's just have them enter email address, send them a link, and it automatically opens the app and authenticates them.
quotes.context: Describing Slack's early UX innovation that became an industry standard

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: We came up with the shouty rooster. When you @everyone, a little rooster pops up with sound waves and says 'This is going to cause a notification for 147 people in eight different time zones. Are you sure?' That worked amazingly - it dropped off the abuse. It also taught people how the product worked because they probably didn't think about the cost.
quotes.context: Example of delightful UX that shapes behavior and prevents spam

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: In the long run, the measure of our success will be the amount of value that we create for customers. You can put effort into demonstrating that you have created this value, but there's no substitute for actually having created it. I made everyone in the company repeat this as a chant at all hands.
quotes.context: The core philosophy that guided Slack's product development

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: The default advice for anyone is persevere - 'hang in there.' But I think you have to be coldly rational. Slack had an enormous advantage: we were working on it for several years without explicitly working on it, only doing features that were so irritating we couldn't stand it anymore. When I had exhausted every non-ridiculous long shot idea to make Glitch commercially successful, I decided to abandon it.
quotes.context: Explaining when to pivot vs persevere using the Glitch  Slack example

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: Don't Make Me Think. For two reasons: it's expensive to make a decision - you literally burn glucose, there's cognitive cost. But also there's an emotional aspect: if your software stops me and asks me to make a decision I don't understand, you make me feel stupid. Most people feel 'I'm dumb' not 'the software is stupid.' They associate that bad feeling with the product forever.
quotes.context: Expanding on the Don't Make Me Think mantra with biological and emotional reasoning

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: Google Calendar's time zone picker presents all time zones in alphabetical order. When I type E-A-S-T, first one is Eastern Australia, New South Wales. It's bananas how bad it is - used by hundreds of millions, presumably every Google employee. No one's going to switch from Outlook because the time zone picker is good, but there's real value in delighting customers. That emotional connection makes them recommend it or advocate for it when they switch companies.
quotes.context: Using Google Calendar as example of neglecting craft and its impact on emotional connection

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: When we shut down Glitch, there were people who loved it and would spend all their free time on it. That was their community and it just disappeared. People lost jobs, people who moved families to different cities. Pivots aren't something I take lightly. It's very different to be like 'there's three of us and we pivoted to a different app.' If you're six months in, you're still messing around. That doesn't even really count.
quotes.context: Reflecting on the painful human cost of pivoting from Glitch to Slack

takeaways: Tilt your umbrella - empathy for users' experience is your competitive advantage when most competitors are oblivious to their impact, creating emotional connections that drive organic advocacy

Utility curves guide investment decisions - the first effort produces no value, then hits a magic threshold of enormous value, then diminishing returns; know which part of the curve you're on before investing more

Comprehension beats friction reduction - most product challenges aren't about reducing clicks, they're about helping users understand what something does and why they should care without making them feel stupid

Pivot only after exhausting all realistic ideas - be coldly rational not emotional, because pivoting is humiliating after convincing investors/employees/users, but persevering past the point of viability is worse

Don't Make Me Think - every decision burns glucose and risks making users feel dumb, so ruthlessly eliminate comprehension barriers and obvious next actions to prevent users from associating bad feelings with your product

contrarian_candidates.why: Directly challenges the ubiquitous 'reduce friction' mantra - argues comprehension matters more than clicks, contradicting decades of UX conventional wisdom
Calling your own product 'a giant piece of shit' right after launch - extreme divine discontent that most founders would never publicly admit
Argues pivoting requires 'cold rationality' and admits it's 'fucking humiliating' - challenges the romanticized 'pivot early, pivot often' Silicon Valley narrative

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: A lot of teams, they learn how to do their jobs building products by being told, 'Build these features.' That's a really structured, okay, I just turn out some work problem. And so, we're asking teams to fundamentally do a really different type of job and I think teams needed some scaffolding for how do you make that shift.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: We tend to just really struggle with this distinction between the problem space and the solution space. I think that the heart of good product is really getting comfortable in the problem space or the opportunity space, really taking the time to frame a problem well, and to really get into what's needed before we jump to solutions.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: So the first thing that makes this hard is you have to interview well. I think interviewing is a grossly underestimated skill. Grossly underestimated skill. So that's the first thing is that if you're not collecting rich stories in your interviews, it's going to be really hard to identify opportunities.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: I tell my teams when I teach it in class, I say, 'Look, we're going to focus on structuring an opportunity space, and I'm probably going to make you think harder than you've ever had to think in your job,' because we don't think that much at work. We go from meeting to meeting, we stay surface level a lot.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: I hear from people all the time say, 'I'm not allowed to talk to customers.' I go, 'Okay, well, your company doesn't own you when you're not at work. I bet you know people like your customers. Why don't you just start there?'

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: People make this mistake of we shouldn't put something in our backlog that hasn't been properly discovered. It's not true. Everything in our backlog is a bet, everything. Whether we do discovery or not, everything is a bet. Discovery is helping us make a better bet.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: I think the reason why people make this mistake is they think about it as phases. First I discover and then I deliver. No, you're always delivering and you're always discovering. The more you build this discovery habit, the better those bets are going to get with time.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: The outcome is that we don't really collaborate. When we don't collaborate, I don't think we build very good products. So if we just go back to real life and when you're hanging out with friends and you're trying to accomplish something, you don't first stop and say, 'What's my role? What's your role?' That's just not how humans interact. We all collaborate intuitively. Business has taught us otherwise.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: Kindergartners just start doing. They don't worry about their rules. They don't worry about who's in charge. They just brute force trial and error. What do MBA students do? There's posturing, like who has power and who's the decision-maker and who's right? They spend the whole time negotiating this political social space instead of just doing.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: Product people are in the business of changing behavior, understanding and changing behavior. I think that's a really big mistake that teams make is, both in their prototype tests and in their interviews, they focus on what people would do, on what people think. It's all really unreliable. It's a garbage in, garbage out situation. The real measure is tell me about your behavior. What did you actually do?

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: I don't know why product teams suddenly are held to a standard that nobody else is held to. When somebody says, 'Why is it reliable to make a decision based on one interview?' I flip the question around. Tell me about the decisions you made last week. How many customers did you talk to? Every human in business is making decisions with zero data. So I'm going to go with one is better than zero.

takeaways: The opportunity solution tree provides scaffolding for outcome-focused work - starting with an outcome, branching into customer opportunities (needs, pain points, desires), then solutions. The key is staying in the problem space before jumping to solutions.

Interviewing is a grossly underestimated skill. Collect rich stories by asking 'what happened next?' rather than direct questions. The best interviews feel like having a beer with a friend, not a 50-question interrogation.

Discovery and delivery aren't phases - you're always doing both. Everything in your backlog is a bet; discovery helps you make better bets. Don't stop shipping to do research, start discovering in parallel.

Product trios (PM, designer, engineer) should truly collaborate without rigid role boundaries. Well-functioning trios find options everyone agrees on rather than fighting over who decides. Kindergartners outperform MBAs because they just start doing instead of posturing.

Focus on actual behavior, not hypotheticals. 'What did you do?' is more reliable than 'What would you do?' Product people are in the business of understanding and changing behavior - garbage in, garbage out if you collect unreliable data.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the 'I'm not allowed to talk to customers' excuse by suggesting you find customers in your personal network - subverts organizational gatekeeping
Flips the small-sample-size criticism by pointing out everyone else makes decisions with zero data - defends qualitative research against data purists
Uses kindergartners vs MBA students to challenge business culture's obsession with roles, hierarchy, and planning over action

episodes.episode_title: Tobi Ltke's leadership playbook: First principles, infinite games, and maximizing human potential

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: My energy source is dissatisfaction with status quo. I think today is the dystopia of the future. It behooves us to try to build the kinds of products that lead towards progress.
quotes.context: Describing what drives him as a founder and why he rejects copying existing solutions

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: A Tobi tornado is a whole lot of change management compressed into a very short timeframe. If I imagine something might not be the right thing to work on, I'm either incorrect or I'm correct - and it's super unfair for letting people work on something that isn't going to make it.
quotes.context: Explaining the 'Tobi tornado' phenomenon of rapidly killing projects when he realizes they won't work

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: I really, really, really think that there is not a single person on this planet who is even close to being at their maximum potential. Reminding people of their own potential constantly is actually a wonderful thing to do.
quotes.context: Explaining his philosophy of maximizing human potential through high standards and direct feedback

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: The most powerful unquantifiable things in the world of business are fun and delight. If all the metrics are pointing down but everyone says 'My God, I'm having so much more fun,' I think the very next thing that will happen with some time delay is all metrics will start going up.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify doesn't use OKRs and instead prioritizes unquantifiable things over metrics

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: Optimism always sounds dumb, or at least naive. Pessimism sounds extremely sophisticated. Metrics driven sounds sophisticated. Talking about fun sounds naive. But almost all of the alpha in the world is now in exactly the things that are unobvious but true.
quotes.context: Challenging conventional business aesthetics and why contrarian approaches often win

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: If you want to do something better than what exists, you have to do it differently. That's axiomatically not possible to do the same thing and get better results. It fails Archimedean logic.
quotes.context: Explaining why first principles thinking requires doing things differently from everyone else

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: 100 years, you can't talk about this software product but you can talk about the mission itself. Entrepreneurship is just precious. Shopify exists basically to make entrepreneurship more common.
quotes.context: Describing Shopify's 100-year vision and how long-term thinking shapes decision-making

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: On a long enough timeline, playing positive-sum games with your customers is the ultimate growth hack. The best companies resemble a room full of dials or levers for monetization. My job is adding as many of these levers as possible to the room, and then not pulling any of them.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify doesn't maximize short-term monetization despite having pricing power

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: The business world only talks about tactics - conversion optimization, A/B tests, growth hacks. I don't think that's important. The positional game is what matters: what territory are you taking? How much trust do you have? If you do that well, the tactics are yours. But if you extract through tactics all the value you created, you have nothing left in the tank.
quotes.context: Contrasting short-term tactical optimization with long-term strategic positioning

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: Goodhart's law: Any metric that becomes a goal ceases to be a good metric. It's the same as overfitting in machine learning. School optimizes for marks, and overfitting in school is literally kids cheating to get marks. We're extremely data-informed but we don't have KPIs because no metric by itself is a complete heuristic for a complex business.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify core product team operates without KPIs despite being extremely data-informed

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: Most of the time you end up in a bad part of a tree, in a local maxima of a path-dependent environment, by only making good choices. The presence of a downside of an idea does not disqualify the idea. You need to rerun the entire function over the state that is now updated with higher fidelity information.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify went fully remote during COVID by re-running first principles analysis when foundational assumptions changed

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: When someone disagrees with me, I immediately love it. I really crave it. I think courage is really rare. I found a lot more high IQ in industry than courage. I found a lot more genius than courage. What I'm looking for is unstated foundational assumptions - what is our divergence point?
quotes.context: Describing how to disagree with him and why he values courage over intelligence

takeaways: Dissatisfaction with status quo is a founder's energy source - today is the dystopia of the future, so we must build products that lead toward progress rather than accept conventional solutions

Maximize human potential through high standards and compressed feedback - no one is close to their maximum potential, and holding people accountable to that potential (not just current performance + 10%) unlocks extraordinary results

Prioritize unquantifiable things (fun, delight, quality) over pure metrics - Goodhart's law means any metric that becomes a goal ceases to be useful, so Shopify is data-informed but doesn't use KPIs or OKRs

Think in 100-year timeframes to make better decisions today - long-term thinking enables playing positive-sum games, resisting short-term value extraction, and building lasting strategic position over tactical wins

Re-run first principles analysis when foundational assumptions change - being in a local maxima from 'good choices' is dangerous; when core booleans flip (like COVID lockdowns), re-derive everything from scratch

contrarian_candidates.why: Directly challenges metrics-obsessed culture by arguing fun and delight matter more than quantifiable KPIs - sounds naive but produces better results
Argues that optimism and 'naive' approaches contain all the alpha while sophisticated pessimism leads astray - counterfactuals are winning
Rejects conventional monetization wisdom - builds levers for pricing power then deliberately doesn't pull them to play long-term positive-sum games

episodes.episode_title: Why AI is disrupting traditional product management | Tomer Cohen (LinkedIn CPO)

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: When we look at the skills required to do your job, by 2030, which is literally four years from now, sounds a long time, but four years from now, it will change by 70%. So whether or not you're looking to change your job, your job is changing. The only question is, do you keep it?
quotes.context: Tomer shares LinkedIn's unique data insight about how dramatically skills requirements are shifting, setting the context for why the Full Stack Builder model is necessary.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: In order to stay competitive, you actually have to go back to some first principles, go back to the drawing board and reimagine what it means to be building. And what I love about this is when you think about the role of a builder, which the builder is at the heart of company, the goal is actually quite simple. The builder takes an idea, she brings it to life.
quotes.context: Tomer advocates for returning to fundamentals rather than adding more complexity, emphasizing that the builder's core job is simply to bring ideas to life.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: And now we have this real opportunity to collapse the stack backup, go back to craftsmanship, rethink the product development lifecycle, which is where the full stack builder model comes to life.
quotes.context: After explaining how product development became bloated with process and microspecialization, Tomer introduces the Full Stack Builder model as a return to craftsmanship.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: The key trait that I'm emphasizing for builders is where I want them to spend their time is where I think great builders should shine in. So the idea of vision. Coming up with a compelling sense about the future. Empathy, super critical. Communication is critical. Creativity. And then ultimately what I think is the most important trait for a builder is judgment. Everything else, I'm working really hard to automate.
quotes.context: Tomer identifies the five core human traits that AI cannot replace: vision, empathy, communication, creativity, and most importantly, judgment.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: An analogy I have in mind is kind of Navy SEALs. You come to training, they're all kind of learning, they're cross-trained, across multiple areas. What they specialize in is the mission and they operate in small pods and they're very nimble and you can assemble them very quickly. And I think that's going to be the organization that will win in the future.
quotes.context: Tomer uses the Navy SEALs as a model for future product organizations: cross-trained individuals who specialize in missions, not functions.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: If you're at a company at a scale of ours and many others in the market, you're like, this is almost like a new production function and mindset that you have to do. And there's really three components that we're working on. One is platform. The second one is the tools and the agents. And lastly is the culture.
quotes.context: Tomer outlines the three-pillar framework for implementing the Full Stack Builder model at scale companies: platform, tools/agents, and culture.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: You can't just bring a third party tool and have it work on the LinkedIn stack. In fact, that's one of our biggest learnings. It never works. Never works. You have to bring it in and customize a lot of it, working almost in alpha mode with those companies to make it work internally.
quotes.context: A key learning from LinkedIn's AI transformation: off-the-shelf AI tools never work at enterprise scale without significant customization.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: It's not great to just give it access to your drive and say, 'Reason all over this knowledge base.' It actually does a very poor job understanding importance of the past and putting weights on stuff. You actually want to think about specifically what the context when do you want to give it to and what's the knowledge base that you want to have it focused on.
quotes.context: Tomer explains why simply giving AI access to all company data fails - you need curated golden examples and focused knowledge bases for quality outputs.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: Top talent has this tendency of continuously trying to get better at their craft and this innate need to be at the cutting edge of how you build, and I think we're seeing this here as well. This is why I had this phrase I say with the team that if we build all those tools, will they use it? And I know right now the answer is no. It's not enough to give them the tools to use it.
quotes.context: Tomer observes that top performers are the biggest adopters of AI tools, but providing tools alone is insufficient - you need incentives, motivation, and examples.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: Change management here is going to be a critical part. I think I see a lot of companies roll out their agents and just expecting companies to adopt. It doesn't work this way. Some will adopt. That tends to be your cutting edge 5% of talent that just wants new tools and they have a bias for change. But the vast majority needs to work for change management.
quotes.context: A warning against the 'build it and they will come' mentality with AI tools - only 5% will naturally adopt, the rest need deliberate change management.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: If you're looking for a formal reorg or declaration to start building differently, you're waiting too long. Look, my biggest thing is here's a permission for me to just not wait and just go. So whether or not you have the right tools or not, go build the tool, use a tool from the outside, bring it in, show those examples.
quotes.context: Tomer's direct advice to individuals: don't wait for organizational permission to start building with AI - demonstrate the full stack builder mindset now.

takeaways: By 2030, 70% of the skills required for your current job will change - your job is transforming whether you change jobs or not, and the only question is whether you keep it.

The Full Stack Builder model collapses organizational complexity back to craftsmanship: small, cross-functional pods that can take ideas from inception to launch, like Navy SEALs specializing in missions rather than functions.
AI cannot replace five core human traits: vision, empathy, communication, creativity, and most importantly judgment - everything else should be automated.
Three pillars are required for AI transformation at scale: platform (re-architecting for AI), tools (customized agents, not off-the-shelf), and culture (the hardest but most important).
Building tools alone is not enough - only 5% of talent naturally adopts new tools; the rest need deliberate change management, incentives, and visible success stories to shift their mindset.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the common assumption that AI tools work out-of-the-box - at enterprise scale, off-the-shelf solutions never work without deep customization
Pushes back against 'build it and they will come' mentality - most AI tool rollouts fail because companies expect automatic adoption
Argues against waiting for organizational permission or formal programs - if you're waiting for a reorg to start building differently, you're already behind

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: If I'm not getting the reaction that I'm looking for, how might I be contributing to that? Instead of blaming other people for not understanding me, I think about how could I explain this more clearly? How can I be more compelling? How can I anticipate any questions that they might have? I'm a big proponent of agency.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: I see a lot of operators who save their best behavior for executives only. They want to shine when they're presenting to senior leadership, but with everyone else, they're kind of calling it. I just don't think that you're going to be able to get enough reps to actually get good at executive communication if you are only doing it with executives.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: A common mistake that I see is overestimating the amount of buy-in that you have from your audience. That looks like jumping straight into talking about the logistics, the details of the how to do something, when in reality your audience has not yet decided if they even want to do the thing.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: Being concise is not about absolute word count, it's about economy of words. It's about the density of the insight that you're sharing. You can have a 300 word memo that's meandering and long-winded and a thousand word memo that is tight and concise.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: We've all heard 'Don't bury the lead, cut to the chase, put the main point at the top.' All of these pithy aphorisms assume that you actually know what your core point is. You can't cut to the chase unless you know what the chase is. That's the bottleneck to being concise. It's actually not being clear of what you are thinking.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: The blast radius of a poorly written memo is way bigger than most people think. If you're just shooting off a message in a Slack channel with 15 other people and it's confusing, there's going to be a bunch of back and forth. Whereas if you had just taken another look at it, those 15 people would be off to the races.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: All these little things compound and make a big difference. I often hear people think this individual email or Slack message is not worth spending a couple more minutes on. The problem with that line of thinking is that no one instance is ever going to feel important enough, and when you zoom out, that's all your work then.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: MOO stands for Most Obvious Objection. A lot of times we're surprised by the questions that we get, especially in meetings where we feel blindsided. When really, if you thought for even two minutes about what are obvious objections that I'm likely to get, you often immediately come up with what some of those things are.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: One of the most common myths about managing up that I definitely felt early on was that I would have to manage up if I were more junior, but eventually I would outgrow it. It was a rude awakening that no matter how senior I got, not only did I have to manage up, it actually became more important.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: When you just ask your manager 'What should we do?' you're putting a lot of cognitive load on them to think about the problem, think about potential solutions, craft the solution, and then tell you what to do. Whereas if you said 'Here's what I think we should do, how does that sound?' you give them something to build off of.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: I have a framework called strategy, not self-expression. By the time we are giving feedback to someone, we have been frustrated for a while. The goal is behavior change. So trim everything that does not contribute to that goal and only keep the part that will make the person want to change.

takeaways: Take ownership of communication outcomes - if you're not getting the reaction you want, examine how you might be contributing to that rather than blaming others for not understanding.
Always sell before logistics - people haven't decided if they want to do something yet, so establish buy-in before diving into the how and process details.
Being concise means economy of words, not brevity - a longer document can be tighter and more concise than a short one if every word earns its place.
Use the MOO (Most Obvious Objection) framework before any presentation or proposal - spend even two minutes anticipating the obvious objections to avoid being blindsided.
Managing up becomes more important as you get senior, not less - share your point of view and recommendations rather than asking your manager what to do.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges common advice about being concise - argues the bottleneck is clarity of thinking, not word count reduction
Counters the myth that managing up is a junior skill you outgrow - argues it becomes MORE important with seniority

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: One of the big reasons why I think curiosity loops are really useful is that it really fights the fact that there's a lot of bad advice out there. And it's not bad because it's not well-intentioned, but it's bad because it's not contextual.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: A question's good if it's specific, if it solicits rationale, and it's not biased. You don't want to start a question with, here's what I think because people have this tendency to want to please you or to agree with you.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Don't do what people tell you to do. Take it as an input and look for the hard feedback. Look for things that you strongly disagree with or are surprises to you. Because to me, I think these loops are more about looking around the corner and seeing if there's anything you missed in terms of the integrity of your decision making process.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: It's this internal scorecard of what really matters to you in your decision making process as opposed to the external scorecard of status, money, wealth, how other people perceive you, that often we feel really pressured by. So it's this great way to look back and see how well do decisions, or how well do my situations in life align with my values.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Explore and exploit, if you're familiar with it from growth background, is really just around what mode you're in. You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, how well it works, whether or not it fits for you. Or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep and then you're just trying to get more.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Don't be the frog. If you take a frog and you put in a pot and you increase the temperature degree by degree by degree, the frog doesn't notice and before it knows, it's boiled alive. It's really easy to be a victim of inertia. It's really easy for all of us to be the frog where there are little things that make us uncomfortable, and we sit with them.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: I think it's a terrible outcome to wake up one day and be late career and feel trapped because you have a certain lifestyle or a certain expectations of the people around you that you have to go work this job, but then you look at yourself in the mirror and you're not happy going in there. I think that's a terrible trap that we should all try to avoid.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: There's an outer scorecard, which is how the rest of the world evaluates you, how you keep score in terms of external factors. Top 10 lists, wealth status, title. And then your inner scorecard is things that actually matter to you, how you spent your day, how good of a person you are. Did you have an adventure today? Were you kind?

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: My hot take is that for the vast majority of people, they probably do not need a coach. If you're looking for a mentor, a coach is actually a terrible mentor in some ways because it's this one person's opinion. It's actually way better to run a curiosity loop and get the benefit of a couple different minds on a specific topic.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: We're not powerless, even though this game is rigged. We can study the game, we can help each other, and we can actually start to call out some of those rules and then find ways around them.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Eating your vegetables is really this idea around how little kids don't really develop an appreciation for vegetables until they're 10 or 12 exposures in. You have to do things a number of times before you really develop an affinity for it. Because the first time you do it, you're just not going to be good.

quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.text: Figure out, maybe the night before, the one thing that you want to get done in your day, and then at the earliest opportunity, just try to give yourself five minutes on it. Just five minutes. Usually, what I find is that five minutes turns into a solid hour just knocking that thing out early in my day.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: The founders of that company were looking for what I would call a silver bullet strategy to their growth challenges. And what they really needed was to create a strategy to add on new growth loops and a system for how to execute against that strategy.
quotes.context: Adam reflects on a mismatch at Wyzant where founders expected quick fixes rather than systematic growth building.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: The goal of the competency model is not to find a unicorn human being that is an 11 out of 10 on every one of these things, because frankly, that person doesn't exist. The goal is to create a well-rounded team so that you're hiring and balancing skills across your team and that you don't have any gaps in your portfolio.
quotes.context: Adam explains that growth teams should be evaluated holistically rather than searching for impossible unicorn candidates.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: One of the things that people don't easily understand is that most people come to your product with an emotional frame and a lot of people want to appeal to their logical brain right away. And the reality is, don't do that. You have to understand the mindset that people are in.
quotes.context: Adam shares his background in consumer psychology and why understanding emotional motivations matters more than logical appeals.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: Seeking the solution in a customer interview is never going to work, right? You seek to understand and then you take that away and you can think through what the model should look like and how things should change as a result.
quotes.context: Adam agrees with the Collison brothers' view that user research builds your mental model of customers, not direct solutions.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: Influence is one of the biggest and hardest skills to develop. It's no different in a growth practitioner and in some cases it can even be harder because sometimes people come in with a preconceived notion of what growth is and isn't and you have to change their mind.
quotes.context: Adam describes influence as the pinnacle competency that requires constant relearning with each new company or role.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: If you're going to hire a junior person, the key is, how do you help them learn? If you don't know what you're doing as the founder or the leader, you're not going to be able to help them yourself. So you've got to be willing to invest in advisors, outside education, mentorship, coaching.
quotes.context: Adam warns that hiring junior growth talent without support systems leads to enthusiastic people running through walls when doors exist nearby.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: I tend to skew more towards internal hire to be perfectly honest, because I believe in creating opportunity inside a company. I think it's not done often enough. And I also believe that helping people transition into new roles is a way to get more people into the practice.
quotes.context: Adam recommends internal hires for growth roles because they already have customer knowledge and faster time to results.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: Onboarding is the only part of your product experience that a hundred percent of people are ever going to touch. Good luck getting a hundred percent feature adoption of anything else in your product. It's also the first opportunity that you have as a company to deliver on the promise that you made out in the marketplace.
quotes.context: Adam explains why onboarding is such an underappreciated growth lever with universal impact on the user experience.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: I like to think of your brand is the promise that you're making and your product experience is your delivery of that promise. And those two things have to be in lockstep with each other or you're going to have mismatched expectations and some really disappointed customers.
quotes.context: Adam frames the brand-product relationship as a promise-delivery system that must stay synchronized.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: I have seen companies shift their curve outward by 10, 15, 20 percentage points from making those changes, especially when you consider that churn is most likely to happen in the very earliest usage of the product. If you can get people past that hump, it's a really invaluable part of the product to work on.
quotes.context: Adam quantifies the retention impact of onboarding improvements and early habit formation.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: I actually think if you're doing it right, sometimes conversion should actually decrease a little bit. So you might actually have fewer people getting all the way through successfully, but I think that's okay because a lot of those people were probably not the right people for your product.
quotes.context: Adam shares the counterintuitive insight that good onboarding may reduce conversion but improve retention by filtering wrong-fit users.

quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.text: When you're interviewing at a company, you are actually investing an even more scarce resource. You're investing your time. There is no way to get more time. We're all on a finite clock. You can always get more money.
quotes.context: Adam reframes job decisions as investment choices where time is the scarcest and most valuable resource.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: The exploring emerging channels framework has three core ingredients. The first is understanding if there is an overlap between what the customers need is, what your company's goals are, and what the channel actually does really well.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: I was pretty amazed how many more people were trying to crack Clubhouse than TikTok. TikTok is very clearly not going away anytime soon, where Clubhouse hopefully won't but was clearly very early. Part of this reason is to accept the risks of going into that channel.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: I like to spend a lot of time thinking about how they monetize. If you, as a business, can match or support their monetization strategy, it gives you a really interesting leg up. The likelihood of you being able to call them up and do custom stuff with them, or partner with them, goes up pretty drastically.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Do you actually have comfort in being a true first mover? Nobody knows anything, tracking's not going to work, it's not going to be programmatic. You're probably going to show up on content that's offensive. It's going to be really painful to be a true first mover. Do you have that appetite?

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Generally I wouldn't let anything bleed past a quarter. You can probably get some good signal in a month or less, what I would call fishing - putting bait in the water to figure out where the fish are, not necessarily getting statistically significant repeatable solutions.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Start by assuming you no longer have product market fit, because you had product market fit in a different market. It's a different market now, so you have to start over. If you just assume you need to launch a new channel to fix this problem, you're going to be wrong, because your entire customer base changed.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Data driven generally - performance is a very loaded word because people think it means not brand. But you absolutely can measure retention, brand, and the consideration funnel. Making data part of the DNA of everything that's happening is pretty quintessential of being a growth driven CMO.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: The iteration process is not thinking about things as 'We need to plan for the next 24 months.' Having a more agile type approach to everything - the storytelling your salespeople are doing, landing pages, logo design, brand itself. Being more open to everything being possibly iterated on using data to validate.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Learn product development. Go learn agile product development. Any great marketing CMO should be able to consume how to do product development, how to run sprints. And their mind will be like, 'Oh my gosh, I could do this with this big event. I could do this with everything.' There's nothing off the table.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: The one that I see the most is adaptability goes down really fast. Your openness to change in the business, or trying new things, has shifted from 'Here are the flags but let's give it a shot' to 'Why are we wasting our time?' That's a pretty good signal they may be more burnt out than just exhaustion.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: I can pretty cleanly tell the difference between exhaustion and depression. It tends to tie to my broader motivations, not just my motivation to work. When I'm exhausted, I'll still show up to improv class and enjoy it. If I'm depressed, I won't go. I'll just cancel it.

quotes.speaker: Adam Grenier
quotes.text: Now I have five or six different friends that we're massively transparent with about this stuff. The second I shared any of this with them, they shared it with me. And now we've become safe places to have those conversations where I can figure out which thing is causing this energy right now.

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: When you start small, it forces you to think about what is the problem that I'm going to solve. In all this advancements of the AI, one easy, slippery slope is to keep thinking about complexities of the solution and forget the problem that you're trying to solve.
quotes.context: Explaining why starting with minimal AI autonomy helps teams focus on the actual problem rather than getting lost in technical complexity

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: 74% or 75% of the enterprises that they had spoken to, their biggest problem was reliability. That's also why they weren't comfortable deploying products to their end users or building customer facing products because they just weren't sure or they just weren't comfortable doing that and exposing their users to a bunch of these risks.
quotes.context: Citing UC Berkeley/Databricks research on why enterprises struggle to deploy AI products

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: I used to work with the CEO of now Rackspace. He would have this block every day in the morning, which would say catching up with AI 4:00 to 6:00 AM. Leaders have to get back to being hands-on. You must be comfortable with the fact that your intuitions might not be right. And you probably are the dumbest person in the room and you want to learn from everyone.
quotes.context: Describing how successful AI transformation requires leaders to rebuild intuitions and be vulnerable about learning

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: If someone comes up to me and says, 'We have this one click agent, it's going to be deployed in your system and in two or three days, it'll start showing you significant gains,' I would almost be skeptical because it's just not possible. I probably will go as far to say that if someone's selling you one click-agents, it's pure marketing. To replace any critical workflow or to build something that can give you significant ROI, it easily takes four to six months of work, even if you have the best data layer and infrastructure layer.
quotes.context: Warning about unrealistic AI agent marketing and setting realistic expectations for enterprise AI deployment timelines

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: There's this false dichotomy of this either evals is going to solve everything or online monitoring or production monitoring is going to solve everything. I find no reason to trust one of the extremes. Evals are basically your trusted product thinking that is going into this set of data sets. Production monitoring is you're deploying your application and then you're having some sort of key metrics that actually communicate back to you on how customers are using your product.
quotes.context: Addressing the evals vs production monitoring debate by explaining they serve complementary purposes

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: Martin Fowler at some point had this term called semantic diffusion back in the 2000s, which kind of means that someone comes up with a term, everybody starts butchering it with their own definitions and then you kind of lose the actual definition of it. That is what is happening to evals or agents or any word in AI as of today, everybody kind of sees a different side to it.
quotes.context: Explaining why AI terminology like 'evals' and 'agents' has become confusing as different groups use the same terms for different concepts

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: Codex, we have this balanced approach of you need to have evals and you need to definitely listen to your customers. It's extremely hard to build an evaluation dataset for all kinds of interactions that your customers are going to use your product for. With that said, you also need to understand that if I'm going to make a change, it's at least not going to damage something that is really core to the product.
quotes.context: Explaining OpenAI Codex team's pragmatic approach combining evals for core functionality with heavy customer feedback monitoring

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: We built these end-to-end agents and we had to shut down the product because we were doing so many hot fixes and there was no way we could count all the emerging problems that were coming up. Recently, I think Air Canada had this thing where one of their agents predicted or hallucinated a policy for a refund, which was not part of their original playbook, and they had to go by it because legal stuff.
quotes.context: Sharing the origin story of the CCCD framework - real failures that led to developing the continuous calibration approach

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: Misunderstood is the concept of multi-agents. People have this notion of, 'I have this incredibly complex problem. Now I'm going to break it down into, hey, you are this agent. Take care of this. You're this agent. Take care of this.' It's never the case that there are incredibly successful multi-agent systems that are built. Letting the agents communicate in terms of peer-to-peer kind of protocol is incredibly hard to control.
quotes.context: Explaining why multi-agent systems where agents communicate peer-to-peer are misunderstood and harder than hierarchical supervisor patterns

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: Building is really cheap today. Design is more expensive, really thinking about your product, what you're going to build. Is it going to really solve a pain point? That is way more valuable today. And it will only become more true in the near future. So really obsessing about your problem and design is underrated and just rote building is overrated.
quotes.context: Arguing that in the AI era, implementation is becoming commoditized while thoughtful product design and problem definition are increasingly valuable

quotes.speaker: Aishwarya Naresh Reganti
quotes.text: Implementation is going to be ridiculously cheap in the next few years. So really nail down your design, your judgment, your taste. And now we have AI that could help you ramp pretty quickly. After a few years, I think everybody's job becomes about your taste, your judgment and kind of what is uniquely you.
quotes.context: Discussing how AI shifts career value from execution mechanics to taste, judgment, and unique human perspective

quotes.speaker: Kiriti Badam
quotes.text: Persistence is extremely valuable. Successful companies right now building in any new area, they are going through the pain of learning this, implementing this and understanding what works and what doesn't work. Pain is the new moat. That kind of knowledge that you built across the organization or across your own lived experiences, I feel that pain is what translates into the moat of the company.
quotes.context: Introducing the concept that going through the painful learning process of building AI products creates competitive advantage

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: Deep thinking takes time and space, and you got to create that space. The mundane, pointless bullshit will take every square inch you give it. So you got to make that space to sit back and reflect and luxuriate in these ideas.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: To me, LLMs are magical duct tape. They're formed principally by the distilled intuition of all of society into a thing that operates between, a cost structure between human and plain old computing. So much of how the industry is built presupposes the idea that software is expensive to write and cheap to run, and LLMs undermine both of these.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: I think in this early stage, we're in the community gardening phase, not the factory farming phase of this technology. And so I think what people need most is curiosity and play. You should be playing with these things and trying out different things and seeing what weird things are possible now.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: We've seen a vast reduction in the cost of distribution of information, and now we're seeing a reduction in the cost of information production. And most of it is slop. And so in this cacophony, how do you stand out? You stand out by having good taste.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: Taste, one way of looking at this is differentiate from what the LLM would've written if given the same prompt. How different, how distinctive is what you have to say.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: Think of it as having an extremely well-read but slightly naive friend who will never make you feel dumb and is willing to engage you in any particular topic you want to go down. So I use LLMs to help me. It's like getting an electric bike for idea spaces. You can just cover so much more ground so much more quickly in them.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: Kayfabe is a word that comes from professional wrestling and it means a thing that everybody knows is fake and yet everybody acts like is real. And I think it's one of the defining forces within an organization, any organization. So kayfabe in the small is optimism, enthusiasm. The problem that you get is as organizations get larger, this compounds. So then your layer above you does the same, and levels up you can be many orders of magnitude off of the ground truth.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: So much of the way that we tackle problems and build products is this builder mindset. It's like I have a plan, I then manipulate things to match my plan and make it happen. Part of the problem though is it can't possibly create more value than the effort that you put into it. What I look for instead are things that can be gardened, things that can grow on their own and that you can direct or maybe give a little bit of extra energy to.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: I think emergence is one of the most powerful forces if you know how to marshal it and you know how to work with it. And the only thing that's hard about it in my opinion is you're going to look like you aren't very serious. You're going to look like a weirdo. You're going to look like a kook.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: If you want to get your team to do good work, there's a million different paths to do that. If you want to get your team to do great work, there's no shortcut other than to have an extremely high-trust environment where people lean into their superpowers in a way that adds up to something greater than sum of its parts.

quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.text: The adjacent possible is a set of actions that you can do. They are right in front of you that if you do them, they would almost certainly work. And in the tech industry in particular, we default assume that the adjacent possible is like this and then flying leap to something. And in reality, the adjacent possible is quite small. It's within arm's reach.

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: By far, I would say the speed and ambition of working at OpenAI are just dramatically more than what I can imagine. And I guess it's kind of an embarrassing thing to say because everyone who's a startup founder thinks like, 'Oh yeah, my startup moves super fast and the talent bar is super high and we're super ambitious.' But I have to say, working in OpenAI just made me reimagine what that even means.
quotes.context: Alexander describes his initial shock at OpenAI's pace after running his own startup for 5 years

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: If I think of what I was doing in my startup, it moved way slower and there's always this balance with startups of how much do you commit to an idea that you have versus find out that it's not working and then pivot. But I think one thing I've realized at OpenAI is the amount of impact that we can have and, in fact, need to have to do a good job is so high that I have to be way more ruthless with how I spend my time now.
quotes.context: On the ruthless time management required when the stakes and potential impact are extremely high

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: Because we don't exactly know what capabilities will even come up soon and we don't know what's going to work technically, and then we also don't know what's going to land even if it works technically, it's much more important for us to be very humble and learn a lot more empirically and just try things quickly. And the org is set up in that way to be incredibly bottoms up.
quotes.context: Why OpenAI operates with radical bottoms-up decision making due to inherent uncertainty in AI development

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I was just, again, surprised or even shocked when I arrived at the level of individual drive and autonomy that everyone here has. So I think the way that OpenAI runs, you can't read this or listen to a podcast and be like, 'I'm just going to deploy this to my company.' Maybe this is a harsh thing to say, but I think very few companies have the talent caliber to be able to do that.
