quotes.context: A candid admission that OpenAI's bottoms-up approach only works with exceptional talent density

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I like to joke today that AI products, and it's a half joke, they're actually really hard to use because you have to be very thoughtful about when it could help you. And if you're not prompting a model to help you, it's probably not helping you at that time. And if you think of how many times the average user is prompting AI today, it's probably tens of times. But if you think of how many times people could actually get benefit from a really intelligent entity, it's thousands of times per day.
quotes.context: The gap between current AI usage (tens of prompts) and potential value (thousands of daily assists) drives Codex's proactivity focus

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: My analogy for this is, going back to this teammate analogy, it's like if you hired a teammate, but you're never allowed to get on a call with them and you can only go back and forth asynchronously over time. That works for some teammates and eventually that's actually how you want to spend most of your time. So that's still the future, but it's hard to initially adopt. But the key unlock is actually first you need to land with users in a way that's much more intuitive and trivial to get value from.
quotes.context: Why Codex pivoted from cloud-first to IDE-integrated - you need synchronous rapport before async delegation

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: If we're going to build a super assistant, it has to be able to do things. And one of the learnings I think we've seen over the past year or so is that for models to do stuff, they're much more effective when they can use a computer. It turns out the best way for models to use computers is simply to write code. So we're kind of getting to this idea where, well, if you want to build any agent, maybe you should be building a coding agent.
quotes.context: The counterintuitive insight that every AI agent should fundamentally be a coding agent

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: As we make code even more ubiquitous, it's actually just going to be used for many more purposes. And so there's just going to be a ton more need for humans with this competency. I think what we can do basically as a product team building in the space is just try to always think about how are we building a tool so that it feels like we're maximally accelerating people rather than building a tool that makes it more unclear what you should do as the human.
quotes.context: The product philosophy of maximally accelerating humans rather than replacing or confusing them

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I have this sort of hypothetical future that I like to share sometimes with people as a provocation, which is in a world where we have truly amazing agents, what does it look like to be a solopreneur? And one terrible idea for how it could look is that actually there's a mobile app and every idea that the agent has to do is just vertical video on your phone and then you can swipe left if you think it's a bad idea and you can swipe right if it's a good idea.
quotes.context: A provocative thought experiment: Tinder-style swiping as the ultimate human-agent interface

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: We recently shipped the Sora Android app, and that was one of the most mind-blowing examples of acceleration, actually. The Sora Android app, a fully new app, we built it in 18 days. It went from zero to launch to employees, and then 10 days later, so 28 days total, we went to just GA, to the public, and that was done just with the help of Codex.
quotes.context: Concrete example of Codex impact: Sora Android app (became #1 in app store) built in 28 days with handful of engineers

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I think we might've been in this weird temporary phase where, for a while, it was so hard to build product that you mostly just had to be really good at building product and it maybe didn't matter if you had an intimate understanding of a specific customer. But now I think we're getting to this point where actually if I could only choose one thing to understand, it would be really meaningful understanding of the problems that a certain customer has.
quotes.context: As building becomes easier, deep customer understanding becomes the most valuable competitive advantage

quotes.speaker: Alexander Embiricos
quotes.text: I think a current underappreciated limiting factor is literally human typing speed or human multitasking speed on writing prompts. My view is that we need to unblock those productivity loops from humans having to prompt and humans having to manually validate all the work. So if we can rebuild systems to let the agent be default useful, we'll start unlocking hockey sticks.
quotes.context: The surprising AGI timeline insight: human input/validation speed is now the limiting factor, not model capability

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: No one wants to make anybody upset, but through that upset on the other side of that, can often be a whole new possibility and a whole new revelation, and actually a lot of joy and freedom. I think that we forget about all the other possibilities that come out of difficult conversations and we just land on these really uncomfortable parts.
quotes.context: Alisa reframes difficult conversations as opportunities for breakthrough rather than just discomfort

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: She cried. Of course she did. She cried. That's what he knew she was going to do. And so she was upset and she went home early and the whole thing. The next day she came in and she said, 'Thank you so much for telling me that. I wish someone had told me that 15 years ago. I think I could have had a different career.'
quotes.context: Alisa shares a story about a manager who finally gave difficult feedback despite knowing the employee would cry

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: What I'm trying to convey in my tone is also, 'You know what? It's Tuesday. We got to have this conversation. I'm sure it's going to end well. I'm not mad.' The more even keeled and even matter of fact you can be about something that's kind of just run-of-the-mill feedback, the better.
quotes.context: Alisa emphasizes the importance of neutral, matter-of-fact tone in delivering performance feedback

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: Observable facts. The idea that this is not a judgment. This is not... Sort of as less judgy as possible is also very helpful. It makes it neutral. It's observable facts and it's also sort of based on expectations, right? So the writing is, we expect it to be at a certain level and it's not that way.
quotes.context: Alisa explains how grounding feedback in observable facts rather than judgments makes it easier to deliver and receive

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: Hope for the future is so important and I think sometimes we're such in a rush to kind of deliver the bad news that we forget there's a human being over there who needs hope for the future. And hopefully. If they're a good employee, hopefully they have hope for the future.
quotes.context: Alisa emphasizes the importance of providing hope when delivering difficult news about promotions

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: When you, as a leader signal a lot, I care about you, I care about your feelings, I care that you're disappointed, I care about your career, you are always going to be able to help people stay resilient in the face of setbacks and ultimately, do extra work, do the right work for you and be engaged in your company because you've spent the time and energy making sure they know that even when things are not going their way, they have an ally in you.
quotes.context: Alisa explains how signaling care builds resilience and engagement even during difficult conversations

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: Before you fire someone, I think it's helpful to have the conversation before the firing conversation. Regularly with my clients, I'll say, 'Okay, have you been crystal clear about what you need from this person?' And what they always do is the hand motion like well, sort of, but well, maybe. Which means no, which means no. You've not been crystal clear.
quotes.context: Alisa explains the importance of crystal clear expectations before considering termination

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: The positive feedback should have the same standard, which is, 'I saw the way you ran that launch, it was fantastic. All these different benefits came from it. You're so organized, keep doing that.' If you do that often enough, you become in the habit of getting better at positive feedback, which is extremely motivating to people at work.
quotes.context: Alisa argues that positive feedback needs to be as specific and thoughtful as constructive feedback

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: I think it's very misguided for leaders to have this notion that their most important role is to keep people happy, is to create this high engagement workforce. What that comes from is winning culture, which means we're set up for success. We've got the structure for success, we have the culture for success, everyone understands their role, they know the impact of their role.
quotes.context: Alisa challenges the common belief that leaders should focus on making employees happy versus driving results

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: My three questions to end the meeting are, what did we decide here? Who needs to do what by when? And who else needs to know? And if you can capture those, articulate those as deliverables, I promise you, you're going to have better meetings.
quotes.context: Alisa shares her framework for ending meetings with clear decisions and accountability

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: According to Noam Wasserstein, 65% of startups fail because of conflict with founders or the founding team. So it's really essential to get this right, and I agree that people step into this relationship with a lot less care than they should. And bad things can happen because you haven't done the work of getting to know each other before you decide to co-found.
quotes.context: Alisa introduces the founder prenup concept by citing founder conflict as the leading cause of startup failure

quotes.speaker: Alisa Cohn
quotes.text: If you can see your path all the way through to the end, you are following someone else's path. Your path only becomes clear moment by moment as each foot hits the ground.
quotes.context: Alisa shares a Joseph Campbell quote that animates her life philosophy on career paths

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: I really enjoy being right and then it turns out in the working world, that did not serve me so great. I think the hard part is sublimating your ego a little bit and saying it's more important to get to the outcome than to be right.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: Assume that executives have a little tiny dinosaur brain. We can really only hold three facts at the same time. We will never be able to go deep in the way that you are able to do on everything that crosses our desk. The best service you can do is actually do the work of making a recommendation.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: You don't want to come to a product review for every single decision. Instead, what you want is to come to a product review with one decision, but the goal of that decision is to walk out with principles about how to make these decisions in the future so that you don't have to come to product review.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: For me, the hill climb is all about the difference between a local optimum and a global optimum. You're standing on top of the hill, but way off in the distance you can see a mountain. You have to decide, are you going to take the risk of climbing down your hill, crossing an unknown chasm, just to get to the same level with more climbing to do?

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: Narrative can carry so much weight where otherwise you can either tell everybody exactly what to do at every point or you can create a story that we all agree on. If we all agree that the feeling of something should be sitting in Dolores Park with friends on a sunny Saturday, people will just naturally build something that feels more consistent.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: Strategy is super fun but customers don't care. Customers don't care about your fancy strategies and your five-year plan. They care about the product that's in their hands. Anything that distracts you from thinking about the product in your hands is a distraction.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: When you have great strategy but poor execution, you don't win because your strategy never makes it to the market. And what's even worse is that you have learned nothing. You don't know whether it was your strategy that was wrong or whether it was your execution that was wrong.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: The biggest thing that held me back from talking about strategy was I didn't feel confident that I knew enough to declare a strategy. It was actually almost like a self-confidence, imposter syndrome thing. I was always like, how could anything could happen? Who would I be to say I know how the world's going to develop?

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: Don't dampen who you are and your strengths, just continue expanding. Whenever you run into a problem, just add more to the things that you can do, the tools that you have, the ways you can express yourself. Just keep on adding and growing and don't shrink yourself, ever.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: If you give everyone the same goal like 'go get GMV', it leads to what I call toddler soccer, where everybody just runs to the same surface or the same customer set. Everyone's tripping on each other, nobody really gets contact on the ball, there's no coordination.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: As you get senior, the only problems you'll see are ones that are fundamentally unsolvable because otherwise, someone would've solved it before they got to you. All you're doing is choosing which branch of suboptimal you're going to put your name on and describing the principles you're using.

quotes.speaker: Ami Vora
quotes.text: The thing that has led me to the places where I do my best work is a feeling of being at home, which is all about trust. Can I walk through and feel like these people are going to have my back, they're going to let me take risks, I'm going to enjoy spending time with them?

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: Typically, you're bottlenecked where your ideas are not fitting in because they need to be made and they need to be made quickly. Now, you open up that bottleneck. So now actually making things is a lot easier. Actually, you become limited by how fast you can generate ideas.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: I could imagine whatever five years from now, someone running a billion-dollar company with zero employees where it's like the support is handled by AI, the development is handled by AI, and you're just building and creating this thing.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: The vision for Replit has always been is like, okay, making software is fun, is great, more people should do it, but so for more people to do it, it needs to be easier to do, it needs to be in one place, and it needs to be learnable.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: I often go with minimalist prompts. That's also how I code as well. I have a vague idea for what I want to build and iterate from there. Other people, product managers like to write PRDs and more descriptive things, and you can do either of those things.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: If you think about it's like we're building as you were building, so we're building out the agent so that it can continue getting better as our users are also building their applications.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: When the cost of things go down, the total consumption of it goes up. And so I think that's going to be the case of software. As the costs go down, people will just make a lot more software to improve their lives and to improve their work and start more startups and all of that.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: These silos between designers, product managers, and engineers. Everyone feels that pain of, we have low bandwidth communication, which is language and then text on Slack and Zoom calls. The common language that everyone shares is code. What if the language becomes actually working prototypes and working applications?

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: Being generative, being able to generate new ideas quickly, because you can think about it as a factory line. Typically you're bottlenecked by the middle part where your ideas are kind of like they're a lot of them and they're not fitting in, because they need to be made and they need to be made quickly. Now you open up that bottleneck. Actually, you become limited by how fast you can generate ideas.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: The return on investment for learn to code is doubling every six months. Every six months, that's netting you more and more power because you're going to be able to create a lot more. It's going to be easier to create. You're going to be able to create a lot more complete things.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: The way we work is going to change rapidly, and it's important to be resilient to that change. You want to be able to react to it really quickly. When the Anthropic drop the computer use set of capability, we slaughtered our roadmap. We immediately jumped on it and started building things. Being agile, not being stuck with roadmaps, being able to just say, oh, we're just going to switch priorities right away, is going to be super important.

quotes.speaker: Amjad Masad
quotes.text: You got to be fluid because when designers can code and engineers can design, it really becomes, you can't have a lot of structure around that. So you want to build a culture and you want to build an environment or milieu that is really, really flexible, which is uncomfortable for a lot of people.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: Charlie Munger says, 'Fish where the fish are.' If you see a large pond with a whole bunch of fishermen elbowing each other out of the way, you actually want to walk off into the forest and find a small fishing hole with lots of fish and very little competition. Competition equals lower margin.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: You don't want to walk into the gym on day one and try to deadlift 300 pounds. When someone comes to me as a first time entrepreneur and they say, 'I'm going to make the next great AI company,' I think that is the equivalent. You want to take the baby weights and start slowly building your muscle.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: There's a big difference between a business and a job. If the business can get big enough where you can have employees, you can just focus on sales or digital marketing or whatever aspect of the business you love. Lean into what I call lazy leadership - how do I get away from things I hate as quickly as possible?

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: I started Flow, basically Asana before Asana. I made the mistake so many entrepreneurs make - going after an industry everybody goes after. I ended up losing $10 million trying to compete with venture-backed businesses while bootstrapping. It was like Fiji deciding to invade the United States.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: It's just not true that a bootstrap business can't get huge. We bootstrapped the entire business and now across all our companies we do almost $300 million in revenue. The only difference between what we do and what a VC does is the level of tolerance for burning money on fire.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: When I'm buying a business, I'm looking for something I can't mess up. Warren Buffett would call it a moat - a brand like Coca-Cola that gives you pricing power, or network effects where a community has gotten so big that people don't want to go elsewhere. If someone else wants to compete with Letterboxd, why would someone go when all their friends are already there?

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: My business partner says, 'There are no problems. There is only people problems.' As long as I'm surrounded by great smart people, I feel fine. But when we have a bad actor, a psycho or narcissist, all bets are off. I spend 20% of my time just filtering people carefully and ensuring we work with people we enjoy.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: With Lindy, I've automated my email. The AI decides if I even need to see it, labels things time-sensitive, and for simple decisions like 'Want to get lunch?' it emails me privately with multiple choice options. I just say 'four' and it'll email you as me. It's replaced my full-time assistant working on email.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: We are in the Palm Treo phase of AI. If it was accessible to everybody where you could just open ChatGPT and say 'I run a business, can you help me?' and it starts asking questions and becomes a digital employee - that's the iPhone moment we're going to have in the next five years.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: I met this guy worth $5 billion, and he goes, 'Jeff Bezos is just so fucking rich.' I asked what Bezos can do that he can't. He said, 'He can buy a super yacht.' We're all just comparing ourselves to our peers. Whatever our peers have that we don't, we feel hard done by. That's the scary reality.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: I reframed money so that 90% goes into my philanthropic foundation and gets given away. So when I think about working hard or an investment going well, the win isn't for me. The win is about doing something good. I also stopped spending as much - the more stuff I had, the less happy. I was owned by my stuff.

quotes.speaker: Andrew Wilkinson
quotes.text: I started taking an SSRI and within three or four days, it was like someone had turned down the volume on the nasty voice inside of me. For the first time in my life I felt relief. No amount of money or success or attention had done what this little tiny yellow pill could do for my mental state.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: I was so focused on my work that I had slowly become the frog that was boiling in the pot, the typical analogy of you don't realize how bad things are getting because it's happening to you slowly until it happens quickly.
quotes.context: Andy describes how burnout crept up on him gradually during his tech career, using the classic frog in boiling water metaphor to explain why high achievers often don't notice deteriorating mental health.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: I learned very early on that if I wanted to feel good, I needed to achieve, and that if I wanted to love myself and be considered lovable by others, I needed to achieve.
quotes.context: Andy traces his drive for achievement back to losing his mother at age 10, explaining how achievement became his coping mechanism and source of self-worth.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: I'd say that it's a fair estimate to say that at least 50% to 60% of tech employees who have been in the saddle, so to speak, for a minimum of five to seven years, they're experiencing some form of psychological and emotional distress.
quotes.context: Based on surveys and research, Andy shares the prevalence of psychological distress among tech workers, noting it may be more significant than people realize.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: These adaptations, if you're unaware of them and if you're unaware of the subconscious drivers that are responsible for them, they run the risk that they go too far, and that these adaptations, which were initially beneficial to you and to your life, they reverse course in a sense, and they become detrimental to your present state and your future development.
quotes.context: Andy explains how survival mechanisms that served us well earlier in life can become harmful if we remain unaware of their subconscious influence.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: These large transitions in life rarely take place in the absence of suffering. So step number one is suffer. Usually, the deeper somebody suffers, the more significant the transition that may follow.
quotes.context: Andy outlines his four-step framework for deep personal transformation, beginning with the necessary role of suffering in catalyzing meaningful change.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: I now understand what some philosophers described as death before dying. In this process of change that I've been going through, it's been the death of the old me, the death of Andy whose identity was entirely attached to succeeding, and that old Andy doesn't want to let go.
quotes.context: Andy describes the psychological experience of letting go of a decades-old identity built around achievement and success.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: There is necessary suffering in life or the mandatory suffering, and then there's the unnecessary suffering, which is the suffering that is almost entirely, and I think the argument could be made that it's entirely made up in our minds.
quotes.context: Drawing from Eastern philosophy, Andy distinguishes between unavoidable life hardships and the self-created suffering that comes from our mental interpretations.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: Once that dog can make it into the arms of an owner that it feels safe with and loved by, that's when you see the dog transform and change, and that's when you can teach it a lot because it's open and receptive to it.
quotes.context: Using the analogy of adopting a traumatized dog from a shelter, Andy explains why feeling safe is the prerequisite for genuine healing and transformation.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: If your sleep always sucks, if your relationships are constantly strained or frequently strained, if your physical health is failing, there's so many ways that that can be measured so there's really no excuse for that to say, 'Oh, I just didn't know.'
quotes.context: Andy identifies the physical and relational warning signs that indicate deeper psychological distress, emphasizing that the body keeps score of our mental health.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: So we lose who we were before the world told us who to be. It's actually a Carl Jung quote, 'The world will ask you who you are, and if you don't know, it'll tell you.'
quotes.context: Andy explores how social conditioning causes people to lose touch with their authentic selves, citing Carl Jung on the tension between individuality and conformity.

quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.text: The vast majority of people who die on Mount Everest actually die on the way down, not on the way up. You don't save anything for the return home, I think is the point.
quotes.context: Andy uses the Everest metaphor to challenge the relentless pursuit of career peaks, suggesting that treating life as a mountain to climb leaves nothing for the descent.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: The way I learned how to pitch in business school, and I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor. So you have a problem, a pain, I have a solution, a treatment, and I'm going to tell you why it's better than all the other treatments. And the structure that I read about in these movies was different. Every movie starts with some kind of shift in the world.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: This structure really is about defining a movement and that's very different from, 'Hey, I'm going to solve your problem.' So Benioff comes in and he says, 'Hey, software is over and there's this new world called the cloud, a new game, new rules. That's the new way to win.'

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: What I think is really interesting is this story has a certain structure. I call this shift the shift from the old game to the new game. The archetypal example in the business world is what Benioff did with Salesforce. Instead of just saying we're better than Siebel, they said all those others are part of that old game.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: What I call naming the stakes. Zuora is saying, 'Hey, look at all the new winners, Airbnb, Box, they're already doing this subscription thing.' They show this scary stat about the longevity of Fortune 500 companies getting smaller. Basically they make this case that companies are dying, the ones that are winning are doing this.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: How does George Lucas change Luke's mind? He basically kills the aunt and uncle. Now it's pretty clear they're coming for Luke. Now the stakes are life and death. The prospect doesn't see the future as sort of okay. They see it as split between a very negative outcome and a potentially very positive outcome.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Airbnb for a while had this one, live anywhere. If you think about it, this buyer mission statement, this rallying cry, I think of it really as the mission of the company. What is the mission of Airbnb other than to help people live there if they're going to be customer focused?

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: I think about obstacles because they sound like problems. This is what people would normally say, 'Oh, these are the problems we solve.' But by setting up this story thing first we've repackaged them as obstacles to a new goal state that we've already positioned as life and death. So they take on this much more emotional meaning.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Amit Bendov told me, 'Yeah, you know what? In hindsight we probably could have called it strawberry intelligence. It didn't matter. It was really the story that sort of mattered.' I guess I feel like by calling it category and category name, we're just focusing on those three words so much when really we should focus on the story.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Once we have this story then everything in marketing can be all about this story. With Zuora, maybe 80% of the content is not 'Hey, let me tell you about how Zuora is so great.' It's 'Here's how music companies are embracing subscriptions. Here's how luxury goods companies are embracing subscriptions.' It's less salesy.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Another thing I always hear is it becomes the strategic north star for the product. One CEO said, 'We are constantly getting feature requests through sales, through customer success. And we had no way to decide what we take on, what don't we take on. This has clearly become our bar.'

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: I am so against templates. Every team I work with, it's different. It's not the same number of slides. Sometimes we can lay out this shift in one slide, sometimes it just feels better if it's a few. Sometimes there's no slides. These are principles for building it, not any prescribed formula.

quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.text: Make the title the takeaway of the slide so that the person looking at it has to do zero work to take away. Replace 'The team' with 'Our team is veterans of whatever industry.' Every single slide it's a takeaway, not a label. It'll make everything flow a lot better.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: When people say 'I want someone that's strategic,' they're really saying 'I want someone that can articulate a compelling and simple why behind decisions.' The second piece is 'I want someone who will champion and be a change agent for things that are hard but best for long-term interests.' If you have one without the other, people won't see you as strategic.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Summarization, even though I may not be adding a new idea, people actually view that as strategy. They view effective summarization as strategy. Taking ideas and making them slightly better, slightly better - when you think from an outside-in perspective of customer problems, you start to get to big ideas that can really be change agent ideas.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Having a founder that can effectively operate in founder mode means I can go have a conversation with the CEO and say 'We have this huge opportunity and these things aren't working.' Activating that founder to push the initiative that I think is best by making them an ally.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Understanding the details of the business, asking questions about what's working, what's not, financial goals, how decisions are made - getting into that level of depth is super important. Then you can decide as a leader what you want to do with that information. A lot of information I collect, I don't do anything with at a point in time.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Be a historian. When I joined Rubrik, I tried to understand what happened in the past. What products weren't successful? Why? What was the perception of different people? I constructed this past knowledge so I could better understand how to make decisions going forward and learn from mistakes I didn't personally live through.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: It's not about making the right decision, it's about making the decision. Once you commit to a decision, you learn more post committing than in hypothetical analysis. As long as your decision is 70% right, you can iterate on that 20-30%. If you don't commit, you don't get any new high fidelity information.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: I reward the learning versus the outcome. If we're constantly learning, it's okay if we make bad decisions as long as we learn from them. Even in making a bad decision, we learned something about our customers or business that we can use in another context.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: When I hit a difficult personality, I try to understand what drives that person. What do they really care about? If I need something from them, what can I do to motivate them to find what I need important? Like building a product - they have this desire, how do I get them to care about what I want to achieve?

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Instead of feeling anger or frustration, I ask myself what can I learn from this person? Everyone has something they can teach you - their communication style, how they marshal people together, their visionary ideas. Studying that person and being curious, then genuinely feeling gratitude for what I got from the situation.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: I care so much about you and I'm giving you this feedback because I want you to be successful. You do all of that setup explicitly - you actually say that and show it in your body language. That makes the other person much more receptive to hearing whatever you have to say.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: I frame things as 'this is how you're being perceived' rather than 'you are doing X.' You're giving them the benefit of the doubt that how they're trying to show up is different than how people perceive them. Then you can have a conversation about what they can do to change that perception.

quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.text: Journaling is very powerful. When I have a lot of thoughts going through my head, especially negative thoughts, putting them on paper helps me break down what's abstract. I realize 'this is something I feel but the why behind it is irrational, let me let this go.' It's like doing cognitive behavioral therapy on yourself.

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: It's so incredibly necessary in improving decision quality to take what's implicit and make it explicit. It's not that intuition is crap, your intuition is sometimes right. If you don't make it explicit, then you don't get to find out when it's wrong.
quotes.context: Explaining why structured decision-making processes outperform pure intuition, drawing from work with First Round Capital

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: People generally think the purpose of a meeting is for three things, discover, discuss, decide. The only thing that's ever supposed to happen in a meeting is the discussion part.
quotes.context: Introducing the concept of nominal groups - discovering opinions independently before meetings to avoid groupthink

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: The word alignment in terms of we're all aligned as a group is stupid and it shouldn't be used. People don't actually agree, they're not actually aligned on the decision. That's just the thing that makes you feel better.
quotes.context: Challenging the common goal of 'alignment' in meetings - arguing that forcing agreement creates coercion and ignores reality

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: The best way to get somebody's opinion is independently of other people's opinions, independently asynchronously. I want people to stop talking to each other so much. There's cross influence, the loudest person in the room tends to have an outsized influence on the decision.
quotes.context: Explaining why teams should collect opinions before meetings to avoid groupthink and anchoring bias

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: There is no such thing as a long feedback loop. You can make a decision about how long the feedback loop is. The way you choose to shorten the feedback loop is to say, what are the things that are correlated with the outcome that I eventually desire?
quotes.context: Pushing back on VCs who said they can't improve decision-making because feedback takes 10 years - explaining how to find leading indicators

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: A pre-mortem is great only if you set up kill criteria. Commit to actions that you're going to take if you see those signals. People won't quit until it actually isn't a decision. Until you've fallen in the crevasse already, then you'll make the decision to quit because then you know it was really bad.
quotes.context: Explaining why pre-mortems fail without pre-committed kill criteria - citing Richard Thaler's observation about delayed quitting

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: When Kahneman took hiring from completely unstructured to structured decision rubrics, the hit rate went from 50% to 65%. That's pretty huge. The problem is nobody does it. If you do it, the answer is quite a bit. But nobody does it.
quotes.context: Describing Daniel Kahneman's work on structured hiring and the implementation gap between knowing and doing

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: Nevertheless is a really good leadership skill. I hear you. Nevertheless, you're grounded for two weeks. I heard what you're saying and I understand. Nevertheless, this is what's going to happen. You have to have the balance between them feeling heard and following through on what you know or believe is right.
quotes.context: Teaching a leadership framework that acknowledges input while maintaining decision authority

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: Mental time travel is a really good decision tool. They would be really upset about something and I would say this is going to be so great for you when you're 40 at Thanksgiving. You're going to be able to tell these stories to your children. It allowed them to get some time and space from it to realize this is going to be funny at some point.
quotes.context: Describing how to use mental time travel to gain perspective on decisions that feel huge in the moment

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: By the time you quit, it's probably long after you ought to have quit. When we walk away, we feel like we'll have wasted everything that we've already put into what we're doing. But of course, waste is a prospective problem, not a retrospective one. Everything that you're putting into this going forward is the actual waste.
quotes.context: Explaining sunk cost fallacy and why people wait too long to quit projects, jobs, or relationships

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: Stewart Butterfield shut down Glitch when they had $6 million in the bank, 5,000 diehard users, and growing 6-7% week over week. He woke up with dead certainty that Glitch was over. Two days later, he's like, 'Maybe that internal communication tool should be the next product.' That thing now gets a name: Slack.
quotes.context: Iconic example of strategic quitting - Stewart couldn't see Slack until he quit Glitch despite apparent success

quotes.speaker: Annie Duke
quotes.text: When we think about something as simple as forecasting how long it's going to take to launch a product feature, if you're senior and you say 'I think this is going to take three months' and I was thinking four weeks, you're never going to hear four weeks from me, ever. But if we get those opinions independently, you will actually hear that I think it's going to take four weeks.
quotes.context: Explaining how independent forecasting reveals true disagreement that gets hidden in meetings due to hierarchy and conformity

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: Lovable is your personal AI software engineer. You describe an idea and then you get a fully working product. We are building for this 99% of the population who don't write code. Currently, if you're technically inclined, you get much further, but over time, naturally the way to build software is by just talking to an AI.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: These tools are already very good, but mainly they're getting better very, very fast. I think the best thing for people who are interested in this is get your hands very dirty with these tools because being in the top 10% in using them is going to absolutely set you apart in the coming months and years.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: It takes a lot to master using tools like Lovable. Being very curious and patient is super useful. Explaining exactly what you expect and what you're not getting is even more important with AI than with humans. Don't say 'it doesn't work' - explain exactly what you're expecting and which parts are working and which parts are not.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: We are seeing the biggest change humanity will ever see. Before you had manual labor being taken over by machines, but now it's actually cognitive labor being done better than humans by machines. What's the best way to have positive impact? Enable those who have had such a hard time finding people who are good at creating software.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: There are many scaling laws when you build AI systems. This one is about when you put in more work, the product reliably gets better. We painstakingly identify places where it gets stuck and address them, tune the entire system quantitatively with a very fast feedback loop to improve it in the areas where it got stuck.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: People love the product. That's the driver of the growth. For getting awareness, we've mainly been posting what we've shipped on social media. The team is everything in building a great product. You want people who can ship really fast and have good taste for what's simple, what's the right abstractions.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: If you're a founder or you want to build something, figuring out what are pain points and seeing how you can make this 10X better somehow is super important. The engineer skill set is still important because it helps you understand the constraints. Engineers should see themselves as translators from problems stated by humans to technical solutions.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: Doing a bit of everything. Being a generalist is I think much more important than it used to be. If I'm putting together a product team today, I would obsess about getting as many skill sets as possible for each person I hire. They should know architecting, design, product taste, how to talk to users.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: The most important thing is that people care a lot. They're not just 'here for a job' or 'here to be a passenger.' Everyone should really care about the product, the users and care a ton about the team. That care or preferably obsession gets you a very long way.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: This is the time in human history when you have the most impact for a worked hour. That's why we have to be super ambitious. Inspiring people to be ambitious in a place where the average ambition is lower but the raw talent is much more available - that's a great recipe.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: Identifying what is the biggest bottleneck, the biggest problem, and iterating fast on solving that problem. Then picking the next one and not overthinking, not dreaming out the long roadmap. That's a very simple algorithm. Understanding what is the biggest problem is not always simple though.

quotes.speaker: Anton Osika
quotes.text: We work from the office most of the time. Especially lunch, eating lunch together is a pretty productive hour where you're cross pollinating. People are constantly thinking subconsciously about how to solve problems. Being in office has this focus but also high bandwidth where everyone has unstructured communication.

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: You have to think about users on modern internet consumers having three attributes. So they are lazy, they are vain, and they're selfish. Lazy meaning, 'I don't have time for this, so blow my mind away. Otherwise, I'm not going to pay attention.'

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: We are product managers, and we are in the business of influence. Users are doing something, and now we want them to do something else. Our engineers are doing something, and now we want to influence them into building something fast.

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: What you're working backwards from is an entire machinery at a particular day that is working. For the date of GTM, what do we need to do from here till that particular day so that the GTM is successful, but also, what will be the machinery we would have created.

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: I really truly believe in the power of three. So I actually ask my teams to write three press releases, alternative and divergent. What if we... Suppose you're launching a membership program. Instead of two tiers, let's do three tiers. Let's say within these three, and they all need to be fully thought-through.

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: I think product managers have to own outcomes and not only features and parts of the problem. Did it work in the way that it really changed the behavior of the kind of user that we wanted to achieve a business outcome that will build a capability that is important for us?

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: In my opinion, when you have to make a choice, think more and ship better. Most experiments should be thought experiments. They should not even be tried out because they're obviously going to fail which is contrary to, 'Let's try it out, and then let's see.'

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: Most product managers should not even be product managers. They should think a little bit more around whether this is actually the right field for them because I think a lot of people from other areas have entered the field without fully realizing what it takes.

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: There are only three reasons why things do not happen the way you want them to happen as a leader. Either that person can't do, which is a capability issue, or they won't do, which is a motivation or an alignment issue, or they were not set up to do.

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: At least I've realized that apart from what product managers can do, almost 70%, 80% of problems why things don't happen are a setup issue. Product leaders or other leaders have not thought through what OKRs are doing to my company, not really fully thought through around org design.

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: OKRs will not work in marketplaces. Fundamentally, OKRs are a way to think about objectives and key results, but the fundamental assumption here is that it is solving for a kind of user. But if it is working for three different kinds of users, then all the goals will all the time be in conflict with each other.

quotes.speaker: Anuj Rathi
quotes.text: Work backwards from an amazing future. So first thing is creatively imagine a future, and then work backwards from that, and essentially, think what will make that successful, and be paranoid about... that everything is going to go wrong.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: Open mics are the real live experiments. You put something out there, you get very clear micro feedback from users, and then you get tough feedback sometimes. And I think as product builders, that's actually one of the great skills to have, which is you sometimes launch stuff that have a fantastic vision, but the first version is not quite there.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: What does a Frontier product look like? And more importantly, how does a Frontier way of working look like? What does a team with three people and tons of compute and AI tools look like?

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: When I think about agents, I think about three things. One is an increasing level of autonomy and kind of independence that you can delegate higher and higher order tasks. Second thing I think of it is complexity. It's not a one-shot, it's build me this prototype. And then the third thing I would say is asynchronous. It works when you are not working.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: NLX is the new UX. Traditionally we've thought very consciously about GUI because the graphical interfaces are not something natural. What we have with conversational interface and natural language is it's a much more elastic. That doesn't mean it's not designed. Conversations also have grammars, they have structures, they have UI elements, they're invisible.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: In this day and age, if you're not prototyping and building to see what you want to build, I think you're doing it wrong. I call it the prompt sets are the new PRDs. I really insist on folks saying if you're building new projects, new features of course come with prototypes and prompt sets. Demos before memos.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: The time to first demo is much shorter, but the time to a full deployment is going to take longer. There's going to be a massive increase in supply of ideas and prototypes which is great. It raises the floor, but it raises the ceiling as well. How do you break out in these times that you have to make sure that this is something that rises above the noise?

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: It becomes even more important to have that editorial and taste making in a Frontier, one or a few at the heart of it because otherwise you just have Frankenstein product. That definitely doesn't change.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: If you are a TPS report, mostly process person, I think then you do have a question of what is the value add here. But what I do think is the taste making and the editing function becomes really, really important. In a world where the supply of ideas, supply of prototypes becomes an order of magnitude higher, you'd have to think about what is the editing function here.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: The updating of the priors is really hard. The models couldn't do some things one year ago. My impression from trying it a few months ago, that prior needs to be updated. You have to do something almost counterintuitive to say ignore what you learned about what this can or cannot do. The baby just grew up to be a 15-year-old in a month.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: There's a temptation to rush and say to go to scale before solve. So I've always said to my teams solve before scale. When you're trying to solve a problem, there are wide lurches. You got to be very comfortable with the fact that you're day one thinking about a plant detection tool and day 15 you're like, oh, actually, the tech is really good for translating foreign language.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: You do want to look for at least two out of these three factors: Is there a step function in the tech? What is the consumer behavior shift? And is there an inflection point in the business model? All three for a great product, but at least two out of three for a good product.

quotes.speaker: Aparna Chennapragada
quotes.text: It's harsh, but being early is the same as being wrong. The interface was great, the intelligence wasn't there. It made me realize I really love seeing around the corner and building the product rise to the occasion way more than the scaling and sustaining products.

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: 40 to 60% of B2B purchase processes end in no decision. The majority of those couldn't figure out how to make a choice confidently. So what they did was they just went to their boss and said, 'You know what? Now's not a good time. Let's not do it now. Let's do it next year.'
quotes.context: Explaining why B2B buyers delay decisions - not because status quo is better, but because they're overwhelmed and afraid of making the wrong choice

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: What B2B software buyers want in a sales interaction is perspectives on the market and help weighing their options. And we don't do that. We're just like, 'Here's our stuff. You figure it out, it's up to you.'
quotes.context: Contrasting what buyers actually need versus what sales teams typically provide

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: The way we combat buyer indecision is not just talking about ourselves, it's actually about trying to be helpful to that person in this very stressful situation that is trying to figure out how do I make a really good decision.
quotes.context: Describing the shift from product-centric to buyer-centric sales approach

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: If a customer is indecisive, throwing FOMO into the mix makes it worse. They're less likely to close the deal if you throw that in. They're already stressed out and you're just putting more stress on them by pressuring them.
quotes.context: Citing research from The JOLT Effect that studied 2.5 million sales calls

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: There is this secondary job that the champion of the deal has, and that's how do I make a decision without getting fired? And so we got to help them accomplish that job, otherwise we don't get what we want, which is the money.
quotes.context: Discussing Jobs To Be Done framework applied to B2B software buying

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: Once we realize that the champion is the key, then we can get really tight on our positioning in our sales pitch. What we're really trying to do is just cook the champion, and then once the deal's going we got to arm the champion for how to handle all these objections of all these other groups.
quotes.context: Explaining B2B buying complexity with 5-7 stakeholders involved

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: Differentiated value is the answer to the question why pick us over the other alternatives? It's value that the other guys can't deliver because they don't have the capabilities that underpin it.
quotes.context: Defining the core concept that drives effective positioning and sales pitches

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: The posture we should have is calm confidence. We really understand why people should pick us. We should be able to come in and say, 'Look, if you don't care about those results, you shouldn't pick us. You should pick someone else.'
quotes.context: Describing the ideal sales posture when discussing competitors

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: Obviously creating a category is not the only way to create a legendary business because the vast majority of legendary businesses did not create the categories that they're in. Google did not create search, Facebook did not create social network.
quotes.context: Pushing back on the 'category creation or bust' narrative

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: Most category creators actually get overtaken by fast followers. What happened to MySpace? What happened to Ask Jeeves? Most category creators wins their market. Like what happened to MySpace? It didn't work out so good for them.
quotes.context: Challenging the myth that category creators always dominate their markets

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: In the work I do with clients, generally what we're working on is a shift in the positioning. For the most part what was happening in the sales pitch is there was no positioning going on at all. The sales pitch was essentially a product exposition, just feature, feature, feature, feature, feature.
quotes.context: Diagnosing the core problem with most B2B sales pitches

quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.text: I worked at a company where I was the VP marketing, and we, within two quarters, had doubled the revenue just by tightening up the pitch. Just tighten it up. Most of the time, the pitches are so bad that if we could improve it even a little bit, it actually has this big impact.
quotes.context: Sharing the concrete business impact of improving sales positioning and pitch structure

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: Most businesses do ultimately fail. And so the way we look at it is can we lower the barriers to getting started and get as many people in the door trying their hand at entrepreneurship? If we do that, many of those folks will maybe on their first attempt not be as successful, but we're going to have a set of merchants who go on to become extremely big businesses.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify optimizes for lowering barriers rather than retention, embracing the power law of startup success

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: This way is thinking about a cohort of users we acquire in a given time period, say a quarter. And then over the next year, two years, three years, four years, five years, how much GMV have those merchants produced in total? Not about per merchant basis, but in total, did that cohort generate GMV?
quotes.context: Describing how Shopify measures success through long-term cohort GMV rather than individual retention metrics

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: And I would encourage everyone, if you can, look at some of the experiments that you thought were your biggest winners. Look at the downstream metrics for a year, two years on that experiment. And I'll bet you'd be surprised how many times the metric is different than what you thought it would be after a year.
quotes.context: Encouraging teams to measure long-term effects of experiments, revealing that results often differ significantly over time

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: I think it actually trains, a lot of us in growth are looking at these short-term metrics. A lot of the time it's actually more pull-forward effect than you fully realize or an incremental user that's just really not worth that much.
quotes.context: Explaining why short-term experiment wins often don't translate to long-term impact - they're frequently just pull-forward effects

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: If I give you a little monetary boost and reduce that monetary friction, I can actually causally change your ability to become successful, because I've given you a little bit more time to try that idea a little bit longer. I've given you that opportunity to move your business over to Shopify.
quotes.context: Explaining how reducing monetary friction can causally enable entrepreneurial success by giving people more time to succeed

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: How often do we find no long-term effect after seeing early impact? It's in the 30 to 40% range. Unfortunately, I think that's brutal. Probably more common than we like to believe. A lot of experiments showing short-term lift have no incremental long-term lift on GMV.
quotes.context: Revealing the uncomfortable truth that 30-40% of experiments showing short-term lift have no incremental long-term impact

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: My recommendation to folks is don't think, 'Oh my goodness, I have to wait all this time.' Because if you didn't move the short-term impact, you're not going to have the long-term lift. So still ship if it's short-term lift. Just be reasonable that if you can measure it longer term, you'll get better about identifying what things are that are really impactful.
quotes.context: Providing practical advice: still ship experiments with short-term lift, but calibrate expectations about long-term impact

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: The simplest way to increase my signup to activated thing is just make it harder to sign up. Nuts and bolts, that will always happen is when you have teams on that local conversion rates, you get all these weird team incentives, because they're optimizing to basically implicitly make it harder to do the step before them.
quotes.context: Warning about the perverse incentive where teams optimize conversion rates by constricting the funnel step before them

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: Instead of I'm trying to convert a bunch of people, a conversion rate, I just want more people to get activated. And then once you start thinking that way, you realize actually the best way to get more people to get to a step sometimes, and often they just get more people in the door in the first place.
quotes.context: Advocating for teams to focus on absolute numbers rather than conversion rates to avoid perverse incentives

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: In our culture of aim heavy, if the intuition is right that this probably is helping merchants, why do we start with that the original control is better if it's neutral? Let's start with, what would we have shipped if we were a blank slate? And if it's neutral, actually neither is better, so let's just pick the one we feel better about and ship that.
quotes.context: Explaining Shopify's philosophy of shipping neutral experiments when intuition suggests they help merchants

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: One of the things I've learned is that how, the technical architecture determines strategy in a technology company even more than the what and who we're building for. If you build the right technical how and set yourself up to have a platform that can be adaptable, flexible, that is incredibly valuable over the long term.
quotes.context: Sharing Tobi's insight that technical architecture determines strategy more than product decisions in technology companies

quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.text: It's subjective, but it's objective in the sense that it's kind of a small number of people who really hold what that bar is and needs to be. I think if it's just subjective, let's just ship what we want without a couple people really holding that quality and that taste bar, that's where things go really sideways.
quotes.context: Explaining how Shopify maintains quality without KPIs - through a small number of leaders who hold the taste bar

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: The positioning for Square Stand was for brick and mortar businesses, particularly quick serve coffee, donuts, sandwich shops. It was up against your ugly old point of sale, your cash register. The benefit was turn your iPad into a point of sale. The differentiator was one unified experience you'd be proud to have out on your counter.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: Seesaw is an iPad app that helps work from elementary school students go between teacher, parents and student. When I tell you what the company does, you're like, 'Oh, that makes sense.' But the name doesn't tell you exactly what it does. I tend to like names that are suggestive or evocative where the name makes sense when you hear the company.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: There's descriptive names like Internet Explorer, suggestive names like Chrome, evocative names like Seesaw and Maven, and then empty vessel or fanciful names. When you do your brainstorm, you want to think across all of them. My personal bias is I tend to like suggestive names.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: Seven criteria for names that always apply: trademark, domain availability, distinctiveness - is it memorable and different? Is it timeless? Does it somehow suggest an emotion or feeling you're trying to convey? Sound and ease of pronunciation. Appearance - some names lend themselves to visual design. And length.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: Disney means magic today. Volvo means safety. Those names are not good. If I just put it in a spreadsheet, no one would pick it. A bad name with a great company with great strategy, great marketing is going to be great over time. A good name is just going to help you, but I don't think a bad name is going to kill a good company.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: Your brand is who people think you are. And developing a brand strategy is what do you want to be? What do you want people to think you are? And what are you going to do to help shape that perception? There's a lot of steps, but I have this process: your purpose, your product positioning, and your personality.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: A good purpose explains the change you want to see in the world irrespective of financial gain. It exists on a 10 year frame. Everything with product positioning is pretty malleable, exists on an 18 month frame, whereas your purpose is going to stay the same for 10 years. It's that north star.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: Positioning is the space you occupy in your target customer's mind. You have a positioning problem if I ask 10 of your customers or 10 of your employees what the company does and I get multiple answers. If you can't explain what you do to me in a sentence, you have a positioning problem.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: The positioning statement is: For target audience who has a statement of need or opportunity, our product name is a category that has a benefit. Unlike the old thing they were doing, our product works this other way. This has been around for 40 or 50 years. It's one of the most powerful tools in marketing.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: I believe that great benefits will be the H1 on your homepage and will be what you want someone to tell someone else. If my girlfriend is having drinks with another small business owner, what would I want them to say? 'I just got the Square Stand. It's this cool new register that turns my iPad into a point of sale.'

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: The bar test: pretend to be someone in your target having drinks with someone else in your target and say, 'Hey, I just started using product name. It's this really great category that has a benefit.' If you can say it out loud and it's stuff people would actually say, then you've done a pretty good job.

quotes.speaker: Arielle Jackson
quotes.text: Brands need tension to be interesting. If you tell me we're helpful, we're nice, we're approachable, you've told me nothing. Whereas if you tell me we're really savvy but also really approachable, that's cool. Write statements that say we are X but not Y, where Y is taking X too far. Google is playful but not silly.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: All of a sudden, these are these living organisms that just get better with the more interactions that happen and in many ways I think this is the new IP of every single company and it's a completely different way to build product and to even think about products that think and live and learn.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: Look, I think that software as a primitive is changing and the artifact inside of it is a model alongside the software components itself. And so in many ways I think that software products will all be model forward products, if you will.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: I think that where companies fail is that they're doing AI for AI's sake. They have a ton of projects that they're kicking off at the same time without a blueprint to understand how it actually worked and what their Stack looks like and they aren't treating it like a real investment, and so they don't have the measurement and the observability and the evals all set up.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: I think it's all about the loop, not the lane here. And so I think that whatever function you are, you have to be obsessed with trying to understand the efficiency or the cost of the product, the actual rewards or system design that you're going after, the actual UI, UX, how that actually manifests for agents or people.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: And if you think about getting really good at that loop, I think that is the product, that is the IP, that is the future of every organization and I think feedback becomes continuous and observability becomes the culture, and I think that functions start to blur in future workforces.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: I think that product makers really need to rewire their mindset around this because I think we spend an inordinate amount of time thinking about the UI of something rather than how something composes, how an agent's going to be able to read something. How do you actually get infinite scale?

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: I think that we're approaching this world in which the marginal cost of a good output is approaching zero. And I think when that happens, we're going to see exponential demand for productivity and outputs. And I think that the way that you scale to that is with agents.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: And so I think that when all of that happens, the org chart starts to become the work chart. I think that tasks and throughput become more important than they have been before. I also think that you just don't need as many layers. I think the whole organizational construct might start to look different in a few years.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: And so we think about it as what season are we in? And so a season which is very uncomfortable can be denoted by a set of secular changes that are happening in the industry or that are happening from customers. And so you can think about season one might've been the prototyping of AI and the early GPT work and then it was all around models and reasoning models and now it's the advent of agents.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: I think the other thing is just we try to leave Slack in the system, not just for the unplanned, but for the slope. I think that we have to continuously be thinking about how we're going to disrupt the platform in our thinking and what we need to be investing in to make that possible.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: The number one learning that I had was look like WhatsApp didn't win because it had stickers or stories or dark mode. In fact, I don't even think it had all of those things when it won. It won on a few premises because one was the phone book... It was the reliability and how fast it was... it wasn't the hundreds of features, it was all in the infrastructure and the platform.

quotes.speaker: Asha Sharma
quotes.text: I've learned that optimism is a renewable resource. This company for 50 years has had every reason not to succeed and it has... I think that his ability to generate energy and to use his optimism to renew everybody's dedication to the mission is unbelievable.

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: The impact is only achievable by looking at two sets of variables, a set of variables related to the environment, a set of variables related to your skills, and really breaking down each and understanding what's happening in the environment bit by bit and what's happening with your skills and where are you hindered structurally within the environment.
quotes.context: Explaining his framework for career impact from his legendary blog post on choosing where to work

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: Your manager is the most important variable in the environment, because a great manager who is empathetic, who is aware of what's going on, who is a great communicator, has the ability to move the chess pieces around and to fix some of these for you either immediately or in time. There's no one other than your manager who can really help to increase your scope.
quotes.context: Discussing why people don't leave jobs, they leave managers

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: Communication is the one that tends to be the most impactful. You see this for people who are poor executors but incredible communicators and they seem to continue to rise and rise because they can tell a great story, but when you look under the covers, there's nothing there. So communication for better or worse is one of the most important things.
quotes.context: On the skills side of his Impact = Environment x Skills framework

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: People think about mentorship as like, I have a mentor. I tell them, it's actually better to have a stable of mentors. You want to have three or four. Ideally, you meet with each one of them once a month on a different Friday of the month. So every Friday you're meeting with someone different. If one or two cancel, you still have two people to talk to that month.
quotes.context: Unconventional advice on building your mentor network

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: That is what I call the anti-pattern of what we want to do and I call that identify, justify, execute. Where you identify something, someone says, 'This would be great to build.' And you go pull data to go justify why that would be great to build and then you sink an ungodly amount of time working on it, but it ultimately doesn't succeed.
quotes.context: Introducing the concept of understand work vs the common anti-pattern

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: Is it a better outcome to just ship more faster now, but most of the things aren't impactful? Or is it a better outcome to ship fewer things but really work on making sure that you're shipping them in the best way and de-risking a lot of other things so that a year later your win rate's higher and your velocity is higher?
quotes.context: The counterintuitive lesson that slowing down to understand leads to faster long-term velocity

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: This is the irony of growth, is people think growth is overnight success and it's not. It is a lot of short wins and short-term execution for a longer-term gain and really understanding you have a lot of short terms towards the longer-term outcomes.
quotes.context: Debunking the myth that growth is about overnight success

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: I found this framework, it travels from computer to computer with me and team to team, called managing complex change. It's got five components: vision, skills, incentives, resources, action plan. You need all of those to have change. If you're missing the vision, you end up in confusion. If you're missing incentives, you end up in resistance.
quotes.context: Framework for diagnosing team dysfunction when driving organizational change

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: People talk a lot about product as you're the CEO, and I don't actually fully believe that analogy. If you think about it as a team sport, not everyone's going to be a star player. But not everyone needs to be a LeBron James or Kobe Bryant. You need role players. You need people who feel valued in their role.
quotes.context: Reframing product management from CEO to coach analogy

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: Think about what is your leadership tree. Who have you helped to build up and help to grow? I have people who were on my team in the earlier days who are running growth at Stripe or the CPO at Chief or now running stories at Instagram. Their success is my success. It reinforces that it's your responsibility to coach people up to greatness.
quotes.context: Borrowing the coaching tree concept from college basketball

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: When you're in a hypergrowth product, it's really important to understand who your users are today and what motivates them, but then also to understand who is the next user? Who is the user who could be using this product, but for some reason it doesn't work for them, and understanding who that adjacent user is.
quotes.context: Explaining the adjacent user theory that came from Instagram's hypergrowth

quotes.speaker: Bangaly Kaba
quotes.text: People think that stories was the sole reason why Instagram grew. Story brought us a lot of people, but we literally, our retention doubled over the course of a year and a half. The connections pivot - making sure that people got connected with their friends early on rather than celebrities - changed the way that people perceived the value.
quotes.context: The untold story of Instagram's connections pivot that doubled retention

quotes.speaker: Ben Horowitz
quotes.text: Success is a series of bad decisions. None of the decisions by themselves is that bad, but when you add them up, it's bad. And if you can break psychologically, you can take the sunk cost, then that gets you out of a lot of bad paths. A small good decision may be difficult, but you have to believe it's going to lead to the next one. A lot of success is about that. It's a small thing, a small thing that's hard to do that doesn't seem to have a high impact, but it leads to the next small hard to do thing.
quotes.context: Sharing the pilot's lesson about JFK Jr.'s plane crash - how small bad decisions compound

quotes.speaker: Ben Horowitz
quotes.text: All the things that you perceive that are happening to you that are bad, be it the systems against you or somebody undercuts you or racism or sexism or this or that or the other is very small compared to what you do to yourself. If you believe what people say about you, if you believe what they did to you, then that destroys you. But if you go, 'That's not me,' you can overcome almost anything.
quotes.context: Shaka Senghor's lesson from 19 years in prison - self-beliefs matter more than external obstacles

quotes.speaker: Ben Horowitz
quotes.text: The biggest mistake that you make, the worst thing that you do as a leader is hesitation. And the thing that causes you to hesitate is both decisions are horrible. What happens to you as CEO, it's like, 'Okay, if we rearchitect this product, I kind of know it's not going to get us to where we need to go. But if we rearchitect it, we're going to probably miss all the features, miss the quarter, have trouble raising money.' So both are really bad, and so I'm just going to try to avoid this subject because I don't even want to deal with either of those. And that's the worst thing.
