quotes.text: Self-serve monetization has a cap of about $10,000. That's just how much we're able to process on the credit cards before they start getting flagged and declined by the banks and how much we as consumers and prosumers are even willing to put on our credit card.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Products fundamentally do a really bad job at communicating enterprise-level value prop. They're very good at showing you as a user what you can do. They're terrible at showing what organization actually can benefit out of the solution.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: To understand how sales should be applied in the situation, you need to understand end user's motivation, ability, and permission. A lot of times the end users miss permission of solving enterprise-level problems. There's lots of stakeholders, there's a committee that has to make a decision.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: That organic demand very quickly dries up if you rely on hand-raisers of your champions. If you rely on having enterprise buyers in your user base that are asking to just sign on the dotted line, then you have a very limited ceiling for your growth.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: To have product-led sales means you're going upmarket, period. That means you're going for contract values that are probably over your sales floor, so the minimum that the sales is willing to engage and close, which is traditionally around $15,000.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: In B2B, unfortunately, we've let go of the products having accountability over monetization model. We've gotten into the spiral of product just builds a product and it throws it over the fence to marketing and sales to sell.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: You cannot consider a new product sign-up an MQL in the traditional sense. They're just not there yet. They have a fraction of the enterprise problem that they're solving and they're not ready to buy.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: One of the biggest PQAs is number of users in the company using your product. By the way, the magic number is usually seven. The more time you have seven or more users in the company, there's enough value distributed across multiple people that there might be an enterprise conversation to be had.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Your terms of use pages, your privacy and policy. Nobody cares about it unless they're considering enterprise deal. If you see anybody from account land on your terms of use pages, reach out to that person. More likely than not, you have a buyer on the hook.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: The worst thing that you can do is to say, 'I'm going to do product-led growth,' or, 'I'm going to do product-led sales and I'm going to do it in marketing.' Recipe for disaster. You'll be failure mode within six months because product has to take accountability over selling of the product itself.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: I think we all in tech, and I specifically point a finger at my B2B industry, just got a little bit complacent with revenue ownership from product side. I do think it's catastrophic for us in the long term if we don't fix it.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: You have to fail to learn. You can't just constantly succeed. Success is an output of a lot of failures, but the question is, how much time do you have to fail? And a lot of times we don't realize how many failure cycles we're going to have to go through before we get a success, and that company, or even market, has no time for that.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Growth cannot function without data. If you have 10 users or 10 customers, that's not data, that's a G-sheet with your customers and you don't need a growth team for that. Until you have data that you can actually do an analysis and you can create hypotheses on and you can start applying experimentation, don't even think about growth team.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Growth can amplify great product market fit and growth can help you grow faster once you are already growing. But if you are slowing down and you have issues with either your go-to-market strategy or your core product strategy with your core product market fit, growth is going to be absolutely helpless to do anything.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Never ever once have I seen a rebrand or redesign, especially of UK marketing site produce good performance results. New CMO comes in designing their website or designing the brand as if it was reflection of their personal taste, and oftentimes it's promised with our acquisition is going to go up and it never materializes into anything meaningful.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Benchmarks are usually done on all of the competition, on all of the softwares out there. And the way people define numbers is so different from company to company. Even if you look as something as simple as signups. So taking also any benchmark that is derived from competition and saying, 'This is where we should be,' is also so dangerous because it might not even be applicable depending on how you define the metric.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: There are patterns and there are frameworks, but there's no shortcuts.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Your problem is not unique. I am 99% sure of that. Your problem has been felt by somebody somewhere in probably many, many places and you trying to re-engineer solution is time lost to market and has a huge opportunity cost. Do not start from scratch. It's the worst thing that you can do because you can waste so many cycles on trying to do something that probably has already been solved.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Focusing on these earned channels that you own becomes the outmost priority. And if you don't have them on your growth roadmap, you are going to be in some really big trouble over the next year to two years because your cost of acquisition is only going to go up. Your competition and those channel is only going to go up.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: If every single one of your initiatives that you're doing on growth is an experiment, that's a problem. It's almost like a disease, like a paralyzing disease, that slows down progress, that slows down velocity, that slows down learnings, that creates very terrible consequences to the output that growth teams produce.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Data is good, but data is only good if you have enough of it. So if you have low volume real estate, that is going to take you eight months to reach some sort of answer. Do you really want to test it for eight months? My rule of thumb, if we cannot collect the sample size in the month, we shouldn't test it, period.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: People stop in this age of data, almost rely enough on their element intuition. Experimentation cannot be the way that people make decisions in the company. There's still so much about knowing your user, understanding the market for your brain to connect all of those dots and to know what needs to be an experience that your customers are going to want.

quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.text: Growth teams are often too obsessed about removing friction. If you ever have a line item on your roadmap that says simplified onboarding, please cross it out. It's not going to work because simplifying onboarding is an action. What is the problem that you're solving? You always have a problem of people are confused in it, but people don't know where to go or they get lost in it or they're not educated enough. That is the problem.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: I'm very dedicated to the work and to the teams I'm part of. It's been part of who I am for a long time that I give everything I've got to the job that I'm in. I do the best work I possibly can, less so for myself and my own ambition and more so because I think of myself as being part of a team and so I really need to deliver for that team.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: The dedication piece really isn't about long working hours. It's more about how much I care about excellence. And that might not mean that I work really wild hours or I work weekends. I've actually tried to avoid setting that as an expectation, but more that I hold myself to a very high standard.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: My mother used to describe to me that the last 5% is the 5% that really mattered. And so it is that framing of the extra effort you put into something to make it world-class or to make it excellent. And so I do like to push myself that way and I hope it sets a good example for other people too.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: It shows up for the people who report to me, is one part example setting. So if I don't do it, why would they do it? I treat that very seriously that we should all be held to the same standards. And as a second thing, I give feedback when it's not up to the standard.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: I feel very strongly about setting an example of 'Let's work on this together,' and then through that, help people uplevel themselves so the next time around they know the expectations and they've had help getting there in the past. That's probably happened a thousand times in my career where I jump in with both feet because something needs to be better.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: I would much rather have someone spend the time thinking about what's the conversation we really want to have? Not, 'Could I spend another 20 hours to make it look like everything's perfect in this document?' Instead we really got to the outcome we wanted because we were thoughtful about it and put energy and iteration into making sure we got to that outcome.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: We can't really have any of the other aspects of the culture, including candor, learning, seeking excellence and improvement, freedom and responsibility if you don't start with high talent density.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: If this person on my team came to me and said, 'I'm leaving today, I have a different opportunity,' would I do everything I could to keep them at Netflix? If not, then I should be having that tough conversation about, 'Should you really be here? Are you in the right role?' if I might be a little bit relieved if you said you were leaving.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: At Netflix we try really hard to say we're looking for the new perspective or the person who's actually going to make us stronger as a team. So thinking about additive skills, additive perspectives, people who are going to push our thinking on something. That tends to help us with thinking about talent density because you're constantly introducing people to the team who uplevel.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: We give people the freedom and the space to explore and question things and experiment in a way with solutions. I think that would be very hard if not dangerous if we didn't have a high talent density. It's really not a top down do A, then B, then C.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: Our job is not to tell the story that someone wants to hear with the data or to solve the problem that someone thinks is most important. It's for us to have our own perspective about things. I think that uplevels the whole organization because it means we're able to be truth tellers or to be curious in a way that might not fit if we had a different organizational structure.

quotes.speaker: Elizabeth Stone
quotes.text: While those sound like physical strength, I've found especially endurance sports are much more mental and how you go through the highs and lows and sustain and then coming back from challenge. From the lows I've really learned how to recover and bounce back. Those feel like universally applicable skills.

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: Great marketers learn the audience and learn the product quickly. And sometimes that fresh set of eyes is helpful and you have other experts in house on the audience. But the business model really dictates what marketing does in a big way. By business model I mean, are you doing top down sales? Are you selling the enterprise? Are you doing bottom up product led growth or have a free version?
quotes.context: Explaining why business model experience matters more than industry experience when hiring marketers

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: Forget all the sub-functions that you've heard about in marketing. Forget the product marketing content marketing partner, demand and growth, forget all of it and just think of marketing as you need fuel and you need an engine. Fuel is all the things that you're creating - the content, the words, the design. An engine is how you get it out to the right people.
quotes.context: Introducing the fuel and engine framework to simplify how founders think about marketing

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: Who is your product for? Why is it better? What are the benefits? How does it compare to competitors? If you don't have an answer for those questions, you don't have top performing content and you don't know your positioning and all that stuff, you got a fuel problem. But if you wrote this really great piece of content and I saw it on your website, how are you distributing that? You got an engine problem.
quotes.context: Providing a diagnostic framework to identify whether a startup has a fuel problem or engine problem

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: You want the first marketer to be an expert in one of those three areas - product marketing, content marketing, growth marketing. And you want them to be proficient in another one. But you want them to be able to set strategy and know how to hire contractors across all of them. I call these pi-shaped marketers, not pie like dessert, but pi like 3.14 where the symbol has two vertical lines.
quotes.context: Describing the ideal profile for a first marketing hire - someone with depth in two areas and breadth across all

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: Do they know what high quality looks like? It doesn't always have to be that you've been at a startup that everyone thinks of as really great at marketing, but it is helpful. Some people just have a really high quality bar and really understand what great marketing looks like even if they haven't worked in those companies. But I like to say, has worked somewhere early enough that they could set strategy across all of marketing.
quotes.context: Explaining what to look for when evaluating marketing candidates - exposure to great and early-stage experience

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: They don't understand how all the marketing works together and they don't understand how they built the foundation. It's much different marketing something that already everybody knows what it is or everybody knows the brand, than building something up from scratch. That's just a very different marketing motion, and you need to do a lot of things yourself, you need to be a doer.
quotes.context: Warning against hiring marketers from only large public companies who haven't built marketing from scratch

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: Marketing is really good at accelerating growth and doing that scale one to many. So if you're still in the very well spoke founder led sales, founder led marketing, like I'm doing discovery with each of these potential customers and have to modify my product for them, you don't need a marketer yet. Founders can do a fair amount of stuff and they can use some contractors.
quotes.context: Advising on when to hire a first marketer - only after you have enough product-market fit to scale

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: Product led growth is a misnomer. I think people will do anything they can possibly do to not call marketing marketing. Product led growth really means not as much sales, which means product plus marketing. To me, product led growth means you are going to have a bigger marketing team early on because you're not going to have those sales. Sales is not communicating with customers, so marketing is.
quotes.context: Challenging the common understanding of PLG - arguing it actually requires more marketing investment, not less

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: We had a list of areas of responsibility which is just who owns what. It's not your job title, it's what are the things that you are the DRI for? It doesn't mean you're not going to collaborate with people on those things. This made it really easy to know who to go to. Often what happens with product is they're like, I'm doing a launch, I don't know who I'm supposed to go to, so I'm just going to skip it.
quotes.context: Describing Asana's AOR system that clarified ownership and made cross-functional collaboration easier

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: Marketing comes back to you with the GACCS - goals, audience, creative, channels, stakeholders. And you can weigh in on the channels, the creative has maybe the highest level messaging. You get buy-in early on and then you can go much faster. Then you're not just sharing with product, here's a blog post that I wrote for the launch, and they're like, what? This is the wrong audience.
quotes.context: Explaining the GACCS framework for marketing briefs that enables faster execution through early alignment

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: A lot of what marketing is, is splatergy not strategy - meaning you just throw a bunch of stuff out there. If you're doing a bunch of work and it's a lot of busy work and you want to look busy, but it's not impact focused, that's a problem. The best marketing teams are impact focused. They can tell you what their big bets are - what are the things that can cause step change growth?
quotes.context: Distinguishing between busy work marketing (splatergy) and impact-focused marketing strategy

quotes.speaker: Emily Kramer
quotes.text: If your goal is to write 10 blog posts this month - no, that's not a goal, that's maybe a tactic. The goal should be traffic and the conversion rate from that traffic or the signups that come from that. You shouldn't have activity goals, you should have impact goals. I can get a lot more people to sign up for a product, but they might be really shitty quality.
quotes.context: Warning against activity-based goals in marketing and advocating for impact and conversion-focused metrics

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: We became what a lot of late stage software companies are today, which is a bit bloated. We lost some energy. Our strategy was diluted and unfocused. We're trying to do all the things for all the people.
quotes.context: Reflecting on Intercom's state before his return as CEO, describing how the company lost focus after his departure

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: I'm now of the belief that providing a customer with a highly engaged, instantly available expert, consistent, fast, charismatic, funny, friendly, personal agent available for literally every single customer every minute of the day around the clock is so much more personal than making them wait 2, 3, 4 days for a crappy canned response.
quotes.context: Explaining how he reconciled Intercom's original 'make internet business personal' mission with their pivot to AI agents

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: You betray your intuition in little bits and pieces over the years when the bright spark of your original idea turns into this big, unstoppable, scary corporate beast and a little bit of you dies every single time you go and betray yourself in that way.
quotes.context: Describing how founders compromise their vision over time to placate employees, follow advice, and bring investors along

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: I always believe that that pricing should come from value and not from costs. The cost is our problem. We just had this sense and intuition early on that this thing will get cheaper and it got a lot cheaper.
quotes.context: Explaining Fin's 99-cent-per-resolution pricing model and how they bet on AI costs decreasing

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: It was the type of decision that where I had to practice the professional CEO approach, which is, 'Hey folks, what do you all think? Let's take everyone's input.' Everyone had color beside all of the different options that we may take. Let's make a group decision. I said, 'Sorry, this is what we're doing.' So, I was very dictatorial in that respect.
quotes.context: Describing how he made the decision to focus entirely on customer service instead of maintaining multiple product lines

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: I rewrote the values designed to be a sharp knife to cut out the parts of the company that I just knew wouldn't be effective. So, I said that people must be resilient, that we had very high standards, that we'd work incredibly hard, that shareholder value was the most important thing that we'd optimize for.
quotes.context: Explaining how he deliberately designed new company values to filter out employees who wouldn't thrive in the transformed organization

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: It's my strong belief that great employees and great companies want and are constructed out of a very clear and strong hierarchy where it is the responsibility of the CEO to make brave and hard decisions unilaterally, yes, using their experts as inputs and be responsible for the outcome.
quotes.context: Defending his top-down approach after being asked about the soft coup attempt and pushback from employees

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: There's such a thing as product market fit. There's a thing as founder market fit, there's a thing as founder, product market fit. That's how you're doing it right, but there's also such a thing as employee, founder, product market fit. You have to have the right employees for the type of business you're creating.
quotes.context: Reflecting on the 40% employee turnover during the transformation and why different companies need different types of employees

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: When a founder runs away from their business, it is the ultimate betrayal of their heart and the dream that they have. Now, it's okay to wrap things up and quit, but when you kind of run away, like I kind of had to because I was sick and burned out and kind of disenchanted, I don't know, it didn't feel good.
quotes.context: Being vulnerable about his departure from Intercom due to illness and burnout, and why returning was deeply meaningful

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: You don't have a choice. The story of the technology industry or digital technology is really short and it's punctuated by a small number of things, microprocessors, personal computers, the internet, maybe mobile. Now there's AI. I think AI is bigger than all these things. And if you're not in it, you're about to get kicked out of all of it.
quotes.context: Giving his strongest advice to founders considering AI transformation - that there is no alternative

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: I don't actually generally promote working that hard. I actually think a life well-lived includes taking slow walks in nature where you're not thinking about ARR growth or hiring your chief revenue officer. I'm simply saying that if you want to compete and enjoy success in this age, which means you need to be doing AI, that is the price.
quotes.context: Nuancing his advice about working as hard as young AI companies - acknowledging it's not ideal for a good life but necessary to compete

quotes.speaker: Eoghan McCabe
quotes.text: The interesting thing about 12 years of weekly therapy and spiritual work is that it takes your edges off, but they're all edges that are super counterproductive. All the edges that made you an asshole, got you triggered, miscommunicated or fought back when you were insecure, they take all the edges away then help you see yourself and love yourself so much more for who you are.
quotes.context: Sharing how 12 years of therapy with a CEO coach transformed his leadership by removing counterproductive defenses while preserving his edge

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: MVP is simply for whatever the hypothesis is that we're trying to test, what is the most efficient way to get the validation we need about whether a hypothesis is true or not? Part of a successful test is to understand what are the demands of customers in our market.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: The number one lesson of the scientific method is if you can't fail, you can't learn. And so if you set yourself up in a position where psychologically you can't admit that something didn't work, you can't learn. That really is the essence of MVP.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: Far worse than having a startup fail is to be in a company that won't die, a zombie undead company that you hate but you can't leave. We're having a mental health crisis among founders that's not talked about enough. Building a company you hate, that becomes a maligned force in the world - that's way, way worse.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: The pivot is really about learning. Anchored in what you've learned and yet connected. Oftentimes the vision is discovered more than chosen in these stories. It's really much more about having the courage to see the world as you think it ought to be and then dance with that wherever it takes you.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: If you're asking whether you should pivot or not, you probably know the answer already. If you have had product-market fit you would not have time for this. When it's working there's no time for naval gazing. The whirlwind of it is so amazing and so horrible at the same time. If you're not sure, you're sure.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: AI is going to force us to take governance issues seriously. At the end of the day, AI is a management technology. We're training machine intelligence and transmitting values to it - those are going to be our organizational values. Tech has severely underinvested in creating governance structures to have those values explicitly embodied in the organization.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: No individual person can ever make promises on behalf of an organization - it's a category error. You're replaceable. Organizations are actually alive. They are superorganisms with their own soul and their own life. Founders don't create them, we birth them. We don't own them, we nurture them.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: What is the probability that Google will file its next quarterly report on time? 100%, as certain as the sun will rise. What is the probability they would be complicit in something harmful? 'Probably not.' We have built a massive apparatus to make sure certain things happen. Companies are really good at things they care about.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: My view is that what it means to be a for-profit company, we've gotten it wrong. Making a profit is actually about maximizing human flourishing. Philip Morris has great ESG scores - how can that possibly be right? We need to build companies where human flourishing is the thing at the beating heart.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: Every founder wants the one weird trick. There's no one weird trick. You want to do the right thing, it is a relentless and constant process. We need to build a structure of the company so that at every level, at every decision, somebody in the room feels like they have a fiduciary duty to do the right thing.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: First principles thinking has two components. A lot of my work is just descriptive - giving a name to a thing that already happens. Pivot is just what it's called when you change strategy but keep fidelity to the vision. It needs a name because we do it all the time. The prescriptive parts are just deductive logic from there.

quotes.speaker: Eric Ries
quotes.text: It took us 10 years to build the MVP for LTSE. MVP doesn't necessarily mean cheap or low quality. It's just whatever your hypothesis is, whatever you actually believe is going to work, let's put that thing to the test. As little as necessary - not as little as possible.

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: Speaking as a manager, and I've talked to hundreds of managers, very few people go and ask their manager, 'What can I do to help you? What do you need?' And so just asking sets you apart, and it begins to build a relationship that we're on the same team, that I'm here as a part of your organization to make you successful, not just myself.
quotes.context: Explaining step two of The Magic Loop framework for career advancement

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: The reason this works is managers help those who help them. It's just human nature. We all do that. Generally, they're very open to meeting you halfway and saying, 'Sure, I need this. We can rearrange it. We can find a way to meet your goals over time.'
quotes.context: Describing why The Magic Loop works - the principle of reciprocity with managers

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: The point of this loop is it's in your control. It is true that a good manager would do all those things I just mentioned, but not all managers are good and some of them need help. You can be upset that your manager isn't perfect, but move on from that and take control of your own situation.
quotes.context: Emphasizing personal agency in career development regardless of manager quality

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: The difference between a senior manager and a director is how you lead and the work you're doing. You can get as far as senior manager by being really strong in your function and being really good at getting things done. As a director, and as a VP beyond that, it becomes much more about influence, coordination with others, and letting go of being in all the details yourself.
quotes.context: Explaining why senior managers get stuck and what changes at director level

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: I often reference the book by Marshall Goldsmith, What Got You Here Won't Get You There. Not only because it's a great book classically on this problem, but because the title tells the story. All the great traits that got you to this one level won't get you to the next level where you're more expected to be thinking in strategic terms, thinking longer term.
quotes.context: Describing the behavioral change required to move from senior manager to director

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: You don't need that much time. Two hours is great, but you only need two hours once a month. People think invention takes all this time. The thing is once you have one good idea, it often takes years to express that. You don't need very many good ideas to be seen as tremendously inventive.
quotes.context: Demystifying invention - it requires dedicated time but not as much as people think

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: The biggest thing I see particularly at higher levels is people talk about what they have done but not why it mattered. They don't talk about the impact. A leader is not hiring someone to just do work. They're hiring someone because they have a problem or a need. If you can show them the things you've done that have made a difference, that makes you more of a leader.
quotes.context: Advice on standing out in interviews - emphasize business impact not just activities

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: So the first thing I did was I owned it. I said, 'Yes, it's not working. It's my fault. I will deal with it.' I took ownership. And the second thing I did was start updating him very proactively. Even though Jeff had sort of lost trust in me, given that he agreed with the plan, he was willing to give me 60 minutes. I was buying life one hour at a time.
quotes.context: How he handled failing Jeff Bezos during the Amazon App Store launch disaster

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: It's really easy to flame. He had been flaming me, writing angry emails. Angry emails are easy. Sitting three feet from someone and being angry with them face-to-face is hard. And when faced with, I can either start ranting at this person who reports to me, or I can say something nice, he chose to say something nice, and that rebuilt our relationship.
quotes.context: Reflecting on his in-person meeting with Jeff Bezos after the App Store failure

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: Two years later, I was promoted to vice president. So even though I had failed the CEO on this very public launch where he was very definitely mad at me, I re-earned the trust, I showed I had learned the lessons of how to launch more reliably without outages, and I was promoted. If I can get away with publicly failing one of the richest and most famous inventors on earth, you can dig out of any hole.
quotes.context: The outcome of his App Store failure - proving recovery from major mistakes is possible

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: Bias for action says speed matters in business and many decisions are reversible. And so it's important to go faster. I think people don't understand that in a competitive environment, being right is good, but being quick is necessary. Because if there are 10 startups working on an idea, some will gamble, make bad gambles, and go out of business. But some will gamble and make an early bet and be right.
quotes.context: Explaining Amazon's bias for action principle and why speed matters

quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.text: With working from home, we've only been doing that for a few years since the pandemic began. Which one is likely to have more opportunity for improvement? There's so many things we haven't explored with remote work. The people who say, 'Back to the office, it's because we know it works,' well we know what it is, but I have so much more faith in the opportunity to improve the remote experience.
quotes.context: Contrarian view on return-to-office - remote work has far more room for innovation

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: What I learned there is that actually, you're trying to deliver an end experience, and product, and story to your viewers, to your audience. It doesn't actually matter what's real. It matters what you see on the screen. It matters the emotion that it creates, the story that it creates, how it reinforces all of the other pieces.
quotes.context: Discussing what he learned at Pixar about focusing on end results rather than technical accuracy

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: You can't do homework, you can't do exercises, you can't do fake stuff. You have to work on real products at real companies with real customers, with real data to get better at product management. So any kind of training, mentorship, reading, et cetera that you do is just a layer on top of that. The real acceleration happens from doing it and getting more reps.
quotes.context: Explaining why PM skills can only be developed through real-world experience, not simulations

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: What are the problems you give a junior or brand new PM? Known problem, known solution. 'Please work with engineering and design to deliver that thing on time, and then tell us what happened.' So it's like a very tightly constrained problem. As you level up, then some of these things become more unknowns.
quotes.context: Describing how PM responsibilities evolve from known-known problems to unknown-unknown problems

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: For products that had a high bar to activation, sometimes more set up and higher friction, good friction could actually help those customers be successful. There are other kinds of products that are high-intent where they know what they need to do to have simple actions where lowering friction might be the right thing.
quotes.context: Sharing a counterintuitive insight from Instacart about when higher friction in onboarding can improve outcomes

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: You can't just do the work. You have to actually communicate the work. You have to talk about what you're doing, what you've generalized, what you've learned so that you can hit the next step, which is scale your opportunities.
quotes.context: Explaining the importance of communication in the PM learning loop for career advancement

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: You got to be doing this stuff, but often, somebody needs to see it. The scale opportunity piece of the step often requires someone from outside to notice that you're doing something really well and trust you with a bigger opportunity. I think of this as sponsorship, not mentorship.
quotes.context: Distinguishing between mentorship (day-to-day guidance) and sponsorship (trusting you with bigger opportunities)

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: I call this going two stack levels up, two stack levels down in terms of your curiosity and what you understand, and also, knowing what's to the left and what's to the right. You should understand your boss's priorities and your boss's boss's priorities. Eventually, that means you have to know what the board is thinking.
quotes.context: Framework for how PMs should understand context both above and below their role

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: I always think of it as trying to build a mental model of how the company works, and what's important to it, and what's the equation, so to speak, or what are all the boxes, and then figure out like, 'How is my work creating leverage in that?' I find that when you are thinking at that level, people tend to trust you.
quotes.context: Explaining how building a mental model of company mechanics creates trust from leadership

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: You have to shift from doer to editor is the way I think about it. You have to shift from, 'My job is to do the work,' to, 'My job is to make the work better. My job is to plus the work, to review the work, to help other people solve problems.'
quotes.context: Key mindset shift required when transitioning from IC to manager role

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: I actually think of it as start thinking in terms of being lazy, 'What's the least amount of work I could do to make this thing as good as possible?' versus, 'How do I do as much work as possible to make sure it's great?' So it's like looking in terms of ROI.
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice for new managers to maximize impact through minimal intervention

quotes.speaker: Fareed Mosavat
quotes.text: As a leader, you now own the business outcome, the impact, the delivery, not some sub-problem or known answer. You have to define the solutions. You have to talk about how many people you need to do them, and you need to figure out what do you need from the rest of the organization to do that.
quotes.context: Describing the fundamental shift in responsibility when becoming a product leader

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: If you do the hard path and it doesn't work, actually you still win because you've now done something hard. You've probably worked with smart people, you've learned something along the way that is valuable.

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: Everyone says, 'Oh yeah, work hard and do more hours when you're young, whatever.' I'm like, what if you just did more per minute?

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: It is the most underutilized management tool in engineering, bar none. It is just not used as much as it could be.

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: Tobi famously built a lot of Shopify paired programming, and what he would do is he would actually set a timer and him and the CTO Cody would pair program for one hour. And if they did not finish the problem in one hour, they would delete all the code and they would keep the tests and they would start over.

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: What better time to rewrite code than right after you've written it because you now know the problem domain? And by the way, it sounds like a waste of time. It sounds like I'm just deleting code but the reason is that code lives a long time. Code is a liability.

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: If you're doing something monumental, I don't know, you're doing a reorg or something, right? You can do it the slow way. 'Let's sit down, and plan, and roll it out.' And it's probably six months in most companies. Shopify, this is a week or two. You sit down, you're like, 'Hey, this is the bones of it.' But then, it's going to start leaking. So we just launch it.

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: Sitting with Tobi, he's like, 'You guys are thinking about it wrong.' He goes, 'How long would it take to build NFT gating?' I'm like, 'I don't know. Two, three weeks.' He goes, 'Now, how long would it take to build a platform layer, which exposes APIs so anyone could build NFT gating in one hour?' I'm like, 'I don't know. Two, three months.' He goes, 'Do that.'

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: I don't know why is everybody getting so crazy, because what I want to see is GitHub Copilot deleting 1 million lines of code. That's when you know we're actually at this point where this is close to an engineer.

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: The more you can simplify, the much easier everything becomes, resiliency, performance, reliability, maintainability, all the illities become much, much, much easier when the code base is simple.

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: I think if you don't have two or three big projects that are on fire, you're probably not pushing hard enough because you're not really trying things that are outside of your... If everything's going well, are you really taking the risks you need to be taking?

quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.text: People feel like the comfort gives you stability, and really the uncomfort gives you stability because now you're constantly learning and that makes you more robust against things that could come across.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: The job is to delight customers. Like Peter Thiel, his book, From Zero to One. The job of an entrepreneur at the beginning is just to find out something that's 10X better. Delight is trying to work in that magnitude.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: I'll bet my paycheck that within a week, Blockbuster's going to put a happy family on their couch, too. And this is the problem of doing things that are easy to copy. So in the long term, if you can delight customers and create hard to copy advantage, things are just a lot better.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: I mainly was just trying to find these high level theories and hypotheses that I hoped would delight in hard to copy, margin enhancing ways. The reality was, we'd have 10 ideas and probably six of them would fail, but a lot of value in the three or the four that worked.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: You sort of want to get to this place where you don't really care, and your sort of true North is okay, how can we best serve our customer? And that's what I really love about that particular model.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: If you find an idea that only works for 2% of your customers, now you're creating complexity, one more thing to choose. As a rule, I never used rules as thumbs, but these two percenters, I would kill them. If I launched something and it was only 2% we'd, we called it scraping the barnacles, just get rid of it.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: As product managers, we feel like every decision we make is high stakes. It's good occasionally to think about, hey, what's the magnitude? And then, is it reversible? Amazon calls those two-way door decisions. It's reversible. The one way door, those are the bigger deal.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: I would just text my pals, and they would just give me the data. That's amazing insight, just by having peers in the business that you talk to, which this is the behavior that I want everybody out there engaged in. I call it building your personal board of directors.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: The first rule of thumb is, don't ask a person to be your mentor. That's really awkward. First, identify them. Say, this is a person I think that could be helpful to me. And then, find ways to be helpful. Everybody needs help. Everybody, everybody, everybody.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: I just need you to force rank these three factors for me: growth, engagement, and monetization. And I need the two of you to agree. Growth is basically year over year customer growth. Engagement is how I think about product quality. A more engaging product is a better product.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: These are the kinds of fundamental misalignments that can wreck startups. I'm not saying that one or the other was right or wrong, but as leaders in the organization, we've got to get some of the basic stories straight, including how do we fundamentally prioritize growth versus engagement versus monetization?

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: When I would join a new company, I would give myself two weeks to develop the product strategy for that company, which is a little outrageous, but I would just do it fast. I would develop the SWAG, but then I'd go to one person. 'Hey, this is my best thinking, what do you think?' And of course, they had been there for four years. They were much smarter than I, and they would refine my thinking.

quotes.speaker: Gibson Biddle
quotes.text: Begin your day with intent. What are the three to five things I'm hoping to do today? Second, minimize meetings. That sucks the life out of everybody, including you. Spend a lot of time with your customers. Find a balance between doing and thinking. Most of us do, do, do. Occasionally stop and ask yourself, what should I really be doing right now?

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: I basically became a part-time PM for them nights and weekends. Within three months this thing grew big enough and that became Google AdSense. It's very important to do a core job really well at any company, but it's equally important to have curiosity and be open to serendipity. Great careers are built by knowing a lot of people doing great work so they know and want you on their teams, and just waiting for serendipity and then seizing it and jumping.
quotes.context: Describing how he accidentally created Google AdSense by wandering around the office at 6pm and asking engineers what they were working on

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: I could never ever imagine that I could be passionate about payments ever in a million years, but the environment of the company Square was so infectious and great and the culture was so good that we even made working on payments... I always think of, not what you're working on but what problem you're solving. I get much more energy from personally solving problems that affected a small business or basically people or small business that I can relate to.
quotes.context: Explaining how he found passion in unexpected places and why customer segment matters more than the problem domain

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: It's very important for founders to really live and breathe the mission themselves in an authentic way. If people are smart, and I think you've got to really honestly think if this person is constantly talking about revenue and trying to convince you that you're going to get wealthy or they're going to get... That's not the kind of founder that's going build a really large company. They care about winning. They will win and money will come, but it's a side product.
quotes.context: Describing what to look for in founders when deciding where to work - authentic mission over money

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: I would much rather be the number two or number three person at the leader in a space, than the top person. Google versus Yahoo. I saw even if you're the VP of product at Yahoo or the head of product at Yahoo versus a ICPM at Google, you probably want to be the ICPM at Google. I bet you all day long. Yahoo is a great company, but Google is just a different caliber and different class.
quotes.context: Explaining why working at winning companies matters more than titles, using Google vs Yahoo as example

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: One of the most interesting things I've realized is there are multiple paths to greatness. Google would be technical. Facebook was very growth focused. Square was very design focused. DoorDash by nature is more operational. I think there are multiple paths to greatness, but I think the founder and market fit in terms of even the type of company that's needed is very strong. Founders have to be authentic to themselves.
quotes.context: Comparing the different DNA of successful companies he's worked at and why founder authenticity matters

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: The product itself ideally needs to have some remarkability. It needs to be better than anything else that solves that pain point along a few dimensions that really matter. A good metric is that 40 to 50% of your new customers should ideally come from organic channels and 50% from paid. If 90% come from paid, that means at some point that the music is going to stop.
quotes.context: Explaining why products need organic growth and word-of-mouth, not just paid acquisition

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: The right time for PMs to join the company is about eight to 10 engineers or so. The role of the PM is actually to be the liaison between the founder, founders and the engineering team. And so it needs to be someone that the founders trust and the engineering team trusts and also they know how the founders and the engineering team work. Many times if you bring a PM from the outside with a completely different process, many times the organ can be rejected by the body.
quotes.context: Explaining when and how to hire your first PM - convert an internal engineer, analyst, or designer

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: The biggest one I think is, the founder becomes too tactical and disempowers their team. I think the founder thinks they know what customers want. They basically just tell the engineers what to build. And I think that leads to teams that are basically tactically just shaping feature after feature without truly solving problems. That leads to the culture of what is called a feature factory, where product teams basically are very proud of shaping feature after feature without truly knowing how much impact the feature has.
quotes.context: Describing the biggest mistake founders make in product development that creates a feature factory culture

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: Engineers are by far the most expensive resources in the company. By far. And if you think of it that way, then if you're not caring and feeding and not leveraging this amazing most expensive resource, well, that's a crime. Do I have the bandwidth to sit with them and present the right problems, talk to customers, figure out the right sequencing, the right prioritization of problems to work on? And if you're not able to do that, you've got to have someone who can do that full time.
quotes.context: Making the case for when you need a PM by framing engineers as your most expensive resource

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: In order to hire, if you want to have a playbook for hiring good leaders or strong leaders for any function, look at best of class companies or companies that are best of class at that function in the similar space. You don't hire the person, the head of marketing at these companies. You hire the person who's reporting to them, the lieutenant. You just literally go through that company and pick out the people.
quotes.context: Sharing his famous hiring playbook - hire lieutenants from best-in-class companies, not the heads

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: I'm most opposed to director and VP titles. Because those are the titles that lead to the most contention in the company, that lead to the most conflict, that lead to the most disgruntlement. I was meeting with a 25 person company today and that CEO told me, 'I need to hire a general counsel instantly.' Do not give the general counsel title at a 25 person company because the person at a 250 person company is going to be very different. You might still want to retain this person, you just don't want them to be the general counsel.
quotes.context: Explaining his strong opinion on delaying director/VP titles as long as possible at startups

quotes.speaker: Gokul Rajaram
quotes.text: I strongly believe that great founders create new markets themselves, or they pivot. With my check, the biggest mistakes I made early on were sins of omission. I much more care about sins of omission because you can only lose one X your money. But for me, the relationship with the person, I don't want to lose that. It's an optionality for me to invest in not just this company, but in every other company they start. Folks who are unsuccessful the first time around, but then use those learnings to start a company in the same or similar space and then succeed.
quotes.context: Explaining his founder-centric angel investing philosophy and why he regrets passing on investments

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: People could be more full stack. Imagine a designer that can ship a fully baked product, a product manager that can prototype and ship to production. We shouldn't put limits on ourselves and what we can build, and what we can ship, and what we can dream about making possible on these web surfaces.
quotes.context: Discussing how AI tools like v0 enable people to become more full-stack and remove traditional role limitations

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: A lot of the programming jobs to be done that used to be specializations, I think, are going away, in a way. They're translation tasks. Knowing how things work under the hood is going to be very important for you because you're going to be able to influence the model and make it follow your intention a lot better.
quotes.context: Explaining which programming jobs AI will replace (translation tasks) versus what skills remain valuable (understanding how things work)

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: Taste, sometimes I think we think of as this inaccessible thing that, 'Oh, that person was born with taste.' I see it as a skill that it can develop. I think is extremely important to try lots of products. We have one of our internal operating principles as increasing exposure hours. Try to quantify how much time you expose yourself to watching how people use your products and you'll develop that muscle.
quotes.context: Answering how to build taste in product development, emphasizing it's a learnable skill through exposure

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: We need to stop talking about AI at some point. I just see a future where AI becomes synonymous with software. We build software and we use software to build software.
quotes.context: Closing thoughts on AI's future - it will just become part of normal software development

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: How many product builders are people with aspirations of building products exist? My back of the napkin, minimum calculation is a hundred million. Slack has about a hundred million monthly active users. A lot of those people are building digital products. They talk to one another about what they would want to see in the world.
quotes.context: Explaining the TAM expansion opportunity - from 5 million developers to 100 million potential builders

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: v0 inverts that. The Git commit is you go into the chat and say, 'Please change the color of this button. And when I click it, save this form to a database.' And so you're starting with the intent and the output is the code.
quotes.context: Explaining how v0 inverts the traditional development workflow - intent comes first, code comes second

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: My number one guidance or piece of advice I would give to any startup founder was, 'Create a lot of opportunities for people to give you feedback inside the product.' When you're building AI products, it's a constant stream of user feedback. It's going to be hard to compete with something that has such a tight feedback loop with users.
quotes.context: Discussing the competitive advantage of AI products - they create tight feedback loops that improve the product constantly

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: A great product is made up of a thousand little details and so you're never really done. There's a humility that comes from the process. When you say yes, it's like adopting a puppy. A feature is like adopting a puppy. It grows into a beast that you have to take care of, and it's very demanding and loving. But also it's a lot, and poops everywhere.
quotes.context: Explaining why product quality requires obsession and why saying no to features is critical

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: The model output more accessible code than what I wrote. It follows the accessibility guidelines that the web standards consortiums put out better than I did, because it just knows everything.
quotes.context: Sharing an anecdote about v0 generating more accessible code than he (an expert engineer) wrote, demonstrating AI's comprehensive knowledge

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: Developing eloquence and your linguistic ability I think is going to be very important. Your ability to steer the model with your words into those references, into those inspirations, is going to be very important. The difference between knowing that word and not knowing it is getting that style into that beautiful thing you created.
quotes.context: Discussing essential skills for the AI era - eloquence and knowing the right words to prompt effectively

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: The most profound one is that conversations between product builders and their customers will be mediated by these zero links, these artifacts. The idea that when we talk, we would not have the power to make those ideas a reality, it seems like an L to me. I would love to see people constantly live in the product, be in the design, spend time tuning and trying out new ideas.
quotes.context: Describing the future of product development where ideas can immediately become prototypes during conversations

quotes.speaker: Guillermo Rauch
quotes.text: v0 is making you such a powerful generalist that you can step out of your comfort zone of like, 'Well, my job was to do only this.' You can just create. Us giving permission to people to build and ship things is part of that cultural backdrop that makes these things possible.
quotes.context: Explaining how AI tools like v0 enable people at Vercel to step outside traditional role boundaries and create

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: Certainly every software product in my opinion, has to be refounded because AI is such a paradigm shift, it's not even just like the shift from desktop to mobile or on-prem to cloud where that was more like a very one time and somewhat predictable change in form factor.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: It's actually now also hard to taste the soup without participating in at least some part of creating the soup. Meaning with AI, you can kind of look at the final product and say, okay, this feels right or not, but I think to really understand the solution space of what's possible, you have to be in the details.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: I take pride in being the number one most expensive in inference cost user of Airtable AI, not just within our own company, but I think for a long time I was globally across all our customers. I mean, I'm extremely intentionally wasteful.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: The value versus the actual cost of AI when applied greedily but smartly, it's a crazy ratio. And more people should be aggressively throwing compute cycles at these very high value problems.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: We did this recent reorg where now we have what I call the fast thinking group, which officially is called AI platform, but it really means we want to just ship a bunch of new capabilities on a near weekly basis. And then separately, we have the slow thinking group, and that's not meant to be better or worse. It's literally like you need fast and slow thinking in the common sense to operate as a human.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: If you were literally founding a new company from scratch with the same mission, how would you execute on that mission using a fully AI native approach? And if you can't really introspect and say I'm better off doing this with the pieces that I have, then I think you should sell. You should find a buyer for that company and then go and start the next carnation of it.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: If anyone wants to just literally block out a day or frankly even a week and have the ultimate excuse, you could say that I told you to do it. If you want to cancel all your meetings for a day or for an entire week and just go play around with every AI product you can find that you think could be relevant to Airtable, go do it.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: What I found is that it really does become more about individual attitude and maybe some polymathism. There's a strong advantage to any of those three roles who can kind of cross over into the other two, like the hybrid unicorn types.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: I would actually go further and say I think you need to get decently good at all three. There's just a minimum baseline of if you're any one of those roles, you need to be minimally good at the other two, and then you can go deeper into your own specialty.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: The best way to innovate on the product is not incrementally split over all these different little surface areas, but actually to have a bigger, more step function vision of how this product needs to make a leap, or what's the next big act of the product or reinvention of the product.

quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.text: Don't step away from the details that both you love. If your passion is building product and product design, even if it feels like at times the company needs to do all this other stuff like scale up, don't lose the essence of the thing that you love doing and that really made this product happen.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: We call it sugar-coated broccoli. People don't want to eat the broccoli but people like sugar, so give them the sugar then hide the broccoli inside of it.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: Sense of maturation is you don't see the world just from your perspective but from outside your perspective. At tech, we were young. Took us multiple years. It hit your head straight into the wall to realize that. People just don't care.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: Building for something you want the world to have is building for your value. You have some taste. You have some aesthetic. You have some values. You want the world to have more of that. They are different energy. Building for value it's more lasting and more fulfilling.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: You're building too much for your own self and value without realizing at the end of the day, if you're building a product and tool has to be used by others, you need to create a balance. Too much of yourself, then there's no users. Then you're just doing our project. And too much for a business, you're building a commodity.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: You can create progress through better abstractions. And that thing compounds faster, can catch up to all the things you build much quicker than you ever thought. Humans are not good at thinking in terms of abstraction or exponentials. We're thinking in terms of linearly. If you just reset it and you find a better way to do it, you can get all the thing you have to some cost recovered really quickly.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: Internally we use the metaphor that Notion's a small bus. The bus, the smaller the bus, it's easier to turn corners, easier to accelerate, easier to maneuver. The bigger the bus it is, bigger the boat or bigger the bus, slow down. And as a leader in the company, you decide who sit around you on the bus seats. That dictates how fast our overall bus moves.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: We name our conference room after timeless tools in history. iPhone's obvious one, original Macintosh, various different form of chairs, Lamy's 2000 pens, Toshiba rice cookers. Because software, and especially tech, it's every six months, every 12 months cycle. We don't think enough about creating something that lasts. I care creating something that at least the form factor lasts longer than 18 month.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: Internally, our company philosophy called crafts and values. Craft is your skill set, your taste. Value is your personal value and how do you see the world. Craft is about apply your value to some technical know-how and to make more clever trade-offs to create something new and useful and just keep doing that.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: There's no free lunch. You don't get something for free. You have to give up something. I always feels like AI language model feels like a new type of wood. It feels like aluminum. It's a new type of material. Mass air travel wasn't available until aluminum become cheap enough that people can make airplanes that support this at cost.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: Notion, we call Notion is Lego for software. We ship non-Lego pieces into our product. That's a realization. If you create this thing called a product or business, you attract people are value aligned to it. Then if you're trying to optimize too much on this competition revenue side of things, forced to introducing something anti-your-value, then the system, it's like there's organ rejection with your employees, with your customers.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: Only hardcore Lego fans care about Lego bricks. Most people care about Lego boxes. And they actually want the Lego box to be ready-made. When you unpack the box, the set is there for you. That's what we're learning a lot, especially move up market. There's this term that took me a while to learn. It's called solutions.

quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.text: The tools are extensions of us. And once they extend us, once we shape them, once we bring them to world, they can come back to shape us. One of my favorite quotes like the Marshall MacLean quotes, 'We shape our tools. Then after, our tools shape us.'

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: We run a very different kind of business. We are focused on efficiency, we're not focused on growth. We think that constraints, simplicity, small teams actually are where it's at, and keep us honest, and allow us to do great work for our customer base.
quotes.context: Explaining why 37signals has 75 employees while competitors have 1500-3000, yet similar customers and profitability

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: We build products with two people at a time. Every feature we work on is two people, one programmer, one designer, and they have a maximum of six weeks to deliver. So we don't get stuck in these big huge projects, with meetings with 18 people, and slow decision-making, and indecision, and complexity.
quotes.context: Describing how 37signals builds features - small teams with tight time constraints

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: For me, it's really about, would I want to do this again? If the answer is, 'Yeah, that was enjoyable. I enjoyed that. That was worthwhile. I'm glad I did that. I'd like to do that again,' then it was successful.
quotes.context: Defining success differently - not by metrics or revenue, but by enjoyment and wanting to repeat the experience

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: We don't have financial goals. We don't have OKRs or KPIs. I don't have revenue targets. I don't have growth targets. It's just, at the end, 'Did we make more than we spend? We did. Then the things we did this year were worth it.'
quotes.context: Explaining his anti-metrics philosophy - no OKRs, KPIs, or growth targets, just profitability

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: I'm so sick of the startups. Starting a business is actually way easier than staying in business. Literally tomorrow, I can start a new business. But, are you going to be there in two years? Staying is harder than starting. So I'm here to celebrate stay ups.
quotes.context: Coining the term 'stay up' vs 'startup' - emphasizing that longevity is harder and more valuable than starting

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: You don't need to outdo the competition, it's expensive and defensive. Underdo your competition. We need more simplicity and clarity.
quotes.context: Contrarian advice about competition - don't try to do more, do less but better

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: Independence is the root of all the things we're able to do. We want to be entrepreneurs and to me, that means working for yourself. The moment you go out and take money or have these big obligations, you end up working for someone else.
quotes.context: Explaining why independence (no investors) is the foundational principle that enables everything else at 37signals

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: We don't have a multi-year plan. I don't even have a one-year plan. I don't even have a six-month plan or a quarter. We think about everything we're going to do every six weeks. We're very much an in-the-now company, making it up as we go.
quotes.context: Explaining his anti-planning philosophy - no long-term plans, only 6-week cycles

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: I think the further out you plan, the less you know about the decisions you're making. People end up doing things they don't want to do because they said they were going to do them. Obligations in the future, I think, are quite dangerous.
quotes.context: Explaining why long-term planning is harmful - it creates obligations that lead to unhappiness

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: I almost would be embarrassed by what someone would come in and look at, and go, 'Oh my God, you guys are missing so many opportunities here.' I'd be like, 'Yeah, I know. I know we are, but I'm totally fine with it.'
quotes.context: Acknowledging they intentionally miss many growth opportunities (multiple pricing tiers, enterprise versions, etc.) and being okay with it

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: We don't say, 'If this gets 20,000 users, then it's a success.' I don't know. We don't care. It doesn't even matter. We're making it anyway, and we're going to see what's going to happen. The market will tell us what happens. I'll just wait to find out.
quotes.context: Explaining their approach to launches - no success metrics, just make it and see what happens

quotes.speaker: Jason Fried
quotes.text: That's pride, though. We want to be proud of the work that we did. If I'm not for me first, it's hard to be for someone else. We want to make things that we're proud of, that are unique, that bring something new to the world that doesn't exist.
quotes.context: Explaining their product philosophy - pride in craft first, market success second

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: Management is just about having an outcome. You have a north star, you have a vision, and you're just trying to figure out how to use the resources that you have to get that thing done. Used to be people, but now it's basically models and different models have different strengths. You have to assemble the Avengers so that you can use the right tools for the right purposes.
quotes.context: Explaining how management principles apply directly to working with AI agents and models

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: Defining the goal and defining the outcome and being really, really crystal clear on what does success look like is the first skill. Different people may have different pictures of what success looks like. How do we get even more specific so that we know without question whether we've hit it or not. This is actually a really, really difficult problem.
quotes.context: Explaining why clarity of outcomes is the most important skill for working with AI and teams

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: AI allows me to do many of those jobs myself. Now, I'm not going to do them at the PhD or the highest 1%, 10% level, but if I was at the zero or 10th percentile, it can certainly get me even today very quickly up to the 60th, 70th. We need to dissolve the boundaries of these traditional roles. Call ourselves builders. I'd love for us to get to the world where that's the title.
quotes.context: Describing how AI empowers individuals to transcend traditional role boundaries

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: I don't actually think a lot of the fast-growing companies are using data well at this point. Traditionally things just didn't grow that fast. These companies are totally getting by on just good instincts and good vibes. But what always happens is eventually things stop growing. Growth does not happen forever. And usually when growth stops, that's when you start to see the power of good observability.
quotes.context: Contrarian take on how fast-growing AI companies succeed initially without data infrastructure

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: What you really want is you want to diagnose with data and treat with design. Data is not a tool that's going to tell you what you should build or what the solution is. But it can tell you if you have a problem and where that problem or opportunity might be. You still need to go back and undergo a very creative process to figure out what's the best way to solve that.
quotes.context: Sharing the perfect framework for balancing data and design that she and her co-founder use

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: Management is really about this idea of be sturdy while being flexible. I think about this metaphor a lot of the willow tree. The willow tree is a very sturdy tree. It can survive a lot of storms, disasters, et cetera, but it's also very flexible. The branches are very, very flexible, and that's in some ways what allows it to be very sturdy.
quotes.context: Describing the essential balance managers need in times of rapid change and uncertainty

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: I'm a big believer that every strength is its own weakness, and every weakness is a strength. There's no such thing as you're going to somehow get every dimension to be 100%. We can kind of look at you in infinite dimensions. Each of our profiles is very unique, it's like a fingerprint. None of these dimensions are you entirely. Somebody can give you feedback or you can have room to improve, and that's not who you are.
quotes.context: Introducing the dimensionality framework for self-awareness and managing personal development

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: Feedback is essentially trying to put your hypotheses and test them against reality. I'm going to ask you for feedback and you're going to give me a gift. It'll be a gift of reflecting something back of what you see that I can't see. Just like if I have a leaf in the back of my head, I can't see that. That is what feedback is. It is essentially reflection back.
quotes.context: Reframing feedback as a gift that helps calibrate our self-perception to reality

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: It's very difficult for managers to convey purpose if you don't have conviction yourself. Watching your conviction is really important. Sometimes what new managers don't pay attention to enough is what is their true belief. If you don't really believe in what you're doing or you're just parroting the thing that got passed through the organization, it's very hard to be effective or hold that vision and purpose.
quotes.context: Explaining why managers must develop genuine conviction rather than just executing orders

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: I think if you start thinking adversarially like 'my getting better outcomes has to come at the expense of somebody else losing something,' it's very difficult to be successful. If you say, 'Look, actually, my job is to figure out how to create win-wins,' a lot of things get easier. That has to be a collaboration. If it's not win-win and you could be wrong, that would actually be great information because then maybe we can go back and find a way to make it win-win.
quotes.context: Describing win-win thinking as fundamental to effective management and difficult conversations

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: I believe that there's infinity in every direction. If my kids say something like going outside is boring or taking a walk is boring, my general response will be, 'Well, it's because you're not seeing the infinity that's in that direction.' Even something really mundane like staring at a blank wall, you can make that actually deeply, deeply interesting if you can find the thing that is deep, and rich, and infinite in that direction.
quotes.context: Sharing her contrarian philosophical worldview that applies to work and life

quotes.speaker: Julie Zhuo
quotes.text: Emotional regulation is still really, really important. AI makes things so much more comfortable. Technology makes things a lot easier, but you can shortcut a lot of things. How do we actually still learn to sit with what is our true biology that's not changing? True freedom is you can pick the things that are hard and you can feel pride in becoming the thing that you want to be. Don't think about it as a shortcut tool.
quotes.context: Explaining what she teaches her kids about emotional skills in an AI-powered future

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: You can inflict change on people, but if you want to do it with them trust is the key element there. And then a couple months later, we had the best engagement scores in the company.
quotes.context: Katie reflects on a pivotal moment at Airbnb when her team confronted her about not earning their trust, leading to a major shift in her leadership approach.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: But the companies that know that quality is non-negotiable, it is a long-term necessary aspect of what they build, don't play that numbers game. Or what they do is they recognize that it is absolutely functionality, but the quality of those features that is actually going to get to great usability, desirability in their product.
quotes.context: Katie explains how companies committed to quality don't fall into the trap of always prioritizing measurable metrics over excellence.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: I know there's this saying of it's growth versus quality, but quality is growth.
