And if you think about how you can make your product easier to use and more understandable, that will of course drive people to use it, and use more of it, and have a better experience with it that they'll want to talk about with others.
quotes.context: Katie challenges the false dichotomy between quality and growth, arguing they are deeply interconnected.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: A pet peeve of mine is this way of talking about things as there's business goals and there's design goals. Because I think maybe the first conversation one should have is that, 'What are we trying to build towards?' And I would think that folks that want to create really impactful products, they want to create quality products.
quotes.context: Katie pushes back on the artificial separation between business and design goals in product development.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: Things that are more beautiful, increase trust. You see that we've put painstaking detail into this and we care about the details of how something works, and that gives you assurance that we care about other details that you can't see too.
quotes.context: Katie explains why beauty matters for a B2B financial infrastructure company like Stripe.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: The gravitational pull is to mediocrity. It is very easy to fall into a path of a baseline, where what is required to go to that next level where something feels truly great is certainly a lot of effort, and it's a concerted effort.
quotes.context: Katie describes the natural tendency toward mediocrity and why achieving excellence requires deliberate, sustained effort.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: Quality is definitely a group effort. You're sunk if you think that you can just hire some incredibly talented person and they'll do it, that'll be fine. The rest of us will do what we're doing and they'll do it, or that it's just one organization that's going to look out for quality.
quotes.context: Katie emphasizes that quality cannot be delegated to a single person or team - it must be an organizational priority.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: That pairs with the next piece, which is about courage, the ability to actually say, 'No, this isn't good enough.' To have the resolve to just be like, 'Almost, but no.' Which is one of the hardest decisions I think leaders can make.
quotes.context: Katie discusses the importance of editorial courage in maintaining quality standards.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: Performance equals potential minus interference. And I really like this, it's pretty simple, but it's a good reminder that, as a leader, one of the things that you are of course driving towards is trying to get better performance so that your team feels more purpose and motivation.
quotes.context: Katie shares a formula she learned at Airbnb that guides her approach to leading and scaling teams.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: A fear of bold ideas. What happens is that... a fear of shaking things up too much or big ideas with lots of things changing at once are really hard to measure. And so actually if we just make an incremental approach, it's very measured and we know what the outcome is going to be, it feels safer.
quotes.context: Katie warns against the tendency to avoid bold ideas in favor of safe, incremental approaches that feel more measurable.

quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.text: It's easier to teach tools and process than it is taste and character, so I would certainly pay a lot of attention to that. Their hit rate for great judgment and great taste, and how they've honed that, even if they're not very experienced, just to see do they have that natural inclination for great things.
quotes.context: Katie shares her key advice for hiring designers: prioritize taste and character over teachable skills.

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: You start to realize advice is not as powerful as you might think it is. It's a little bit like cotton candy. Doesn't have a lot of nutrition. You get a nice sugar high. You feel great, both sides feel happy, but then a couple weeks later, a couple months later, nothing's really changed.
quotes.context: Explaining why advice from experienced leaders often fails to create lasting change - it doesn't confront the real problem

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: There is this sense that what is interesting about driving is the world hasn't gotten any more complex. Driving's always been driving. But now your place in the world has shifted such that the internal meaning-making and self-complexity that is required requires a complete reboot of the internal operating system in order to allow you to thrive there.
quotes.context: Using a driving analogy to explain how advancing to leadership requires internal transformation, not just new skills

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: The most frightening part about it is you look around and everyone is looking at you like you're the designer of the game, and you thought you were playing. That's often what it feels like when you move into a leadership role, to come back to this sense of what got me here is not going to get me there.
quotes.context: Describing the jarring realization when PMs discover others expect them to set the rules, not just follow them

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: Are you responding to the world from a place of fear, where you see problems and threats, you want to be right, you want to be liked, you're defensive as an inward approach, or are you responding to the world from a place of openness, possibility, curiosity, passion, growth, purpose?
quotes.context: Defining the fundamental distinction between creative and reactive leadership mindsets

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: According to their research, some 75% of leaders are primarily operating reactively. So most leaders are operating from a place of fear, reacting, seeing problems, and threats. That's because that other question of how do you do it is such a hard one to answer.
quotes.context: Citing research from Bob Anderson and Bill Adams showing most leaders operate from fear despite knowing creative leadership is more effective

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: I had to meet other people's expectations, please them, want to be accepted by them, seek their approval. It was this what we call a complying approach. Here, this is why this is so vexing is it actually worked really well. It was pretty effective. Other people liked working with me. But there came a point where I gave away so much power that it was hurting me when it came to purpose and execution and decisiveness.
quotes.context: Ken's personal journey of realizing his people-pleasing approach that worked early in his career became a liability at senior levels

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: For me, the key to that was letting go of needing to be liked and redefining it as an admiration that takes place over time. So rather than I want to leave this room with everyone liking me, I started to realize I want to be the type of leader where, a decade later, people say, 'I would work with that guy again in a heartbeat.'
quotes.context: The mindset shift that unlocked Ken's leadership - trading immediate approval for lasting respect

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: Where we're talking about is this is all me. Now that's empowering. There's empowerment to be able to say I want to change something and it doesn't involve a whole bunch of other people convincing and persuading them. This is all me. But it also, in some ways, makes it harder because it is all you.
quotes.context: The double-edged nature of inner work in leadership - you have full control but also full responsibility

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: How much all of the challenges that senior executives are dealing with come down to people versus product. So it's like it's fun to think about designing products, optimizing, doing user discovery, and testing what, but you sit down with an executive and it's all about people. That's the hard part.
quotes.context: Revealing the biggest blind spot for product leaders - underestimating how much senior roles are about people, not product

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: You are a leader from day one in product management. You don't have any formal authority, but you're a leader. You're expected to lead. Guess what? The hardest part about being a leader is when you don't get to just rely on the formal authority. So you're getting to practice all the hard parts about leadership from day one.
quotes.context: Why PM is excellent leadership training - you practice the hardest part (leading without authority) from your first day

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: The art is communication, collaboration, the more fuzzy, softer skills, people stuff. It's an elevation of that being just as important, if not more important, over time, as all this skills, techniques, tactics, managing a backlog, all that kind of stuff that you have to do.
quotes.context: Elevating the 'art' of product management (people skills) above the 'science' (frameworks and tactics)

quotes.speaker: Ken Norton
quotes.text: I like to think of it a little bit as you got inner board of directors, and there's some noisy, chatty voices that every so often sit in the chairperson's seat and start taking over. If you start to recognize, 'Wait, no, I'm the chairperson. I don't want to hear from you right now. We'll hear from you later,' it starts to create some power.
quotes.context: A practical framework for managing imposter syndrome - you're the chairperson of your inner board of directors

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: Everywhere I've ever worked before this, you kind of know what technology you're building on. But that's not true at all with AI. It's like every two months computers can do something they've never been able to do before and you need to completely think differently about what you're doing.
quotes.context: Kevin contrasts AI product development with traditional tech - the foundational technology itself is constantly changing.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: No matter how big your company gets, no matter how incredible the people are, there are way more smart people outside your walls than there are inside your walls. And that's why we are so focused on building a great API.
quotes.context: Kevin quotes Ev Williams to explain why OpenAI prioritizes its API - they can never build for every use case themselves.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: There's an Eisenhower quote: 'Plans are useless. Planning is helpful.' I totally subscribe to that, especially in this world. It's really valuable to have a moment where you stop and go, 'What did we do? What worked? What went well? What didn't go well? What did we learn and now what do we think we're going to do next?'
quotes.context: Kevin explains OpenAI's lightweight approach to roadmapping - the planning moment is valuable even when plans get thrown out.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: If you're building, and we say this to developers too, if you're building and the product that you're building is right on the edge of the capabilities of the models, keep going, because you're doing something right. Give it another couple months and the models are going to be great, and suddenly the product that you have that just barely worked is really going to sing.
quotes.context: Kevin introduces 'model maximalism' - building for capabilities that are almost there because models improve so fast.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: If you asked me something that I needed to think for 20 seconds to answer, what would I do? I wouldn't just go mute and not say anything and shut down for 20 seconds and then come back. So we shouldn't do that. We shouldn't just have a slider sitting there. But I also wouldn't just start babbling every single thought that I had.
quotes.context: Kevin reveals a key insight: when designing AI experiences, think about how humans would behave in the same situation.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: I actually think chat is an amazing interface because it's so versatile. It is the way we talk. If I had some more rigid interface that I was allowed to use when we spoke, I would be able to speak to you about far fewer things and it would actually get in the way of us having maximum communication bandwidth.
quotes.context: Kevin pushes back on chat critics - the unstructured nature of chat is a feature, not a bug, for AI interactions.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: My personal belief is that you want to be pretty PM light as an organization just in general. Too many PMs causes problems. We'll fill the world with decks and ideas versus execution. You want a PM that is working with maybe slightly too many engineers because it means they're not going to get in and micromanage.
quotes.context: Kevin advocates for lean PM organizations that empower engineers rather than creating bureaucracy.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: High agency is something that we really look for, people that are not going to come in and wait for everyone else to allow them to do something, they're just going to see a problem and go do it. It's just a core part of how we work. People that are happy with ambiguity, because there is a massive amount of ambiguity here.
quotes.context: Kevin describes the traits that make successful PMs at OpenAI - high agency and comfort with ambiguity are essential.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: There's no question that fine-tuned models are the future. Models are going to be everywhere just like transistors are everywhere. AI is going to be just a part of the fabric of everything we do, but there are going to be a lot of fine-tuned models because why would you not want to more specifically customize a model against a particular use case?
quotes.context: Kevin predicts fine-tuned models will become standard practice - customization for specific use cases is too valuable to ignore.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: One of the most important things AI could do would be personalized tutoring. It kind of blows my mind that there isn't a 2 billion kid AI personalized tutoring thing because the models are good enough to do it now. Every study shows that when you combine education with personalized tutoring, you get multiple standard deviation improvements in learning speed.
quotes.context: Kevin identifies personalized AI tutoring as a massive unrealized opportunity that could transform global education.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: The AI models that you're using today is the worst AI model you will ever use for the rest of your life. And when you actually get that in your head, it's kind of wild. Models are getting smarter, they're getting faster, they're getting cheaper, and they're getting safer too. They hallucinate less every iteration.
quotes.context: Kevin's signature framing for AI progress - we should build for future capabilities, not today's limitations.

quotes.speaker: Kevin Weil
quotes.text: Sometimes it's not any one thing, it's just good work consistently over a long period of time. People too often look for the silver bullet when a lot of life and a lot of excellence is actually showing up day in and day out, doing good work, getting a little bit better every single day. Over the course of a year, two years, five years, it adds up like crazy.
quotes.context: Kevin shares his life philosophy, quoting Mark Zuckerberg - sustained effort compounds more than any single breakthrough.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: I would say 90% of us make 90% of our mistakes in that ruinous empathy bucket. It's by far and away the most common problem.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: It was almost like I suddenly realized I'd been marching through my whole career with a giant hunk of spinach in between my teeth and nobody had had the common courtesy to tell me it was there.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: And when a leader treats their team, the people who they interact with on a day-to-day basis with that kind of real care, then it's much more likely that their direct reports in turn are going to treat their teams with real care. And that creates a culture of caring. And even though relationships don't scale, culture does scale.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: Slack is just a feedback train wreck waiting to happen. I once coached someone who kept giving feedback over Slack and I finally just quit coaching him. I was like, 'If you keep making this mistake, I can't be your coach.' So don't do that. Take a moment to pick up the phone and call the person.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: He looked me right in the eye and he said, 'Why didn't you tell me?' And as that question was going around in my head with no good answer, he looked at me again and he said, 'Why didn't anyone tell me? I thought you all cared about me.'

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: This person deserves to have a job where they can excel and you either help them excel on this team or you help them find a different job where they can excel, because everyone can do great work somewhere.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: My job was not to be liked. My job was to care about other people and to get out of my own head and to become others focused is what helped me kind of let go of the need to be liked.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: If you say, 'Do you have any feedback for me?' You're wasting your breath. The other person's going to say, 'Oh no, everything's fine.' Nobody in your life except your teenage children really wants to give you criticism.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: The simplest way to embrace the discomfort is to close your mouth and count to six. Six seconds is a really long time. Almost nobody can endure six full seconds of silence. So they'll probably tell you something.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: A person takes a huge risk, especially if this person is your employee. A person takes a huge risk to give you critical feedback. And if you do not reward that risk richly, you're never going to get any feedback again.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: It's stitch in time saves nine on all these two minute conversations, and really it should be brushing and flossing. This is not like a root canal. This is relationship hygiene that you should be doing all the time.

quotes.speaker: Kim Scott
quotes.text: You do not have to choose between being successful and being a jerk. You can be a successful kind person.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: Every time you see that the product efficiency delta is greater than or equal to four, three things happen. It is irreversible. Second is that you have a very high tolerance for it to fail. And the third thing is what I call the UBP, 'Unique Brag-worthy Proposition.' Every time humans unlock a Delta 4 product or service, they cannot stop talking or sharing about it.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: A lot of CEOs have done well because they follow the 'dharma' of the founders quite well. They have not diluted the dharma of the founders who have started these companies, and managed to sustain that. Maintaining 'dharma', where I will say that 'These principles were given to me and I'm going to sustain this and make it even bigger,' comes from the humility of saying that there is something that was built with some pure form factor.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: ARPU is a function of per capita income of a country. You cannot make $100 per user from a country for a product when their income is let's say $2,500 per year as an average for the whole country. A lot of Indian founders who tried to copy the Western market saying, 'I'm going to have a few hundred million users' make a terrible mistake because they will need to then go abroad to find their ARPUs to balance the act.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: No Indian has ever been paid an hourly salary in their entire life. When you're not paid an hourly salary, the concept of time is not the same. And when the concept of time is not the same, paying for time is hard to do. Many Indian languages do not have a word for 'efficiency.' And that's true for many Asian languages, the word for 'efficiency' does not exist. So then how do you value it if it's not in the vocabulary?

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: In a low trust country, and all developing nations are low trust by design, because the institutions are not strong enough, what happens is there is concentration of trust. So you will see that super apps, superstars, super companies all exist in low trust markets because the lack of trust creates concentration of trust, and therefore you will see one app can do 400 things.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: I often tell people that entrepreneurs are uncertainty absorbers for everybody - for employees, for investors, for customers - and therefore they get rewarded for being those people who remove uncertainty from people's lives.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: One of the things I've learned is that profit pools of a country tell you a lot about what the country values. And trying to copy somebody else's profit pool to your country will not be a wise idea because the country's values are demonstrated in what profit pools exist.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: I think a curious person is somebody who is constantly demonstrating that they are not proud of their expertise, and they will demonstrate extraordinary amounts of excitement when they face a problem which they have no clue how to solve. A lot of people stop growing because they want to constantly demonstrate their expertise versus demonstrating their curiosity.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: My method of learning is to constantly come up with conjectures from the dots that you have connected and then absolutely work hard to find proof of it and then use that to connect to the next dot. So I often tell people that every book you read makes your brain poorer to read the next book. That's the purpose of books, but that's true for every single thing we learn.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: Second order thinking is known to be the most powerful trait to predict the success of somebody. But I often wonder what happened in the childhood of people who became great at second order thinking. I've found some loose examples such as if you played strategy games or only physical games as a strong correlation. Rigor came from physical games, but second order thinking came from playing strategy games as a kid.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: I think entrepreneurs have this weird ability to forget about failures and almost turn that into a lesson that you hold, and you forget the story. I often believe that life is too short to make all our mistakes ourselves. So we should be learning from other people's failures as well. And a lot of times we don't do that because we believe that we are special, nothing like that will happen to us.

quotes.speaker: Kunal Shah
quotes.text: All success comes from an extraordinary amount of pain and struggle and hard work, and there is no shortcut to anything material coming in life. The best way to love yourself is to keep evolving. My motivation comes from evolution, connecting dots, solving harder problems than I've solved in the past. Life is ultimately a game where you want to feel that your levels have changed and your skills have changed constantly.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: I think if you're a startup your enemy is the status quo. And when you don't take risks, when you minimize risk by doing nothing, the best way to minimize risk is to do nothing. You're letting the status quo win. You're letting your greatest enemy and rival and threat to your business win by default, because you're not even going to try to compete.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: I always encourage people to try to make mistakes of commission rather than omission. Because if you make a mistake of commission you can observe it, you can learn from it. You know right away that it's happened. You can move really quickly and adapt and become better. Whereas if you make mistakes of omission you're letting status quo win, you're not observing, you're not learning.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: You want to make it something that a second-grader could understand. You want to minimize the cognitive burden on the recipient. So it should be something where they're not having to expend any extra energy understanding the thing, where it immediately paints a picture.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: People have things that they either care about or don't, and you're not going to change that. It's a huge lift to try to change someone's worldview or their passions. It's a light lift to take the thing you want to talk about and just shape it to fit into their worldview or their passions. If your natural audience cares about X and you're offering Y, then it's your job to create the bridge from X to Y.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: First, you have to acknowledge that you're the underdog, and you're not going to use the GE playbook from the 1980s or whatever. That means knowing that you're not going to play the game that requires you to have more resources, more and deeper relationships, and institutional backings, and to be able to draft off of the current narrative.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: If you want to spread something you go out in concentric circles starting from your own desk. You need to get first really clear with yourself about what your message is. This is hard to do because you know too much, so out of the 1,000 facts in your head you're going to have to pick just between one and three. And then the next circle is your co-founders, executives, employees, investors, power users.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: If employees are not saying that, then people are going to look at employees and say, 'Well, they would know, they're closer to this than we are. So if they're not excited then why would we be excited?' And so that undermines everything that we're trying to do, you can't skip a circle.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: If you decrease the surface area then with the same amount of force you can apply more pressure. Pressure is force divided by the surface area, this is a basic equation for physics, but it's also true of communications. If you decrease the surface area and don't try to appeal to everybody with everything, you're able to with the same amount of effort or expense or time make more of an impact.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: If you're just starting out, get 10 diehards and just spend all your time on them. You can't start out and try to win over the general public. You start out by creating a tiny monopoly. Choose what is going to be your tiny corner of the internet that you are going to just dominate entirely, and they'll expand it out to the next circle.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: If you're writing online or doing something online, the denominator is the size of the internet. You don't need to capture 80% of it. If you capture 0.01% of it, that is a great business and then you can go from there. Once you've won that then you can decide to go from there and the world is a big place.

quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.text: You're doing it as a corporation instead of a person. This is another super common mistake. You're letting yourself speak like a faceless corporation because it feels like that's what you should do now. It doesn't work because people don't trust institutions. People care about people and trust and like people, there's a sense of wanting to cosplay an executive and it doesn't work.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: The best PMs not only can find the one thing to work on, but they can stay with that one thing long enough to actually finish it.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: Prioritization is a tough word because there's so much wrapped up in that and what it means to prioritize. And I've worked for people who wanted to understand the formula for prioritization and why this thing and how can you prove that this is the right thing to work on. And then a week goes by and then they want to reevaluate the priority and they want to re-litigate the priority.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: The really, really good PMs remember to follow up. Because especially when you're in management, couple layers up in management, I'm not going to remember to follow up on that feature, but if a PM comes back to me and says, 'Hey, remember we did that thing, here's what happened.' I can't tell you how rare that is.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: Strategy to me, it's one tiny slice. You do a strategy, but it's 5% of the work that you do. Yes, it's important because you want to get your strategy and you need to pick the right products, but at the end of the day, the person who has a good strategy will not be as successful as the PM who ships more stuff, gets more reps and has the ability to actually create impact.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: Just say that. Just say that thing. The thing that you said to me in conversation is the thing you should write. There's no reason why your prose in a document has to be a certain way. We're not in school. Our goal is to get things done.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: There's a thing that happens with PMs where you join a company and then all of a sudden it's like my boss doesn't know what they're doing and the highest paid person's opinion and the founder wants to swoop in and mess everything up, but those people had an insight on the market that you're in that made the company worth founding and they probably know more than you.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: It's both figuring out how to get confident in your decision and then having the willingness to make the bet and be responsible for it. And that's what separates the PM role from a lot of other roles and why it's such a challenging job when done right is because you have to be willing to take responsibility.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: I am of the opinion that I never wanted to rely on someone else to get what I wanted. And so I would always make sure to share my progress, always make sure to share that because I didn't want to leave it up to chance that someone would notice.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: The more you ship, the more you learn. And that's why it can take years to build up expertise because you just have to ship a lot of stuff.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: If you ever find yourself saying something like, that's not my job, that's probably a thing you should do. And you know what? It probably isn't your job and it probably is someone else's job and you can spend your life getting frustrated at that or you can just get over and get the work done.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: As a PM, you're not going to do your job unless that problem gets solved for the customer or the user at the end of the day. And so your job is to make sure everything happens for that product.

quotes.speaker: Maggie Crowley
quotes.text: People who are really excited about being data-driven, to me that is oftentimes a red flag for their product thinking. To me that says that the team is over-emphasizing quantitative data at the expense of qualitative data and they're not using good judgment.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: There is no question that a lot of companies overhired during the pandemic. I go into some companies and honestly I can't believe all the ridiculous roles that they have, agile coaches and product owners and product ops and business analysts. They're dramatically overpaid for the value they provide. Because it's a project management role.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: Too many people in our industry view themselves as a victim of their company, like they're stuck in a feature team and there's nothing they can do about it other than quit. I think that's not true. There is so much they can do.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: On a feature team, you're basically given a roadmap of output. Their features are projects. You're being asked to design, build, test, deploy that feature. It is a lot easier to deliver output than it is to deliver outcomes. A product team, instead of being given that roadmap of features, they're given problems to solve.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: Strong product companies understand it's all about outcomes. You just don't get points for shipping, you get points for delivering the value. It's about time to money more than time to market. We know how to do time to market. The harder part is time to money.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: You need this person who understands the customers and understands the business deeply. That's where the product manager role came from. You need a different set of skills that your engineers and your designers almost never have. Those are very different skillsets.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: On a real empowered product team, product manager is a creator, not a facilitator. I always cringe when somebody tells me, oh, my job is to say why? And I'm like, 'Well, what do you do for the rest of the week besides the 10 minutes it takes you to say why?' It's ridiculous.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: I was not allowed to take the product manager role until I had visited 30 customers in person, 15 in the US, 15 in Europe. Those 30 customers changed my life because I thought I knew our customers and I really didn't.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: You're supposed to be the expert on the data. How is our product being used? How is that usage changing over time? Another big one is you are the person on the team that represents the compliance issues, the sales issues, the marketing issues, the financial cost issues, the monetization issues, go to market in general. This is all the product manager.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: Most product management advice you find online, probably 90% of the content out there is from the feature team world or worse. Unless they get really lucky or they happen to have a manager that is guiding them in a good direction, it just propagates.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: Product leaders do product strategy. Product teams don't do product strategy. That is the job, is to make these strategic decisions, the focus decisions, the bets you're going to place. Then you give those bets to the teams and you really do give them latitude to figure it out.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: Empowerment does not mean you set up this product team and they go decide what to work on. That would just be anarchy. Empowerment means the leaders do their job, come up with the bets, and then the teams are able to figure out the best way to solve those problems.

quotes.speaker: Marty Cagan
quotes.text: If you are fundamentally a backlog administrator, good luck protecting that because already people are doing that with AI. That is not a good job prospect. For an empowered product manager, if your responsibility is value and viability, that's the real challenge left.

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: If you want to accomplish something truly extraordinary, if you want to be in the 99th percentile in terms of outcomes, it's going to be really difficult. It's going to be really uncomfortable. And you got to sort of remind people of that, that if they ever find themselves in the comfort zone at work, they are definitely making a mistake.
quotes.context: Framing the fundamental philosophy that extraordinary results require leaving the comfort zone

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: When you staff a project, is it better to overstaff or is it better to under-staff knowing that you can't get it right? Well, it's better to under-staff. If you overstaff, you get politics, you get people working on things that are further down the priority list than necessary. That is poison. It's wasteful. It slows you down. It creates cruft.
quotes.context: Explaining the deliberate understaffing philosophy - it's less dangerous than overstaffing

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: One thing that I've learned from Parker is you don't really learn from your mistakes, you learn from your successes. There's more to glean from seeing how it's done right than there is to glean from seeing how it's done wrong. If I tell you you're going to get on an airplane and one maintenance technician has seen it done right a hundred times and the other has seen it done wrong a hundred times, but he learned from his mistakes, give me a break.
quotes.context: Challenging the popular notion that failure teaches more than success - join winning teams to learn

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: Processes in a business exist for the sole purpose of lowering beta. Processes are for decreasing volatility in the output of the system. The downside of a process is that it suppresses alpha. And you have to be super, super careful and judicious in the application of process to know that you're lowering beta in the places where you want to do that without suppressing alpha in the places where you need it.
quotes.context: Introducing the alpha/beta financial framework for thinking about process and people in organizations

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: Product market fit is a sort of thing where you absolutely know it when you see it, and therefore if you don't absolutely know it, you don't have it. Over and over again, over the course of the many years that I spent at Inkling, we thought we had it. We thought we had product market fit, maybe, maybe. And in hindsight, with the benefit of now having experienced solid product market fit, it was so, so obvious that we didn't.
quotes.context: Drawing on his nine years at Inkling to explain how founders deceive themselves about product market fit

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: The Silicon Valley try until you die mindset is not pro-entrepreneur, it's pro-venture capitalist. The incentive of venture capitalist is to put money into your company and milk you dry. They never get their money back. There is no way for them to take that investment back. So the only logical desire that they would have is for you to keep trying against all odds.
quotes.context: Exposing the hidden incentive structure behind the 'never quit' Silicon Valley mythology

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: If you recognize that the market is immutable, no amount of tweeting, LinkedIn posting, advertising is going to change whether the market wants your product. It might raise awareness about your product, but it's not going to change whether somebody wants it. You have to view your startup as running an experiment in the universe to see what you get in return for that.
quotes.context: Using drug discovery analogy - binding receptors either exist or they don't, you can't market your way to fit

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: The only antidote to entropy, the only antidote to decay in a system is energy. You got to inject energy. So if you have a code base, every line of code that you add to that code base increases the entropy of that system and demands ever more energy from human beings to go and intend to it to make sure it doesn't break.
quotes.context: Applying the second law of thermodynamics to explain why constant effort is required to maintain quality

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: The purest form of ambition and the purest and most intense source of energy in the business is the founder CEO. Every next concentric circle of management beyond the founder CEO has the potential to be an order of magnitude drop off in intensity, and that is fucking dangerous.
quotes.context: Warning about intensity drop-off through management layers - executives must mirror founder intensity, not buffer it

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: Don't be chill. Chill doesn't accomplish shit. Be intense. Be good, be respectful, be intense. Don't be chill. What's worse than a chill boss? No, don't work for a chill boss. Don't be a chill boss. It's the most pejorative label I could give you.
quotes.context: Direct advice against the 'chill manager' archetype - intensity is invigorating, not exhausting

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: Fundamentally, the most selfish thing you can do is withhold feedback from someone. When you think a thought that would help someone improve and you avoid giving it to them because it would make you uncomfortable, you're optimizing for your own comfort, and it's fundamentally selfish. It's the most selfish thing you could possibly do.
quotes.context: Reframing feedback avoidance as selfishness rather than kindness - demands escalation culture

quotes.speaker: Matt MacInnis
quotes.text: Play the sport, play it with everything you've got, but never forget that it's just a sport and that none of it matters. Silicon Valley in 2025 is Florence and the Renaissance. The amount of creativity and insane invention and progress that's happening for our species right now in this place is absolutely unparalleled in all human history. You've got to zoom out and appreciate that magic.
quotes.context: The philosophical counterbalance to intensity - remembering insignificance brings levity to the work

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: And I think most planning is often done by looking at the bricks and trying to stack them, and then you can create only so much. And so I guess the column B thinking is thinking about what is that magical wonderful future that you then want to invest years and decades of your life actually building?

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: You kind of want to have a ladder that goes all the way up to the moon, which is your crazy, wild vision. And then you want to have rungs that just work its way up step by step. And so you want to get that really clear picture of the future that you would like and then just take little step, after little step, after little step.

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: So we have this concept of chaos to clarity and every idea starts in the chaos side, and then you have to work all the way to the other side, which is clarity. And so chaos can be an idea, it can be a problem, it can be a philosophy or a belief.

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: That very first step at the very far end of chaos, it's very embarrassing because you're like, 'I have this idea that is so big and so wild and how the hell would I do that? I have no idea.' And so it's quite an embarrassing step, actually, because you don't have mastery at that point. You don't have all the answers.

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: I think the thing that I love about a crazy big goal is that you feel completely inadequate before it. With a crazy big goal, then you want to work really hard to will it into existence. And so if you start with a reasonable goal or a realistic goal, then you kind of get to it and you're like, 'Oh cool, whatever.'

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: We were doing a front-end rewrite and we thought it would take about six months. It was really important because it was critical for cross-platform. And it just felt like we're in a dark, dark tunnel that we could hardly see the end of the tunnel. A product company not shipping product is not really a recipe for fun.

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: It was really clear in my mind that it was the future and I thought the investors were wrong, frankly. But investors also gave really helpful feedback and feedback often in the form of rejection. So they would say, 'Oh, your market's not big enough.' And I would say, 'It's going to be huge.' And I'd add a new page in my pitch deck.

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: It's kind of building a house that you want every brick in the house to match. And if you go and try and take some bricks from someone else's house and stick it in your house, it's probably going to not look very matched. And so trying to find things that are authentic to us and are authentic to everything that's come before it.

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: Often people have a mission that's kind of on the wall somewhere and then what they're actually doing and the way they actually make money and the way people actually spend their time is in a very, very different direction from that original mission. And I think the magic is when you can bring those two things together.

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: I don't have emails on my phone and so when I shut my laptop, I actually tune out and then if there's a real issue, I'll get an emergency call or page. Sometimes you can miss the forest from the trees when you're just working harder and harder, but maybe you're actually working on the wrong thing.

quotes.speaker: Melanie Perkins
quotes.text: And if you take that problem centered approach that helps people to achieve something they actually want to do in the real life, you're probably going to be at a reasonably good spot. I think it's better to solve a small number of people's problem really well than trying to solve a large number of people's problem not very well at all.

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: I had this notion coming in like, 'Yes, these models are great, but are they able to have an independent opinion?' And it's actually really flipped for me only in the last month. My go-to product strategy partner is Claude. Opus 4 really looked at it in a new way. That is a new angle that I hadn't been looking at before and I'm going to incorporate that immediately.

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: We really rapidly became bottlenecked on other things like our merge queue. We had to completely re-architect it because so much more code was being written and so many more pull requests were being submitted that it just completely blew out the expectations of it. I've just found all these new bottlenecks in our system.

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: The upstream bottleneck is decision making and alignment. A lot of things that I'm thinking about right now is how do I provide the minimum viable strategy to let people feel empowered to go run and type and build and explore at the edge of model capabilities.

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: The team that works in the most futuristic way is the Claude Code team. They're using Claude Code to build Claude Code in a very self-improving kind of way. They've realized Claude is generally right and it's producing pull requests that are probably larger than most people are going to be able to review. So can you use a different Claude to review it?

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: If the proportion was already skewing towards having more of that embedding, I've just become more and more convinced. If we're shipping things that could have been built by anybody just using our models off the shelf, where we should play and what we can do uniquely should be stuff that's really at that magic intersection between product and research.

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: Making this all comprehensible. What's still the difference between somebody who's really adept at using these tools in their work and most people is huge. Strategy, how we win, where we'll play. And opening people's eyes to what's possiblethe delta between what the models and the products can do and how they're being used on a daily basis. Huge overhang.

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: Sometimes I'm like, 'Be brutal, Claude, roast me. Tell me what's wrong with this strategy.' Claude's like a pretty nice entity. It's hard to push it to be super brutal, but it forces it to be a little bit more critical as well. Make the other mistakeif you tend to be too nice, can you focus on being more critical?

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: More than headcount we need a couple of almost founder type engineers. I'm a huge believer in the founding engineer tech lead with an idea and pair them with the right design and product supports. I'm 10 times more a believer in that than before.

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: How do we figure out what we want to be when we grow up versus what we currently aren't or wish that we were or see other players in the space being? I think there's room for several generationally important companies to be built in AI right now. Let's figure out what we can be uniquely good at.

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: For utility of AI products, it's three parts. One is model intelligence, the second part is context and memory, and the third part is applications and UI and you need all three of those to converge to actually be a useful product in AI. MCP really tried to tackle that middle one.

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: You know when your product is really serving people and it's doing a good job of doing that. So much of when you get really metrics obsessed is when you're trying to convince yourself that it is when it's not. Do we repeatedly hear from people that Claude is the way that they're unlocking their own creativity and getting things done?

quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.text: There's tremendous power in distribution and reach, but there's also people have an assumption about how to use things. I get excited about startups that have a completely different take on what the form factor is by which we interface with AI. Do something that feels very advanced user, very power user, very weird and out there at the beginning.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: That is both the torment of scaling companies, which is that the ground is moving under your feet. And as soon as you're comfortable, someone will make sure that you are uncomfortable, but it's also the opportunity, which is that you can go from being someone that's good at building houses to someone that knows how to build entire worlds.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: At Facebook, I got to a place where I was literally giving away my job every three weeks. I was constantly rehiring myself essentially because you have to sort of grow as fast as your company is growing if you really want to take advantage of the opportunity that comes with companies that are growing and changing quickly.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: I externalized all these emotions that come with change into this little tiny monster. I named my monster, Bob. Bob's job is basically to make me the worst version of myself. He's the one that wants to send the rage emails at 9:00PM and burn the house down. All these emotions are normal and they are not useful. They are not the compass that should be telling you what to do.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: The way a lot of people do careers is a set of stairs. Just walk up the stairs and you'll get promoted every two years. But the much more fun careers are like jumping off cliffs. You do fall for a period of time, about six to nine months, but then this thing happens where you climb out way beyond where the stairs could ever get you.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: One of the greatest gifts in a career is knowing yourself. And that's a lifelong journey because who you are and what you want changes, but that knowledge and that gift, nothing accelerates your self-knowledge faster than trying to do something that you don't know how to do and that you're scared of.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: Being the person that takes their learning in their own hands, learning no matter what and learning to ask those dumb questions, it's a superpower. Actually, my superpower is being a professional moron. I'm the one that shows up in a room and is like, 'Do we have goals? What are we doing? Why are we having this meeting?' And most of the time it's actually what I was hired to do, which is bring clarity.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: The rule with the Waterline Model is you snorkel before you scuba. 80% of problems on teams actually happen because of structural issues or dynamics issues. Your only goal as a manager, if you do nothing else, is clear roles and clear expectations. That's it.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: No company needs more than three company goals and the point of company goals is to help people know what the most important things are to success. Facebook basically had three goals for the entire time I was there. If you can govern that business with three goals, you can govern literally any business with three goals.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: Strategy should hurt. If your goal setting process is not painful, then you're not prioritizing heavily enough.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: One goal has one owner. Two people owning a goal is no one owning a goal. One person owns the goal, who is it? It's not you as the CEO, it's someone that works for you. That means that person, come hell or high water, owns that number.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: 80% of the culture of a company is literally defined by the personality of the founder. Facebook is Mark. Google is Larry and Sergei. Our job as operators or as leaders around founders is to help articulate the culture that they're creating and to help extend it.

quotes.speaker: Molly Graham
quotes.text: More people does not actually make you faster. We think it does. It does not. It makes it harder. It makes it harder to get work done. It makes it slower. So you should be scared of adding people, not like, 'Oh, this is the answer to all my problems.'

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: The most dangerous kind of person to have in an organization is an agreeable taker. And the most precious person in an organization is the disagreeable giver. Those are the people who are really motivated to do what's best for the company, but they can be a little bit disagreeable in the sense that they may not say what you want to hear. They may push back on things, they may fight for things.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: We had a notion of growth accounting, which looks at what's our net growth every day? And what we found was the churn and resurrection lines were actually much larger than the new user line, which implied to us that retention and driving those two lines was actually our biggest lever to drive net growth.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: One of my Naomi-isms is really understand, identify, and execute. In 2009 in January, we basically stopped doing anything on our roadmap except data instrumentation. We just didn't have the data that we needed to make informed decisions to know really what were the biggest levers to drive growth.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: I think the majority of the value is in just having extreme clarity around the goal and that allowed everybody to work towards optimizing the same goal. It doesn't matter if it was seven friends in 10 days or 10 in 14. What mattered was that we picked one of them and we had the same goal.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: All of the work that we did on growth around optimizing the flows were really about removing micro barriers. We found 20% of people aren't actually confirming their email. We allowed people to get notifications even as an unconfirmed account, and if they clicked on any of those notifications, that would count as an account confirmation. It's just removing a micro barrier.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: A PM is a conductor. It's as though the team that you are a PM on is an orchestra. There are many different functions in your team that includes legal policy, comms, data analytics, engineering, design. And as a PM, your job is to make sure everyone's playing their part correctly, but at the same time, they're playing together, they're unified in the music that they're producing.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: Extreme clarity means everyone's on the same page. It definitely doesn't mean that they all agree with each other, but they just have the same understanding of the facts. So we can disagree, but we all believe in the facts, which is that there's A, B, C, our options are X, Y, Z and here are the trade-offs 1, 2, 3.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: I never use bulleted lists because you can never refer to a bullet. I always use numbered lists because you can always reference number two in a meeting. Versus the third bullet, two up from the second, whatever, that is not extreme clarity. So it's very, very small tactical things to bigger things like canonical everything.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: I always want a canonical doc. Where can I learn what I need to learn about this project? I ask five different people, get five different answers, that is unacceptable. Everyone should know exactly where the canonical doc is. That's the one place I can go to get all the information I need about a project.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: That's why I think it's very important to have a single-threaded owner. We used to call this a directly responsible individual or a throat to choke. We obviously don't say that anymore. Single-threaded owner, every work stream has a single-threaded owner. Everything canonical needs to recurse.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: I often go into a project, everyone's operating at a PhD level, I'm coming in at a kindergarten level. It doesn't mean I want to oversimplify, that's not what a simplifier does. They're identifying the most basic building blocks of a complex problem and then unfolding, or revealing or building on top of them additional complexity and details as you go along.

quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.text: I would say 80% of the time I think it's a people or process issue. I want to make sure a project is perfectly executing, because only then can we really reevaluate whether or not this strategy is right or wrong. We're in the worst of all worlds where we are imperfectly executing and the project might fail, but we don't know why.

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: I looked on the App Store and the number one app in the United States was an app called Sarahah, but the entire app was in Arabic. Like the strongest signal that you could ever have that people want something. The way you should search for product ideas is this concept of latent demand where people are trying to obtain a particular value and going through a very distortive process.
quotes.context: Describing how he discovered the opportunity for tbh by observing an Arabic app being #1 in US

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: We built 15 apps over four or five years. One took us about a year at first, then our last one took us about two weeks. The most important thing I instruct teams to do is develop a reproducible testing process. That will influence the probability of your success more than anything. It's so unpredictable whether a consumer product idea will work - if you focus on your process for taking many shots at bat, that's what actually reduces the risk.
quotes.context: Explaining the importance of iteration speed and systematic testing over individual ideas

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: Every tap on a mobile app is a miracle for you as a product developer because users will turn and bounce to their next app very quickly. If you actually sit behind someone and watch them use their phone, they switch between apps at a pretty high frequency. Every tap that you get, every single one is so scarce that you should be optimizing everything.
quotes.context: Describing the shift from web to mobile product thinking and design philosophy

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: When you're testing something, test the best possible version of what that could be, whether it takes manual work or something that is never going to scale. You want to eliminate all those potentially confounding variables so you can know immediately whether something's working or not. You never want to walk away from an experiment and say 'Well, maybe the execution was bad.'
quotes.context: Explaining why they manually seeded entire schools to test apps properly

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: When people ask 'What's the benchmark for product-market fit?' this founder Roger Dickey told me: 'If your product's working, you'll know. And if there's any uncertainty, it's not working.' It really is a binary when it comes to consumer products. People are going to be fighting to get into it. Our metric was hourly actives per day, not daily active users.
quotes.context: Describing what true product-market fit feels like for consumer apps

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: The thing that is hard to really understand for first-time founders that hit breakout success is how draining it is, because everything breaks. Everything you built needs to be substituted almost every three days. Our first customer support system broke after three days. The next one broke seven days later. It is absolute chaos to keep the thing online as it scales up.
quotes.context: Describing the reality of hypergrowth with tbh going viral

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: For every social app I've built, the number of invitations sent per user drops 20% for every additional year of age from 13 to 18. If you build for adults, expect to acquire every user with ads. If you're targeting older cohorts, you're going to have to raise huge venture capital to finance that user acquisition pipeline.
quotes.context: Explaining why teens are the optimal target for viral social apps

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: People download apps to make or save money (WhatsApp - free texting), to find a mate (Tinder, Snapchat - find love), or to unplug from reality (Netflix, Fortnite). Putting that in a framing document and the particular nuanced reason why people are going to adopt is difficult when you're presenting to seasoned professionals inside a large company.
quotes.context: Explaining his framework for why people download apps and why big companies struggle with zero-to-one

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: Large companies take 12 to 24 months to respond to competitive threats. An app starts charting, a PM makes a post, market research does a study, it floats around for months, they put together a framing deck, goes through VP reviews, then development takes 6-12 months. It's hard to present something you have a hunch about - you need market evidence or it's not defensible.
quotes.context: Explaining why incumbents are slow to respond and why copying is the only defensible path inside big companies

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: As a product manager in a large tech company, there is very little product management that you do. You're actually not as involved in the product as I assumed. You're completely detached from the design process. There's a design vertical org that does all that and they don't really want you working on that. Products live and die in the pixels - that's on you.
quotes.context: Describing the disconnect between PM role and actual product development at Facebook

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: Put live chat customer support in your app 24 hours a day. It sounds insane - the whole point of tech is you don't need that. But users get this white glove experience, and it's the best vehicle for getting feedback and doing user research because users will literally tell you the problem they're having. Our support rep would paste interesting feedback into Slack and we'd turn it into features.
quotes.context: Sharing tactical advice on eliminating confounding variables during product testing

quotes.speaker: Nikita Bier
quotes.text: At the peak of tbh, we were getting 360,000 installs per day. I looked at our numbers and I'm like 'We will be number one in the United States in six days.' Then I looked at our Amazon bill - $120,000. Our bank account said $150,000. I quickly had to put together a funding round. We geofenced the app because we needed to scale our servers and control growth.
quotes.context: Describing the chaos of tbh's viral growth and strategic decision to geofence to control it

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: What separates traction from distraction is one word, and that one word is intent. The time you plan to waste is not wasted time. Anything you want to do with your time and attention is fine as long as it's done with intent, as long as you're doing it on your schedule, and not someone else's.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: 90% of the time that we get distracted, it's not because of what's happening outside of us, but that most distraction begins from within: boredom, loneliness, fatigue, uncertainty, anxiety. That is the cause of 90% of our distractions.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: The problem is not our technology. The problem is our inability to deal with discomfort. Always identify what is that internal trigger, what is that itch that you are looking to escape when you get distracted, because that is the source of 90% of our distractions.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: We know that this technique that a lot of people use of abstinence, telling yourself, 'Don't do that, that's bad,' actually can backfire. A much healthier technique is not to tell yourself no. It's to tell yourself not yet.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: You cannot call something a distraction unless you know what it distracted you from. If you can't look at your calendar and say, 'Oh, that's traction,' if it's not written in your calendar, it's a distraction.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: One of the main reasons why to-do lists suck is because to-do lists have no constraints. You can always add more to a to-do list. Day after day, week after week, month after month, I was reinforcing this self-image as someone who doesn't know how to manage their time.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: A much more beneficial metric to track is not, 'Did I check off the box? Did I finish?' Rather, it's, 'Did I do what I said I was going to do for as long as I said I would without distraction?' Because that is the only way to understand how long things take you.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: Procrastination is an emotion regulation problem. It's not a character flaw. There's nothing wrong with you, you're not broken. It's just that you don't have the tools to deal with emotional discomfort and that's the part that everybody skips over.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: High performers in every industry, business, the arts, sports, they feel the same internal triggers. They also feel lonely. They also feel bored. They also feel stressed. But they use that discomfort like rocket fuel to propel them towards traction.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: Ego depletion does actually exist, but only for one group of people. The only people who really did run out of willpower the way you would run out of charge in a battery were people who believed that willpower was a limited resource.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: Distraction is a symptom of dysfunction. If you can't talk about a problem, if you can't raise your hand and say, 'Hey, I'm just not able to do my best work when I'm constantly expected to reply to every email, every notification,' if you can't talk about this problem, that is the problem.

quotes.speaker: Nir Eyal
quotes.text: The antidote for impulsiveness is forethought. Fundamentally, distraction is an impulse control issue. That's all it is, and it's a skill like any other. We learn skills. Why do we expect that we should just be born with this innate skill to fight distraction?

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: At Facebook, you can design the product. But at Intercom, you can design the company. And, that was extremely appealing to me, a great pitch. He's like, 'Just design the company with us that you want to work in.'

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: We have a principle called Ship to Learn. Ship fast, ship early, ship often. So, in that idea is the idea of failure. It's not going to go right. And, it's going to go wrong more often than not. But if you ship early, and fast, and learn fast, you can change fast, and you can improve fast.

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: This is a meteor coming towards you. This is bigger than mobile as a technology shift, as big as the internet. Maybe it's bigger than the internet itself as a technology shift, the way it'll shape society. So I'm all in.

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: I'd start with the thing your product does. What's the core premise behind it? Why do people use it? What problem does it solve for them? And then, ask the question, 'Can AI do that?' And for a lot the answer's going to be, 'Yes, it can.' For some, it might be, 'It can partially do it.'

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: We literally ripped up our strategy almost entirely, and started again, from first principles and said, 'Okay, why do people use Intercom?' We totally changed how we think, how we work, and we just went heads down and built. It was a little bit of a bet the farm mindset.

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: Don't bolt it on. Don't be like, 'Oh, we'll have a bunch of AI people...' And we do have some specialists. But generally speaking, we're trying to have everyone learn about it. I'm a big believer in generalists.

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: Number one thing I would say is keep it simple. Fight so hard to resist the temptation to add extra ways in which you price. People can't understand their bill.

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: People who adopt a product, or buy a product, or switch to a product, there's two driving forces. One is the attraction of the new solution, and that's basically differentiation. But, on the other side, there's an entry requirement or table stakes. To play the game, you got to have a certain amount of things.

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: Swinging the pendulum means, you take a step back from everyday work life, and you make the observation that something's in an undesirable state. And then, so you go and fix it, but the temptation is that you over-correct. And we've done this so many times in so many domains.

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: The market is the people, the problems they have, and how important the problems are to them. To have a good market, you need a lot of people with the same problem, and they need to care a lot about it. The product is the solution to that. The market's the who, the product's the what.

quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.text: For us with Jobs to be Done, it was a really good way of centering on the customer problem, focusing on not getting distracted, basing it in good solid research informed insight. There's so many people who spend so much energy debating the nuances. Who cares? Your customers don't care.

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: Great leaders know that when you try to advise and have the answer all the time, you're not actually equipping your team to go solve the hard problems. You're training your team to come to you with all of the hard problems. Coaching is a different way. It's an alternative path that unlocks brilliance in your team and is way more motivating for the people around you.
quotes.context: Explaining why leaders should shift from always having answers to coaching their teams

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: Most people aren't listening. They're just waiting for their turn to talk. This is rampant in tech. Great leaders flip that script and tune in. They're the kinds of leaders who walk into a room, and they can see the elephants. They can name them. They can ask the hard questions to get people collaborating.
quotes.context: Introducing the first skill of coaching - active listening - with a Fight Club reference

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: Level three listening is global listening. That's what I'm hearing beneath the words. I'm hearing what you're communicating, not just what you're saying. I see your body language. I notice your tone of voice. I know the context around what you're talking about, and I can reflect back more insight about what's happening than you're aware of. Dropping into level three listening is what great leaders do when they're influencing, selling, pitching a vision, and definitely when they're coaching.
quotes.context: Describing the deepest level of listening that enables true understanding and connection

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: I use a GROW model. The G is goal - what does success look like? The R is about your current reality - where are you stuck? The O is about your options - what paths could you take? The W is the way forward - what are you going to do next? The people on your team will appreciate the space and time to unlock an option they didn't think of before and walk away with a concrete next step.
quotes.context: Introducing the GROW model framework for coaching conversations

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: When people are in their gifts and their strengths firmly, most of the time, they have more energy. We all have more energy when we're operating from the things we naturally are good at and the things we innately love doing. I try to help my leaders see that they can design their lives so they're spending 80% of their time in their gifts.
quotes.context: Explaining the connection between operating in your strengths and avoiding burnout

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: It's no one else's job to help you live in your gifts. What I notice in big companies is people are often annoyed or frustrated with their management for not making their job more interesting. No, your manager's job is to help you perform in the job you were hired to do. It's your job to navigate your career.
quotes.context: Challenging the expectation that managers should design fulfilling work for their reports

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: 65% of startups fail because of co-founder conflict. Co-founders are in a moment where they're trying to build the future for their business, but also trying to build their own livelihood. So there's so much at stake to get along with your co-founder. The core of a healthy relationship is self-awareness: what do I bring into this dynamic, and how am I being experienced by the other person?
quotes.context: Explaining why co-founder relationships fail and what makes them healthy

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: People, when they want to have a conflict, they come in armored and ready to prove their point. There's a misguided view that the goal is to convince the other person that what they're doing is wrong. Actually, the goal of any conflict is to create mutual understanding. Not to prove your point, but to help the other person empathize and see clearly what's happening.
quotes.context: Reframing the purpose of conflict from winning arguments to creating understanding

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: We operate in tech. We're supposed to give all of ourselves, all of our time, all of our energy to this endeavor, and it's purely logical. That's not at all true. It's completely emotional. Professionals have feelings. If we ignore our feelings, they will bubble up, and we will be unconsciously acting from them.
quotes.context: Challenging the myth that tech work is purely logical and emotions don't belong

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: Difficult conversations makes you want to run away. The marketing on conflict is poor, so I want to reframe that. When we feel internally ambivalent, there's something really beautiful and important to pay attention to. When we are in conflict, something important is at stake. We care deeply about what we're building, about the person that's letting us down. So instead of avoiding it, lean into this moment.
quotes.context: Reframing difficult conversations as growth opportunities rather than things to avoid

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: I ask them, 'Would you enthusiastically rehire this person for the same role?' Which is the question we always asked at Stripe. When the answer is no, no matter how many difficult conversations you have, this is not going to work. So then you have to take action. It's very clarifying because it's binary. You have an immediate reaction that is honest.
quotes.context: Sharing Stripe's clarifying question for making talent decisions

quotes.speaker: Rachel Lockett
quotes.text: Building a product and a business is about product market fit and the wave you're on. Timing is important. But everything besides that is so human. It's about talent, and it's about the environment that you put that talent in. You need to create the conditions such that your talent can thrive.
quotes.context: Emphasizing that beyond product-market fit and timing, business success is fundamentally about people

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: There is no such thing as a truly viral product. Even Facebook in its heyday had a viral factor of about 0.7. What I mean is, no app has sustained a viral factor of greater than one for any real period of time. The true secret behind virality is word of mouth. It is the virality you can't measure that isn't a mechanic that isn't in a feature. It is when one user spontaneously tells another user about your product.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: The Switch log. It's born out of the observation that your calendar says what you thought you were going to do, but it's really only your trail of work that describes what you actually did. What if I just did whatever the heck I wanted? Every single time I change task I just Slack DM'd my EA and said, 'TS:,' and then a few words for the task I was doing.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: I looked at all of the major font families, and honestly none of them was what I would call truly excellent. I was looking for a font that was in and of itself gorgeous, that could convey a message of any kind without overpowering the sentiment, that made reading speed and comprehension really fast, and that made email addresses themselves look great.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: Email is mission-critical. It's not something where you can simply launch with a half-baked product. When you have mission-critical products like email where you are interfacing with customers, with candidates, with investors, it turns out to really matter. That's why you can't just launch with a half-baked product.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: You have to pick something. The most well-known brands have stood for one clear thing, they have a clear position. So in order for Superhuman to be memorable, I believed that we needed to occupy a clear position that was unique and which was available and which reinforced our product strategy. That's how speed became our position.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: At peak we had about 20 people doing manual onboarding. What we found is two things.
