Number one, the user metrics are excellent for things like engagement, retention, product market fit score, MPS, virality. And number two, in a world where you can easily and quickly raise funding, you can actually use dollars to avoid building a first-time user experience and instead focus all of your engineers on finding product market fit.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: You can measure product market fit. You can optimize product market fit. You can systematically, even numerically increase product market fit. And you can even have an algorithm write your roadmap for you, and that is a roadmap that is guaranteed to increase product market fit.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: To get to product market fit, you have to deliberately not act on the feedback of many of your early users. You're listening to people intensely and building what people want. But it can't be all people. The question becomes, how do you listen to them? And then even of what they say, what do you pay attention to and what don't you?

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: We should make business software like we make games, because when we make products like we make games, people find them fun. They tell their friends, they fall in love with them. It's another way of backing into word of mouth. It's not gamification, that doesn't work. Game design works, but game design is not gamification.

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: Make fun toys and then combine those into games. The best games are constructed out of toys. Why? Because then they are fun on both levels, the toy and the game itself. Think about the features of your product. Do those features indulge playful exploration? Are they fun even without a goal? Do they elicit moments of pleasant surprise?

quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.text: SDR - Single Decisive Reason. For important decisions, you should be able to identify one reason that on its own supports the decision. All too often we rely on a collection of weak reasons to justify decisions. Multiple low quality reasons rarely add up to a high quality reason to do something.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: The advantage a smaller company has really is in latency. You can have an idea one day, you can test it the next day, and as a result you can have this really short cycle time between an assumption or a hypothesis and being able to validate that hypothesis. And that's just not true at larger companies where there's a lot more momentum.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: I've had to shift my mindset from an experimental-oriented approach to making decisions to much more of a conviction-oriented approach. Too often in a startup you can spend a lot of time in paralysis around analyzing market research or going through all of the different things you could do strategically.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: More often than not, when I talked to teams and helped to debug that issue, what it came down to was that there wasn't a deep enough understanding of what the strategy is. So what is the framework that should actually inform that prioritization? Oftentimes I was seeing difficulty prioritizing as well as tactical issues surface in the day-to-day and be able to be tracked back to pretty fundamental gaps in terms of an individual PM's understanding of strategy.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: Those five pieces, the company mission, the company strategy, the product strategy, the product roadmap, and the product goals all work together as a system where if a PM is looking to define strategy, they can work top to bottom, and if they're looking to debug strategy, they can actually work bottom to top.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: The analogy I like to use, it's a little bit like working with an architect. You would never work with an architect that didn't provide you a blueprint of the house that they want to build for you because being able to describe a house in words alone is not enough. Everyone will come away from that with a different interpretation of what is needed.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: I think it's really important for PMs to understand design, to understand UX and UI. Having that ability to think at a conceptual level about how UI and UX works is I think a critical part of being a product manager. And if it's a skill that you don't have today, there's great resources to be able to work on that skill.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: The analogy I like to use, it's a little bit like taking a road trip and starting out by saying, 'Hey, we need to drive 250 miles.' It's like, no, if you're going to take a road trip, you first decide where you want to drive to. If you're in LA, you might take a road trip to Vegas. And so our destination is Vegas, and we'll know whether or not we reach there if we've driven 250 miles. Because that 250-mile goal is in the context of a destination.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: The first type of risk is really understanding risk. And if you don't understand how to move a particular metric, then the right goal is to set a goal to increase your understanding not to move that metric. Once you have an understanding of how to move the metric, your team may or may not be able to execute very well.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: I think we can think about it as two by two matrix. On one axis of the matrix you have, did we hit our goals? And on the other access we have, do we know why? And ultimately you want to be in the upper right quadrant. You want to hit your goals and know why you hit your goals. Some teams are in the quadrant where they hit their goals, but they don't know why, which is good for now, but it's eventually going to catch up with you.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: I often encourage product leaders to think about their process of becoming more senior, not as a matter of getting more and more high level, but of increasing their dynamic range. So a CPO, it's not that a CPO never thinks about tactical issues, it's that they spend a lot of time on strategy, but they also can zoom into specific issues.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: There's another really effective way of leading which is selective micromanagement, which if you don't feel confident in the direction that your team is moving, the right answer is not to be hands-off and to let them go in that wrong direction. The right answer is to micromanage, but do it in a very tactical and a very temporary way so that you can help them understand what is the right direction moving forward so that you can then pull back.

quotes.speaker: Ravi Mehta
quotes.text: One of the things you can do if you are in a product role is ask them to do this exercise and evaluate you. Your manager will almost certainly have some impression of your performance that they haven't necessarily... If they're not doing it proactively, they probably have it intuitively. And helping them get it down on paper and getting it more specific can be a really good way to start that conversation.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: I think it's super important that founders see a line of sight to work on this for... I think my rule of thumb is a decade, just do you see yourself working on this for a decade? And maybe it's not a decade that you actually work on it. It probably won't, it either, it'll probably fail before then as most startups do, but I think it's a good litmus test for yourself.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: Product Hunt, we called it, not even a side project, we called it an experiment. And that framing I think, is for me, has always been helpful because an experiment is really not about success. Of course you want it to be successful, but the goal is not success. I put that in quotes, it's really to learn and, you know, see if people want this thing and then kind of adapt.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: The thing about launching is going back to why are you raising money. What's the goal? Same thing. Why are you launching? And a lot of people default to things like customer acquisition, but sometimes that's actually not useful. Launch sometimes doesn't help with that, but there are many other reasons why you might wanna launch.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: One of them is team morale. And this I think is overlooked. There is a powerful team morale and kinda building moment where you can all celebrate what you've accomplished and what you built and put it out to the world. And, you know, somebody on the team can share the Product Hunt launch or some Tech Crunch article with their mom. That seems like a trivial kind of meaningless thing, but it actually matters for a lot of people.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: One thing I've noticed among founders and just people in general is they tend to write like a PR person and not like a human. How do your customers or your users describe your product to other people? Or how do you describe it to your friends when you're just hanging out? That language resonates with people because it feels way more authentic.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: Another regret is I would've actually tried to monetize and generated revenue sooner. We raised a seed and a series A and we had capital to grow, and we didn't actually try to make money until after we acquired AngelList. If we would've started in 2014 to make some money, we coulda been cashflow break even 2015, 2016, which would've just given us a lot of flexibility in kind of owning your own destiny.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: Delegation is a classic founder challenge. I'm just generally a controlling person. That's something I'm working on. It's really hard sometimes when I have such strong opinions, and I'm very particular about certain things, to fully delegate and fully trust everybody. Up until shortly before I left, I was editing the newsletter every morning. I was waking up 5 a.m., 5:30 a.m., editing the newsletter. That's just kinda silly many years later.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: Being a CEO or a founder makes it slightly harder in some ways because you still have to put on this mask. You have to put on this face of confidence externally and internally as well, where people need to trust you. You also don't wanna subject them to the same anxiety that you're feeling and be 100% transparent. So, it's a struggle because I value authenticity so much.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: Momentum matters so much. And momentum is reflexive in that high momentum leads to more high momentum. Low momentum leads to more low momentum because there's this energy that kinda goes through companies where, when there is momentum, when people are shipping, when things are going well, other people feel that energy, and they wanna do the same.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: Consumer is you're always fighting for attention. You might be some consumer social company, but you're kind of like competing with Netflix too. Like people could be watching Netflix, or they could be using your product. So, now you're competing with so many different things. Many of those are incumbents where the consumer also has built-in habits, routines.

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: I think it's really hard to build a consumer company without some sort of unique insight, maybe impossible. I used to write a problem journal. Just when things annoyed me or when things were less efficient, I would write it down as a note. And I didn't try to solve it. I didn't say, 'Oh, here's the solution.' I was just like, 'This is annoying.'

quotes.speaker: Ryan Hoover
quotes.text: The more narrow you're generally, the easier it is to build a great solution for those people, because now you can actually hone in the product experience, the messaging, and everything to serve exactly those people. My bias is not to worry too much about if it's too small because what you probably find is, over time, opportunities to expand beyond that.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: In the first 30 seconds of using a new product, you are lazy, vain, and selfish. You want to get it done super quickly. You want to look good to your colleagues or to your friends. You want to feel successful very quickly by engaging in this product. You don't want to have to watch a tour or read anything, really endure any learning curve whatsoever.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: It's fascinating to me that most teams spend the final mile of their time building the product, considering the first mile of the customer's experience using the product. If you can just get more customers through that top of funnel, you are a world-class product team.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: The most humbling moments for me as a product leader have always been shoulder to shoulder to customers. Watching them actually go about their day, not just use my product but go about their day because what you end up getting is context for a lot of data that you're missing.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: Product leaders expect people to talk about a product being great. And people don't talk about a product doing exactly what they expected it to do. They talk about a product doing what they didn't expect.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: Whenever I'm asked by teams, what features need to be part of their MVP, how do they decide which features they need to ship first, I always tell them to optimize for the problems they want to have. You want the problem of customers getting through your funnel, feeling successful, using your product and getting value.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: So actually if you make the whole product about one thing, everyone does that. That core crank operates at 10X the velocity and if that's the most important metric for the business, that's gold. And so, we basically went on a killing spree. And we just started killing things.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: Some of the best product leaders that I've worked with, I do feel like they have this great reductionist or minimalistic tendency by default. They anchor themselves on the one thing they want people to do and do well. And they just are pretty ruthless about everything else.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: I always like to use the analogy of we're driving our teams across country as product leaders with the windows blacked out in the backseat and everyone's sitting in the backseat. If they don't receive the narrative, they will go stir-crazy. As product leaders, we have to merchandise progress. We have to be the steward of this narrative.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: How much conviction do you have in the solution you're building? I know in the beginning before you knew all you know now, you had tons of conviction. That's what caused you to leave your job. Now, knowing all you know, do you have more or less conviction in the problem and the solution you're building?

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: I have an allergic reaction to founders that are real promoters who are constantly trying to sugarcoat the truth, who like to gloss over the hard parts. I've always admired leaders that are optimistic about the future but very pragmatic and somewhat pessimistic about the present.

quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.text: I've always found that resourcefulness brings you further than resources despite the fact that over the last seven to 10 years, we've basically thrown resources at every problem. If resources are carbs, resourcefulness is like muscle. It stays with you. It makes you stronger.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: The Black Loop is someone comes in, they make a doc, they share with a group of people, some subset of the people turn around and make another doc, and the process repeats itself over and over again. The blue loop is someone comes in, makes a doc, and instead of sharing it with a team or with the collaborators, they publish it to the world.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: Almost all products have some form of loop. That person turns around and maybe sharing is built right in your product or maybe it's not, or maybe there's a way that it happens through advocacy, but understanding that the way products actually grow and spread happen through some type of loop not funnel, is I think pretty fundamental.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: He said great companies have a very small list of golden rituals. And there are three rules of golden rituals. Number one, they're named. Number two, every employee knows them by their first Friday and, number three, they're templated.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: When we're building companies, we actually build two products. We build one for our customers and we build another one for our employees. That's actually how we work part of it. That's the term he uses for that, is culture. That's the product we build for our employees.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: You can direct the writer, so you can tell people what to do. You can motivate the elephant, so you can give this thing a kick in the butt and it's going to move. You don't know exactly where it's going to move, but it's going to move. And you can shape the path. Shape the path is I'm going to set this way up so that you can only do these things.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: The eigenquestion, the simplest definition of eigenquestion, it's the question that when answered also answers the most subsequent questions. Rank them by which ones would eliminate the most other questions off the list.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: We basically have this discussion and we all came to the conclusion this market is going to value consistency over comprehensiveness. And by the way, I think, I mean now almost 15 years later, I think we were right. If you go look at video market obviously it exploded. There's so many great video properties out there, none of them are comprehensive.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: We value consistency over comprehensiveness. We would much rather be on fewer phones with a more consistent experience than be on all of them with an inconsistent experience.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: If you're a junior product manager, what happens? You get handed a problem. You get handed a solution. You get handed the how. And all you have to do is execute. At some point you become a little more senior. We hand you a problem and you come back with the solutions. And at some point you're senior enough that you tell us the problems.

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: Everything about leading up to this moment from high school and college has been about scope. And at this point you're all of a sudden told, 'We're not judging you on scope anymore. We're judging you on this PSHE thing that's very confusing.'

quotes.speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
quotes.text: I generally value the reference check over interview signals. If I had to stack rank in interviews, what is the best signal, the reference check is the top of the list. Those people, they worked with this person sometimes for years, their knowledge, what you're going to get out of 30 minutes of artificial scenarios, it's just never going to compare with what a good reference check will give you.

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: If you do a pre-mortem right, you will not have to do an ugly post-mortem. The genius is the initial prompt: imagine this project has failed six months from now. Now work backwards and ask what went wrong. It creates psychological safety for team members to talk about things they're concerned about without being negative.
quotes.context: Introducing the pre-mortem framework with tigers, paper tigers, and elephants

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: In a pre-mortem, bring up three things: a tiger (a threat that will actually kill us), a paper tiger (a seeming threat others worry about but you're not), and an elephant in the room that nobody is talking about. That shared vocabulary becomes powerful - in future meetings people started saying 'I have this tiger' and it became okay to bring those things up.
quotes.context: Explaining the specific structure of effective pre-mortems

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: All your tasks are not created equal. There are L tasks (leverage) where you put in effort and get 10X or 100X in return. N tasks (neutral) where you get what you put in. And O tasks (overhead) where you get back less than you put in. Most ambitious people treat each type the same way - and therein lies the problem.
quotes.context: Introducing the LNO framework for prioritizing PM time

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: The same activity can be an L, N, or O task depending on context. Filing a bug report can be leverage if it's a critical issue requiring detailed documentation, or overhead if it's minor and you're just being thorough. Taking notes can be leverage after a strategic CEO decision, or overhead after a routine sync.
quotes.context: Illustrating how the same activity requires different levels of effort based on strategic importance

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: Most execution problems that I encounter in high performing environments are actually not execution problems - they are either strategy problems or interpersonal problems or cultural problems. When you put on a bandaid and the bandaid falls off, it's probably not an execution issue.
quotes.context: Explaining why teams stay overwhelmed solving the same problems repeatedly

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: Two teams misaligned? It looks like an execution problem. But often it's because we don't know what the strategy is. We craft OKRs based on what makes sense, but they're not aligned because we lack clear strategy and priorities. All the review meetings in the world won't fix a strategy problem.
quotes.context: Illustrating how lack of strategy manifests as execution problems

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: In high leverage roles, stop doing work that simply provides positive ROI. Start focusing on work that minimizes opportunity cost. The problem with ROI mindset is you decrease the denominator by working on quick wins and low-hanging fruit. You fill your plate with quick wins and miss the upside by not focusing on optimal things.
quotes.context: Explaining the opportunity cost framework learned from observing Patrick Collison at Stripe

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: Opportunity cost is the value of the optimal option minus the value of the chosen option. When we reprogram ourselves to think in terms of opportunity cost, we're no longer thinking 'Is this a good use of my time?' Instead: 'Is this the best use of my time?' It's a subtle but profound shift.
quotes.context: Contrasting opportunity cost thinking with traditional ROI thinking

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: I learned from Google's 70-20-10: during planning, give teams allocation guidance. 60% on incrementals (high ROI features), 30% on big new initiatives (can't be five initiatives, probably one or two), 10% on stability and infrastructure. This gives people space to pursue the right things instead of filling everything with quick wins.
quotes.context: Sharing tactical guidance on portfolio allocation to enable opportunity cost thinking

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: High agency is finding a way to get what you want without waiting for conditions to be perfect or blaming circumstances. The PMs who surprised me in positive ways - exceeded their capabilities on paper - all had high agency: strong ownership, creative execution through challenges, and high resilience.
quotes.context: Describing the trait that differentiates high-impact PMs from those with unrealized potential

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: At Google I learned the power of thinking really big. There was this unwritten rule: if it's not going to generate more than $100 million in revenue, it's not worth talking about. They would regularly not pursue $100 million opportunities because they had access to billion dollar ones. That habit to ask 'can we make it 10X bigger?' got ingrained.
quotes.context: Describing Google's culture of thinking big and pursuing only massive opportunities

quotes.speaker: Shreyas Doshi
quotes.text: Jack Dorsey would just listen a lot more than you'd expect the CEO to listen. Then he would ask one vital question. We discussed a potential acquisition - went through all the intellectual arguments, strategic arguments, metrics arguments. Jack asked: 'How does this make our users love Twitter more?' Simple question. We never really talked about that. I didn't have a good answer.
quotes.context: Describing Jack Dorsey's leadership style and ability to ask penetrating questions

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: We're on these narrow sidewalks in Vancouver when it starts raining. Most people with umbrellas wouldn't move them out of the way - the pokey bits are at eye level. Only one-third would tilt their umbrella. We said your failure to really exercise this courtesy and be empathic about other people's experience is an advantage that you can create.
quotes.context: The umbrella tilt story that became a core Slack value about product craftsmanship and empathy

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: Utility curves: first bit of effort produces no value, then there's a magic threshold where it produces enormous value, then continued investment doesn't pay off. We would investigate whether we were on the first shallow part of the curve, the second shallow part, or just coming up to it. This helped us decide whether something was worth it.
quotes.context: Explaining the utility curve S-curve framework for product investment decisions

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: It became an assumption that you should always be trying to remove friction. But the challenge is really comprehension. If your software stops me and asks me to make a decision and I don't really understand it, you make me feel stupid. Instead of reducing clicks or taps, focus on how can I make this simple? How do I prevent people from having to think?
quotes.context: Explaining why comprehension matters more than reducing friction or clicks

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: Have you exhausted the possibilities? Creating the distance so that you can make an intellectual rational decision rather than an emotional decision is essential. The reason I say you have to be coldly rational is because pivoting is fucking humiliating. You convinced so many people - investors, employees, press, users - and now you're admitting 'I was wrong. This didn't work.'
quotes.context: Explaining the emotional difficulty of pivoting after Glitch  Slack and Flickr pivots

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: This is 2014, the year Slack launched. MIT Technology Review asked if we were working to improve Slack. I said, 'I feel like what we have right now is just a giant piece of shit. It's terrible and we should be humiliated that we offer this to the public.' If you can't see almost limitless opportunities to improve, you shouldn't be designing the product.
quotes.context: Expressing divine discontent and high standards for Slack even after launch

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: We invented the magic link experience. Typing your password on your phone if you have any minimal threshold of password hygiene is a terrible experience. Capital H, lowercase Q, six, caret, period. So let's just have them enter email address, send them a link, and it automatically opens the app and authenticates them.
quotes.context: Describing Slack's early UX innovation that became an industry standard

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: We came up with the shouty rooster. When you @everyone, a little rooster pops up with sound waves and says 'This is going to cause a notification for 147 people in eight different time zones. Are you sure?' That worked amazingly - it dropped off the abuse. It also taught people how the product worked because they probably didn't think about the cost.
quotes.context: Example of delightful UX that shapes behavior and prevents spam

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: In the long run, the measure of our success will be the amount of value that we create for customers. You can put effort into demonstrating that you have created this value, but there's no substitute for actually having created it. I made everyone in the company repeat this as a chant at all hands.
quotes.context: The core philosophy that guided Slack's product development

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: The default advice for anyone is persevere - 'hang in there.' But I think you have to be coldly rational. Slack had an enormous advantage: we were working on it for several years without explicitly working on it, only doing features that were so irritating we couldn't stand it anymore. When I had exhausted every non-ridiculous long shot idea to make Glitch commercially successful, I decided to abandon it.
quotes.context: Explaining when to pivot vs persevere using the Glitch  Slack example

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: Don't Make Me Think. For two reasons: it's expensive to make a decision - you literally burn glucose, there's cognitive cost. But also there's an emotional aspect: if your software stops me and asks me to make a decision I don't understand, you make me feel stupid. Most people feel 'I'm dumb' not 'the software is stupid.' They associate that bad feeling with the product forever.
quotes.context: Expanding on the Don't Make Me Think mantra with biological and emotional reasoning

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: Google Calendar's time zone picker presents all time zones in alphabetical order. When I type E-A-S-T, first one is Eastern Australia, New South Wales. It's bananas how bad it is - used by hundreds of millions, presumably every Google employee. No one's going to switch from Outlook because the time zone picker is good, but there's real value in delighting customers. That emotional connection makes them recommend it or advocate for it when they switch companies.
quotes.context: Using Google Calendar as example of neglecting craft and its impact on emotional connection

quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.text: When we shut down Glitch, there were people who loved it and would spend all their free time on it. That was their community and it just disappeared. People lost jobs, people who moved families to different cities. Pivots aren't something I take lightly. It's very different to be like 'there's three of us and we pivoted to a different app.' If you're six months in, you're still messing around. That doesn't even really count.
quotes.context: Reflecting on the painful human cost of pivoting from Glitch to Slack

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: A lot of teams, they learn how to do their jobs building products by being told, 'Build these features.' That's a really structured, okay, I just turn out some work problem. And so, we're asking teams to fundamentally do a really different type of job and I think teams needed some scaffolding for how do you make that shift.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: We tend to just really struggle with this distinction between the problem space and the solution space. I think that the heart of good product is really getting comfortable in the problem space or the opportunity space, really taking the time to frame a problem well, and to really get into what's needed before we jump to solutions.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: So the first thing that makes this hard is you have to interview well. I think interviewing is a grossly underestimated skill. Grossly underestimated skill. So that's the first thing is that if you're not collecting rich stories in your interviews, it's going to be really hard to identify opportunities.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: I tell my teams when I teach it in class, I say, 'Look, we're going to focus on structuring an opportunity space, and I'm probably going to make you think harder than you've ever had to think in your job,' because we don't think that much at work. We go from meeting to meeting, we stay surface level a lot.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: I hear from people all the time say, 'I'm not allowed to talk to customers.' I go, 'Okay, well, your company doesn't own you when you're not at work. I bet you know people like your customers. Why don't you just start there?'

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: People make this mistake of we shouldn't put something in our backlog that hasn't been properly discovered. It's not true. Everything in our backlog is a bet, everything. Whether we do discovery or not, everything is a bet. Discovery is helping us make a better bet.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: I think the reason why people make this mistake is they think about it as phases. First I discover and then I deliver. No, you're always delivering and you're always discovering. The more you build this discovery habit, the better those bets are going to get with time.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: The outcome is that we don't really collaborate. When we don't collaborate, I don't think we build very good products. So if we just go back to real life and when you're hanging out with friends and you're trying to accomplish something, you don't first stop and say, 'What's my role? What's your role?' That's just not how humans interact. We all collaborate intuitively. Business has taught us otherwise.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: Kindergartners just start doing. They don't worry about their rules. They don't worry about who's in charge. They just brute force trial and error. What do MBA students do? There's posturing, like who has power and who's the decision-maker and who's right? They spend the whole time negotiating this political social space instead of just doing.

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: Product people are in the business of changing behavior, understanding and changing behavior. I think that's a really big mistake that teams make is, both in their prototype tests and in their interviews, they focus on what people would do, on what people think. It's all really unreliable. It's a garbage in, garbage out situation. The real measure is tell me about your behavior. What did you actually do?

quotes.speaker: Teresa Torres
quotes.text: I don't know why product teams suddenly are held to a standard that nobody else is held to. When somebody says, 'Why is it reliable to make a decision based on one interview?' I flip the question around. Tell me about the decisions you made last week. How many customers did you talk to? Every human in business is making decisions with zero data. So I'm going to go with one is better than zero.

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: My energy source is dissatisfaction with status quo. I think today is the dystopia of the future. It behooves us to try to build the kinds of products that lead towards progress.
quotes.context: Describing what drives him as a founder and why he rejects copying existing solutions

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: A Tobi tornado is a whole lot of change management compressed into a very short timeframe. If I imagine something might not be the right thing to work on, I'm either incorrect or I'm correct - and it's super unfair for letting people work on something that isn't going to make it.
quotes.context: Explaining the 'Tobi tornado' phenomenon of rapidly killing projects when he realizes they won't work

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: I really, really, really think that there is not a single person on this planet who is even close to being at their maximum potential. Reminding people of their own potential constantly is actually a wonderful thing to do.
quotes.context: Explaining his philosophy of maximizing human potential through high standards and direct feedback

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: The most powerful unquantifiable things in the world of business are fun and delight. If all the metrics are pointing down but everyone says 'My God, I'm having so much more fun,' I think the very next thing that will happen with some time delay is all metrics will start going up.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify doesn't use OKRs and instead prioritizes unquantifiable things over metrics

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: Optimism always sounds dumb, or at least naive. Pessimism sounds extremely sophisticated. Metrics driven sounds sophisticated. Talking about fun sounds naive. But almost all of the alpha in the world is now in exactly the things that are unobvious but true.
quotes.context: Challenging conventional business aesthetics and why contrarian approaches often win

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: If you want to do something better than what exists, you have to do it differently. That's axiomatically not possible to do the same thing and get better results. It fails Archimedean logic.
quotes.context: Explaining why first principles thinking requires doing things differently from everyone else

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: 100 years, you can't talk about this software product but you can talk about the mission itself. Entrepreneurship is just precious. Shopify exists basically to make entrepreneurship more common.
quotes.context: Describing Shopify's 100-year vision and how long-term thinking shapes decision-making

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: On a long enough timeline, playing positive-sum games with your customers is the ultimate growth hack. The best companies resemble a room full of dials or levers for monetization. My job is adding as many of these levers as possible to the room, and then not pulling any of them.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify doesn't maximize short-term monetization despite having pricing power

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: The business world only talks about tactics - conversion optimization, A/B tests, growth hacks. I don't think that's important. The positional game is what matters: what territory are you taking? How much trust do you have? If you do that well, the tactics are yours. But if you extract through tactics all the value you created, you have nothing left in the tank.
quotes.context: Contrasting short-term tactical optimization with long-term strategic positioning

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: Goodhart's law: Any metric that becomes a goal ceases to be a good metric. It's the same as overfitting in machine learning. School optimizes for marks, and overfitting in school is literally kids cheating to get marks. We're extremely data-informed but we don't have KPIs because no metric by itself is a complete heuristic for a complex business.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify core product team operates without KPIs despite being extremely data-informed

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: Most of the time you end up in a bad part of a tree, in a local maxima of a path-dependent environment, by only making good choices. The presence of a downside of an idea does not disqualify the idea. You need to rerun the entire function over the state that is now updated with higher fidelity information.
quotes.context: Explaining why Shopify went fully remote during COVID by re-running first principles analysis when foundational assumptions changed

quotes.speaker: Tobi Ltke
quotes.text: When someone disagrees with me, I immediately love it. I really crave it. I think courage is really rare. I found a lot more high IQ in industry than courage. I found a lot more genius than courage. What I'm looking for is unstated foundational assumptions - what is our divergence point?
quotes.context: Describing how to disagree with him and why he values courage over intelligence

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: When we look at the skills required to do your job, by 2030, which is literally four years from now, sounds a long time, but four years from now, it will change by 70%. So whether or not you're looking to change your job, your job is changing. The only question is, do you keep it?
quotes.context: Tomer shares LinkedIn's unique data insight about how dramatically skills requirements are shifting, setting the context for why the Full Stack Builder model is necessary.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: In order to stay competitive, you actually have to go back to some first principles, go back to the drawing board and reimagine what it means to be building. And what I love about this is when you think about the role of a builder, which the builder is at the heart of company, the goal is actually quite simple. The builder takes an idea, she brings it to life.
quotes.context: Tomer advocates for returning to fundamentals rather than adding more complexity, emphasizing that the builder's core job is simply to bring ideas to life.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: And now we have this real opportunity to collapse the stack backup, go back to craftsmanship, rethink the product development lifecycle, which is where the full stack builder model comes to life.
quotes.context: After explaining how product development became bloated with process and microspecialization, Tomer introduces the Full Stack Builder model as a return to craftsmanship.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: The key trait that I'm emphasizing for builders is where I want them to spend their time is where I think great builders should shine in. So the idea of vision. Coming up with a compelling sense about the future. Empathy, super critical. Communication is critical. Creativity. And then ultimately what I think is the most important trait for a builder is judgment. Everything else, I'm working really hard to automate.
quotes.context: Tomer identifies the five core human traits that AI cannot replace: vision, empathy, communication, creativity, and most importantly, judgment.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: An analogy I have in mind is kind of Navy SEALs. You come to training, they're all kind of learning, they're cross-trained, across multiple areas. What they specialize in is the mission and they operate in small pods and they're very nimble and you can assemble them very quickly. And I think that's going to be the organization that will win in the future.
quotes.context: Tomer uses the Navy SEALs as a model for future product organizations: cross-trained individuals who specialize in missions, not functions.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: If you're at a company at a scale of ours and many others in the market, you're like, this is almost like a new production function and mindset that you have to do. And there's really three components that we're working on. One is platform. The second one is the tools and the agents. And lastly is the culture.
quotes.context: Tomer outlines the three-pillar framework for implementing the Full Stack Builder model at scale companies: platform, tools/agents, and culture.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: You can't just bring a third party tool and have it work on the LinkedIn stack. In fact, that's one of our biggest learnings. It never works. Never works. You have to bring it in and customize a lot of it, working almost in alpha mode with those companies to make it work internally.
quotes.context: A key learning from LinkedIn's AI transformation: off-the-shelf AI tools never work at enterprise scale without significant customization.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: It's not great to just give it access to your drive and say, 'Reason all over this knowledge base.' It actually does a very poor job understanding importance of the past and putting weights on stuff. You actually want to think about specifically what the context when do you want to give it to and what's the knowledge base that you want to have it focused on.
quotes.context: Tomer explains why simply giving AI access to all company data fails - you need curated golden examples and focused knowledge bases for quality outputs.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: Top talent has this tendency of continuously trying to get better at their craft and this innate need to be at the cutting edge of how you build, and I think we're seeing this here as well. This is why I had this phrase I say with the team that if we build all those tools, will they use it? And I know right now the answer is no. It's not enough to give them the tools to use it.
quotes.context: Tomer observes that top performers are the biggest adopters of AI tools, but providing tools alone is insufficient - you need incentives, motivation, and examples.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: Change management here is going to be a critical part. I think I see a lot of companies roll out their agents and just expecting companies to adopt. It doesn't work this way. Some will adopt. That tends to be your cutting edge 5% of talent that just wants new tools and they have a bias for change. But the vast majority needs to work for change management.
quotes.context: A warning against the 'build it and they will come' mentality with AI tools - only 5% will naturally adopt, the rest need deliberate change management.

quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.text: If you're looking for a formal reorg or declaration to start building differently, you're waiting too long. Look, my biggest thing is here's a permission for me to just not wait and just go. So whether or not you have the right tools or not, go build the tool, use a tool from the outside, bring it in, show those examples.
quotes.context: Tomer's direct advice to individuals: don't wait for organizational permission to start building with AI - demonstrate the full stack builder mindset now.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: If I'm not getting the reaction that I'm looking for, how might I be contributing to that? Instead of blaming other people for not understanding me, I think about how could I explain this more clearly? How can I be more compelling? How can I anticipate any questions that they might have? I'm a big proponent of agency.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: I see a lot of operators who save their best behavior for executives only. They want to shine when they're presenting to senior leadership, but with everyone else, they're kind of calling it. I just don't think that you're going to be able to get enough reps to actually get good at executive communication if you are only doing it with executives.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: A common mistake that I see is overestimating the amount of buy-in that you have from your audience. That looks like jumping straight into talking about the logistics, the details of the how to do something, when in reality your audience has not yet decided if they even want to do the thing.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: Being concise is not about absolute word count, it's about economy of words. It's about the density of the insight that you're sharing. You can have a 300 word memo that's meandering and long-winded and a thousand word memo that is tight and concise.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: We've all heard 'Don't bury the lead, cut to the chase, put the main point at the top.' All of these pithy aphorisms assume that you actually know what your core point is. You can't cut to the chase unless you know what the chase is. That's the bottleneck to being concise. It's actually not being clear of what you are thinking.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: The blast radius of a poorly written memo is way bigger than most people think. If you're just shooting off a message in a Slack channel with 15 other people and it's confusing, there's going to be a bunch of back and forth. Whereas if you had just taken another look at it, those 15 people would be off to the races.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: All these little things compound and make a big difference. I often hear people think this individual email or Slack message is not worth spending a couple more minutes on. The problem with that line of thinking is that no one instance is ever going to feel important enough, and when you zoom out, that's all your work then.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: MOO stands for Most Obvious Objection. A lot of times we're surprised by the questions that we get, especially in meetings where we feel blindsided. When really, if you thought for even two minutes about what are obvious objections that I'm likely to get, you often immediately come up with what some of those things are.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: One of the most common myths about managing up that I definitely felt early on was that I would have to manage up if I were more junior, but eventually I would outgrow it. It was a rude awakening that no matter how senior I got, not only did I have to manage up, it actually became more important.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: When you just ask your manager 'What should we do?' you're putting a lot of cognitive load on them to think about the problem, think about potential solutions, craft the solution, and then tell you what to do. Whereas if you said 'Here's what I think we should do, how does that sound?' you give them something to build off of.

quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.text: I have a framework called strategy, not self-expression. By the time we are giving feedback to someone, we have been frustrated for a while. The goal is behavior change. So trim everything that does not contribute to that goal and only keep the part that will make the person want to change.
